TEXT.English: [H1]Boudica[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen of the Celts[NEWLINE]Lived:[\BOLD] ? - 61AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Boudica was a queen of the Iceni, a Celtic people who lived on the eastern coast of Britain. The Roman Emperor Claudius had conquered much of Britain some twenty years ago; according to the treaty with the Iceni, Boudica's husband King Prasutagus would continue to rule his kingdom until his death, at which time it would come under Roman rule. Prasutagus died in approximately 60 AD, and the Romans were quick to seize control of the kingdom. According to the historical sources, the Romans treated their new subjects with unbridled cruelty, and greed. Boudica and her daughters were beaten and raped and sent like beggars from their kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:1]This was a huge mistake. The Romans badly underestimated the Celtic Queen: they would have been far better off killing her outright or treating her with the respect her title deserved.[PARAGRAPH:1]According to Cassius Dio, a Roman historian, Boudica was "very tall, in appearance most terrifying, in the glance of her eye most fierce, and her voice was harsh; a great mass of the tawniest hair fell to her hips; around her neck was a large golden necklace." She was also possessed of a great intelligence and was beloved by her people.[PARAGRAPH:1]After her humiliation Boudica convinced a number of nearby kingdoms to revolt against the rapacious Romans; they quickly raised a large army and made Boudica the commander.[PARAGRAPH:1]At the time, Paulus, the Roman in charge of the island's military forces, was away on business. In his absence Boudica's army wreaked havoc across the island, visiting on their Roman prisoners the same sort of depredations the Romans had recently tormented the Celts with. A number of Roman cities were burned, and the campaign ended with the capture and destruction of the important city of "Londinium" (London).[PARAGRAPH:1]By then the Roman forces had rallied, and though badly outnumbered, had decided to make their stand some miles distant from Boudica. The queen immediately launched an attack against the hated foe. Although she had the great advantage of numbers, her army was no match for the disciplined and highly-trained Roman troops, who blunted the initial Celtic rush with a wave of thrown javelins and then proceeded to kill every Celtic warrior they could catch. Boudica is said to have killed herself rather than risk Roman capture.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although she had led her people for only a year, Boudica's valiant but doomed rebellion would make her a legendary figure in history. Europe would not see another female warrior of her quality for some fourteen centuries, until a young woman named "Joan" would a see vision telling her to rise and fight for the Catholic King of France.
TEXT.French: [H1]Boadicée[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reine des Celtes[NEWLINE]Dates:[\BOLD] ? - 61 ap. J.C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] Boadicée est la reine des Icéni, peuple celtique qui vit sur la côte orientale de la Bretagne. Vingt années avant son règne, l'empereur romain Claudius a conquis une grande partie de la Bretagne et selon le traité qu'il a conclu avec les Icéni, le roi Prasutagus, mari de Boadicée, doit continuer à gouverner son royaume jusqu'à sa mort, à la suite de quoi les territoires tomberaient sous contrôle romain. Prasutagus meurt vers 60 ap. J.C, et les Romains s'empressent alors de prendre le contrôle du royaume. D'après les sources historiques, les Romains traitent leurs nouveaux sujets avec une effroyable cruauté et une grande cupidité. Boadicée et ses filles sont battues et violées puis bannies de leur royaume.[PARAGRAPH:1]C'est une énorme erreur. Les Romains ont gravement sous-estimé la reine celtique : ils auraient bien mieux fait de la tuer immédiatement ou de la traiter avec le respect que son titre méritait.[PARAGRAPH:1]Selon Dion Cassius, historien romain, Boadicée "avait une taille gigantesque, l'aspect terrifiant, une voix rude. Une grande masse de cheveux rouges brillants lui tombait jusqu'aux genoux et elle portait un grand collier d'or torsadé." Elle est également douée d'une grande intelligence et elle est aimée de son peuple.[PARAGRAPH:1]Après son humiliation, Boadicée persuade un grand nombre de royaumes voisins de se révolter contre les avides Romains ; ils lèvent rapidement une armée et confient son commandement à Boadicée.[PARAGRAPH:1]A ce moment-là, Paulus, le romain en charge des forces militaires de l'île, est parti pour affaires. En son absence, l'armée de Boadicée fait des ravages à travers l'île, infligeant aux prisonniers romains le même genre de supplices que ceux que les Romains ont fait subir aux Celtes. Un grand nombre de villes romaines sont brûlées et la campagne se termine par la capture et la destruction de la grande ville de "Londinium" (Londres).[PARAGRAPH:1]Entre-temps, les troupes romaines se sont rassemblées et, bien que surpassés en nombre, elles sont bien décidées à résister. La reine lance aussitôt une attaque contre l'ennemi exécré. Son armée est en supériorité numérique mais ne peut pas faire le poids face aux troupes romaines, plus disciplinées et mieux entraînées. Les Romains accueillent le premier assaut celtique par une vague de javelots puis entreprennent de tuer le plus de guerriers celtes possible. La légende raconte que Boadicée se serait tuée plutôt que de risquer d'être capturée par les Romains.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bien qu'elle n'ait gouverné son peuple que l'espace d'une année, la révolte de Boadicée, courageuse mais vouée à l'échec, en fait un personnage légendaire. L'Europe va devoir attendre quatorze siècles avant de voir apparaître une autre combattante de sa trempe, une jeune femme prénommée Jeanne à laquelle une voix aurait demandé de se battre pour le roi catholique de France.
TEXT.German: [H1]Boudicca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Königin der Kelten[NEWLINE]Lebte:[\BOLD] ? - 61 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Boudicca war Königin der Icener, eines keltischen Volkes, das an der Ostküste Großbritanniens lebte. Der römische Kaiser Claudius hatte 20 Jahre zuvor große Teile Großbritanniens erobert. Laut dem Vertrag mit den Icenern sollte König Prasutagus, Boudiccas Mann, seine Herrschaft bis zu seinem Tod fortsetzen - danach fiel das Königreich unter römische Herrschaft. Prasutagus starb etwa 60 n. Chr. und die Römer übernahmen sehr bald die Herrschaft des Königreichs. Laut den historischen Quellen behandelten die Römer ihre neuen Untertanen mit ungezügelter Grausamkeit und Habgier. Boudicca und ihre Töchter wurden geschlagen, vergewaltigt und wie Bettlerinnen aus ihrem Königreich verjagt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das war ein großer Fehler. Die Römer hatten die keltische Königin vollkommen unterschätzt. Sie hätten besser daran getan, sie entweder direkt zu töten oder sie mit dem ihr gebührenden Respekt zu behandeln.[PARAGRAPH:1]Laut Cassius Dio, einem römischen Historiker, war Boudicca von Furcht erregender Größe, mit einem wuterfüllten Glanz in ihren Augen und rauer Stimme. Ihr volles, rötliches Haar reichte bis zu den Hüften und um den Hals trug sie eine dicke, goldene Halskette. Sie war zudem äußerst intelligent und wurde von ihrem Volk geliebt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem sie so sehr erniedrigt worden war, überzeugte Boudicca eine Reihe nahe gelegener Königreiche, sich gegen die raubgierigen Römer aufzulehnen. Sie bildeten rasch eine große Armee und ernannten Boudicca zur Heerführerin.[PARAGRAPH:1]Paulus, der Verantwortliche für die römischen Streitkräfte auf der Insel, war zu dieser Zeit gerade auf Reisen. In seiner Abwesenheit richtete Boudiccas Armee auf der Insel verheerende Verwüstungen an und ließ ihren römischen Gefangenen dieselbe Behandlung zuteil werden, wie sie die keltischen Gefangenen durch die Römer erfahren hatten. Einige römische Städte wurden niedergebrannt, und der Feldzug endete mit der Eroberung und der Zerstörung der wichtigen Stadt "Londinium" (London).[PARAGRAPH:1]Die römischen Streitkräfte hatten sich inzwischen gesammelt, und obwohl sie deutlich in der Unterzahl waren, beschlossen sie, ihr Lager einige Meilen entfernt von Boudicca aufzuschlagen. Die Königin startete sofort einen Angriff gegen den verhassten Feind. Obwohl sie zahlenmäßig weit überlegen war, konnte ihre Armee es jedoch nicht mit den disziplinierten und gut ausgebildeten römischen Truppen aufnehmen, die den Ansturm der Kelten mit einem Hagel aus Speeren beantworteten, und danach dazu übergingen, jeden keltischen Krieger zu töten, den sie zu fassen bekamen. Boudicca soll eher Selbstmord begangen haben, als sich von den Römern gefangen nehmen zu lassen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Obwohl sie ihr Volk nur ein Jahr lang angeführt hatte, wurde sie durch ihren mutigen, wenn auch zum Scheitern verurteilten Aufstand zu einer legendären Figur der Geschichte. 14 Jahrhunderte lang würde es in Europa keine Kriegerin ihres Kalibers geben, bis eine junge Frau namens Jeanne eine Vision hatte, die ihr befahl, sich zu erheben und für den katholischen König Frankreichs zu kämpfen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Boudica[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regina dei Celti[NEWLINE]Vita:[\BOLD] ? - 61 d.C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Boudica era la regina degli Iceni, una popolazione celtica che viveva sulle coste orientali della Britannia. L'imperatore romano Claudio aveva conquistato gran parte della Britannia una ventina d'anni prima; secondo il trattato con gli Iceni, Re Prasutago (marito di Boudica) avrebbe continuato a regnare fino alla propria morte, alla quale le sue terre sarebbero passate sotto il dominio romano. Prasutago morì nel 60 d.C. circa e i Romani presero rapidamente il controllo del suo regno. Secondo le fonti storiche, i Romani vessarono i nuovi sudditi con crudeltà e avidità. Boudica e le sue figlie vennero prima picchiate e stuprate, quindi cacciate come mendicanti dal loro regno.[PARAGRAPH:1]Fu un madornale errore. I Romani sottovalutarono malamente la Regina dei Celti: avrebbero fatto molto meglio a ucciderla subito o a trattarla con il rispetto che esigeva il suo titolo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Secondo Dione Cassio, uno storico romano, Boudica era "molto alta, dall'aspetto terrificante, dallo sguardo fiero e dalla voce dura; una grande massa di capelli fulvi le ricadeva fino ai fianchi; attorno al collo aveva una grossa collana d'oro". Era anche molto intelligente e amata dal proprio popolo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dopo l'umiliazione, Boudica convinse un numero di regni confinanti a rivoltarsi contro i Romani; ben presto si ritrovarono con un grande esercito, nominando Boudica come comandante.[PARAGRAPH:1]A quel tempo Paolo, il romano al comando delle forze militari dell'isola, era assente e l'esercito di Boudica seminò la distruzione sull'isola, riservando ai propri prigionieri romani lo stesso fato che essi stessi avevano imposto ai Celti. Vennero bruciate delle città romane e la campagna terminò con la distruzione dell'importante città di "Londinium" (Londra).[PARAGRAPH:1]A quel punto le forze dei Romani si erano riprese e, nonostante fortemente svantaggiate numericamente, decisero di affrontare Boudica. La regina lanciò immediatamente un attacco contro l'odiato nemico. Anche se aveva il grande vantaggio numerico, il suo esercito non poteva competere con le truppe altamente addestrate e disciplinate dei Romani, che rallentarono la carica iniziale dei Celti col lancio di giavellotti e poi uccisero ogni guerriero celtico che riuscirono a raggiungere. Si dice che Boudica preferì uccidersi piuttosto che farsi catturare dai Romani.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nonostante abbia guidato il proprio popolo per un solo anno, la coraggiosa e condannata ribellione di Boudica l'ha resa una figura leggendaria. L'Europa non avrebbe visto un'altra figura di donna guerriera prima di altri quattordici secoli, quando una giovane di nome "Giovanna" seguì una visione che le disse di combattere per il Re cattolico di Francia.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Boadicea[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reina de los celtas[NEWLINE]Vivió:[\BOLD] ? - 61 d. C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Boadicea fue reina de los icenos, un pueblo celta que vivía en la costa oriental de Bretaña. Unos veinte años antes, el emperador romano Claudio había conquistado la mayor parte del país; según el tratado firmado con los icenos, el marido de Boadicea, el rey Prasutagus, seguiría reinando hasta su muerte, momento en que los romanos heredarían el país. Prasutagus murió en torno al año 60 d. C., y los romanos no perdieron un momento en apoderarse del reino. De acuerdo con varias fuentes históricas, los nuevos señores de Bretaña se comportaron con codicia y crueldad intolerables. Boadicea y sus hijas, apaleadas y violadas, fueron expulsadas de su reino como si fueran miserables vagabundas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Fue un terrible error. Los romanos subestimaron gravemente a la reina celta: más les habría valido ejecutarla inmediatamente o tratarla con el respeto que su título merecía.[PARAGRAPH:1]Según Dion Casio, un historiador romano, Boadicea era "muy alta, de apariencia aterradora, mirada feroz, y voz ronca; una gran masa del cabello más rebelde que quepa imaginar le caía hasta las caderas; y alrededor del cuello llevaba una gran gargantilla de oro". Además, poseía una gran inteligencia y disfrutaba del amor de su pueblo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tras la humillación, Boadicea convenció a varios de los reinos circundantes de que se rebelaran contra los codiciosos romanos; entre todos reclutaron rápidamente un gran ejército, del que fue nombrada comandante.[PARAGRAPH:1]En aquel momento, Paulo, comandante de las fuerzas romanas, no se encontraba en el país. Aprovechando su ausencia, el ejército de Boadicea se dedicó a sembrar el caos por toda la isla, y trató a los prisioneros romanos como éstos habían tratado hasta entonces a los celtas. Varias ciudades romanas fueron incendiadas, y la campaña terminó con la captura y destrucción de la importante urbe de "Londinium" (Londres).[PARAGRAPH:1]A esas alturas, las fuerzas romanas se habían recuperado y, aunque ampliamente superadas en número, decidieron presentar batalla en un punto situado a varios kilómetros del ejército de Boadicea. Sin perder un instante, la reina lanzó un ataque contra sus odiados enemigos. Pero a pesar de contar con una considerable superioridad numérica, su ejército no era rival para las disciplinadas y profesionales tropas romanas, que repelieron el asalto inicial de los celtas con una lluvia de jabalinas y luego procedieron a aniquilar al enemigo. Según la leyenda, Boadicea se dio muerte antes de dejarse capturar por los romanos.[PARAGRAPH:1]Aunque solo había gobernado a su pueblo durante un año, su valentía como líder de una revolución sin esperanza la convertiría en una figura legendaria. Europa no conocería otra guerrera comparable a ella hasta casi catorce siglos más tarde, cuando una mujer llamada Juana recibiera en una visión la orden de levantarse y tomar las armas para luchar por el rey de Francia.

TEXT.English: [H1]Brennus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Celtic Chieftain[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] ? - 279 BC[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Other than that he was a fearsome and successful warrior, little is known about the Celtic chieftain named Brennus. In 279 BC, he led an army of Celtic warriors on an invasion of Macedonia and northern Greece. They turned the Greek defense at the pass of Thermopylae and sacked the famous Oracle at Delphi - Brennus was wounded in the fighting. From there, the Celts penetrated into Epirus (roughly modern Albania) and looted the treasures stored at the temples of Zeus at Dodona and Olympia. After those triumphs the Greek resistance stiffened. Brennus retreated to Macedonia, where he died of his wounds. Without the leadership of their chieftain, the Celtic warriors split up and went in separate directions. Most of them returned to their homes in Gaul along with the treasure they had pillaged, while a few others headed east and settled in Asia Minor. This group came to be called the Galatians, and remained distinct from their surrounding neighbors for at least two centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]The name "Brennus" is more likely a title than a proper name - in fact the same title was later given to another Celtic chieftain who sacked Rome in 390 BC. It is very likely that the Welsh word "Brenin," meaning king, derived from that title.
TEXT.French: [H1]Brennus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chef Celte[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] ? - 279 av. J-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Outre ses succès et son intrépidité, on sait peu de choses sur le chef celte et guerrier qu'était Brennus. En 279 av. J.-C., il conduit une armée de guerriers celtiques lors de l'invasion de la Macédoine et du nord de la Grèce. Ils attaquent la défense grecque au col des Thermopyles puis saccagent le célèbre oracle de Delphes ; Brennus est blessé pendant les combats. A partir de là, les Celtes pénètrent l'Epire, qui correspond à peu près à l'actuelle Albanie et pillent les trésors entreposés dans les temples de Zeus à Dodone et Olympie. Cependant, après ces triomphes des Celtes, la défense grecque se renforce. Brennus se retire en Macédoine où il meurt des suites de ses blessures. En l'absence de leur chef, les guerriers celtes se séparent. La majorité retourne en Gaule avec le butin de leurs pillages, tandis que d'autres se dirigent vers l'est et s'installent en Asie mineure. Ce groupe se fait alors appeler Galates et, pendant au moins deux siècles, refuse de se mélanger avec ses voisins.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le nom de "Brennus" est certainement plus un titre qu'un véritable nom. En effet, il a été donné plus tard à un autre chef celte qui pilla Rome en 390 av. J.-C. Il est probable qu'il ait donné naissance au terme gallois "Brenin", qui signifie roi.
TEXT.German: [H1]Brennus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Keltischen Stammeshäuptling[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ? - 279 v. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Außer der Tatsache, dass er ein gefürchteter und siegreicher Krieger war, ist über den keltischen Stammeshäuptling Brennus nur wenig bekannt. Im Jahr 279 vor Christus führte er den Feldzug einer Armee keltischer Krieger nach Makedonien und Nordgriechenland an. Die Streitmacht überwand die griechische Defensive an den Thermopylen und plünderte das berühmte Orakel von Delphi. Brennus war während der Kämpfe zwar verwundet worden, dennoch rückten die Kelten von hier aus nach Epirus (in etwa das heutige Albanien) vor und plünderten die Schätze, die in den Zeustempeln in Dodona und Olympia lagerten. Nach diesen Siegeszügen leisteten die Griechen wieder verstärkt Widerstand. Daraufhin trat Brennus den Rückzug nach Makedonien an, wo er an seinen Wunden starb. Ohne die Führung ihres Häuptlings trennten sich die Wege der keltischen Krieger und sie verstreuten sich in alle Himmelsrichtungen. Die meisten von ihnen kehrten mit den erbeuteten Schätzen in ihre Heimat Gallien zurück, andere zogen nach Osten und ließen sich in Kleinasien nieder. Diese Gruppe nannte sich später die Galater und lebte mindestens zwei Jahrhunderte lang vollkommen zurückgezogen von den umgebenden Nachbarländern in dieser Region.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Name "Brennus" scheint weniger ein Eigenname als vielmehr ein Titel gewesen zu sein. Tatsächlich wurde dieser Titel später einem anderen keltischen Häuptling verliehen, der 390 vor Christus die Stadt Rom eingenommen hatte. Darüber hinaus scheint es ebenfalls sehr wahrscheinlich, dass das walisische Wort "Brenin" für König von diesem Titel abgeleitet ist.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Brenno[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Capitano Celtico[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] ? - 279 a. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Oltre al fatto che fosse un guerriero abile e che incuteva timore, poco si sa del capitano celtico chiamato Brenno. Nel 279 a.C. guidò un esercito di guerrieri celti per invadere la Macedonia e la Grecia settentrionale. Aggirata la difesa greca al passo delle Termopili, saccheggiarono il famoso oracolo di Delfi. In quell'occasione Brenno fu ferito. Da lì, i Celti penetrarono nell'Epiro (più o meno l'odierna Albania) e saccheggiarono i tesori custoditi nei templi di Zeus a Dodona e Olimpia. Dopo questi trionfi, le difese greche si riorganizzarono. Brenno si ritirò in Macedonia, dove morì a causa delle ferite riportate. Privati della guida del loro capitano, i guerrieri celti si divisero andando in direzioni diverse. La maggior parte tornò nelle proprie case, in Gallia, portando con sé il bottino di guerra, il resto si diresse a oriente e s'insediò in Asia Minore. Questo gruppo divenne poi noto come i Galati e rimase culturalmente distinto dalle civiltà vicine per almeno due secoli.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il nome "Brenno" è probabilmente più un titolo che un nome, visto che in seguito identificò anche un altro capitano celtico, responsabile del sacco di Roma nel 390 a.C. Probabilmente la parola gallese "Brenin", che significa re, deriva proprio da Brenno.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Breno[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Caudillo Celta[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] ? - 279 a. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Poco se sabe del caudillo celta Breno, aparte de que fue un guerrero temible y afortunado. En el año 279 a. C., invadió Macedonia y el norte de Grecia a la cabeza de un ejército de guerreros celtas. Tras derrotar a los griegos en las Termópilas, saqueó el famoso oráculo de Delfos, aunque fue herido en la lucha. Desde allí, los celtas penetraron en el Epiro (más o menos la Albania de nuestros días) y saquearon los tesoros que guardaban los templos de Zeus en Dodona y Olimpia. Tras estas derrotas, la resistencia griega se hizo más vigorosa. Breno se retiró a Macedonia, donde murió a causa de las heridas recibidas. Sin el liderazgo de su caudillo, los guerreros celtas se dividieron y marcharon en diferentes direcciones. La mayoría regresó a la Galia, su hogar, con el tesoro que había acumulado, pero otros se encaminaron al este y se establecieron en Asia Menor. Este grupo, que recibió el nombre de gálatas, mantuvo su personalidad frente a sus nuevos vecinos durante al menos dos siglos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es probable que "Breno" sea más un título que un nombre propiamente dicho: de hecho, el caudillo celta que saqueó Roma en el año 390 a. C. también lo llevaba. Es muy posible que la palabra galesa "Brenin", que significa "rey", derive de este título.

TEXT.English: [H1]Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios Ponte y Blanco[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Gran Colombia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1783 - 1830 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Simon Bolivar was one of South America's greatest generals. His victories over the Spaniards won independence for Bolivia, Panama, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela. He is called El Liberator (The Liberator) and the "George Washington of South America."[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar was born in July 24, 1783, at Caracas, Venezuela. His parents died when he was a child and he inherited a fortune. As a young man, he traveled in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]As he returned to Venezuela, Bolivar joined the group of patriots that seized Caracas in 1810 and proclaimed independence from Spain. He went to Great Britain in search of aid, but could get only a promise of British neutrality. When he returned to Venezuela, and took command of a patriot army, he recaptured Caracas in 1813 from the Spaniards.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Spaniards forced Bolivar to retreat from Venezuela to New Granada (now Colombia), also at war with Spain. He took command of a Colombian force and captured Bogota in 1814. The patriots, however, lacked men and supplies, and new defeats led Bolivar to flee to Jamaica. In Haiti he gathered a force that landed in Venezuela in 1816, and took Angostra (now Ciudad Bolivar). He also became dictator there.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar marched into New Granada in 1819. He defeated the Spaniards in Boyar in 1819, liberating the territory of Colombia. He then returned to Angostura and led the congress that organized the original republic of Colombia (now Ecuador, Colombia, Panama, and Venezuela). Bolivar became its first president on December 17, 1819.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bolivar crushed the Spanish army at Carabobo in Venezuela on June 24, 1821. Next, he marched into Educador and added that territory to the new Colombian republic. After a meeting in 1822 with another great liberator, Bolivar became dictator of Peru. His army won a victory over the Spaniards at Auacucho in 1824, which needed Spanish power in South America. Upper Peru became a separate state, named Bolivia in Bolivar's honor, in 1825. The constitution, which he drew up for Bolivia, is one of his most important political pronouncements.

TEXT.English: [H1]Bumin Qaghan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chieftain of the Ashina Clan, Khagan of the Turkic Khaganate[NEWLINE]Reigned:[\BOLD] 551 - 552 A.D.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Bumin Qaghan or Illig Qaghan, (died 552 AD) was the founder of the Turkic Khaganate. He was the eldest son of Ashina Tuwu and chieftain of the Türks under the sovereignty of Rouran Khaganate. He is also mentioned as "Tumen" (commander of ten thousand) of the Rouran Khaganate.[PARAGRAPH:2]Not much is known about Bumin’s life except what was documented by Chinese chronicles. Accordingly, Bumin’s ascension began in 545, when his tribe was growing in strength and frequently invaded the western frontier of Wei. In response to that the chancellor of Western Wei, Yuwen Tai, sent a messenger to Tujue (Chinese name for the Türks seat in the Altai Mountains and/or its people) to greet Bumin and try to establish friendly relations. In 546, Bumin answered presenting tribute to Western Wei. In summer 551, the Tiele were launching an attack on Rouran, when Bumin’s army intercepted them and captured a large number of their people. After his victory, Bumin took advantage of this and requested a marriage with a daughter of Yujiulü Anagui, Khagan of the Rouran. Anagui felt insulted and refused this request, viewing the Türks as inferior, sending to Bumin a messenger with his message: “You are my blacksmith slave. How dare you utter these words?” (The Türks were indeed blacksmith servants for the Rouran elite and that may indicate a kind of vassalage system prevailed in Rouran society) In response, Bumin killed Anagui's messenger and cut off relations, leading a revolt against the Rouran.[PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to being a warrior leader, Bumin also used diplomacy as a tool against his enemies and to strengthen his position. After been denied the marriage with the Rouran princess and insulted, Bumin requested a Western Wei princess in marriage. Yuwen Tai, the chancellor of the state, seeking an alliance against the Rouran permitted it and sent Princess Changle to marry Bumin. Other example is when Emperor Wen of Western Wei died, Bumin sent a messenger with two hundred horses in honor to his death, strengthening the relations with the Western Wei.[PARAGRAPH:2]The beginning of formal diplomatic relations with China propped up Bumin's authority among the Turks. He eventually united the local Turkic tribes and threw off the yoke of the Rouran domination. Allied with the Western Wei, Bumin defeated Anagui and his forces north of Huaihuang (modern Zhangjiakou, Hebei) in 552.[PARAGRAPH:2]Having excelled in both battle and diplomacy, Bumin declared himself Illig Khagan of the new khaganate at Otukan, but died within several months after his coronation. His younger brother and vassal Istemi in the western part and his son Issik Qaghan in the eastern part succeeded him. In less than one century, his khaganate expanded to comprise most of Central Asia.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Lázaro Cárdenas del Río[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Mexico[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1895 - 1970 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Lázaro Cárdenas was born in a lower-middle class family in the village of Jiquilpan, Michoacán. He supported his family (including his mother and 7 younger siblings) from age 16 on after the death of his father. He worked in a printing shop; although he had little formal education he used every opportunity to educate himself.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cárdenas originally set his sights at becoming a teacher, but was drawn into politics and the military during the Mexican Revolution after Victoriano Huerta overthrew President Francisco Madero. He backed Plutarco Elías Calles, and after Calles became President, Cárdenas became governor of Michoacán in 1928. He became known for his progressive program of building roads and schools and the unusual strict honesty of his administration.[PARAGRAPH:2]Calles continued to dominate Mexico after his presidency with administrations which were his puppets. He selected Cárdenas to be the PRI's presidential candidate on the assumption that he could control Cárdenas as he had controlled others. Cárdenas's first move once in office was to have his presidential salary cut in half. Even more surprising moves would follow. After establishing himself in the presidency, Cárdenas had Calles and dozens of his corrupt associates arrested or deported to the United States, which was greeted with great enthusiasm by the majority of the public.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1938 Cárdenas nationalized Mexico's petroleum reserves and expropriated the equipment of the foreign oil companies in Mexico. Even though compensation for the expropriated assests was included in this legislation, this move aroused considerable hostility in the international business community and foreign governments, and Mexican oil and other goods were boycotted. However, with the outbreak of World War II, oil became a highly sought-after commodity and the boycott ended.[PARAGRAPH:2]After his presidential term he served as Mexico's secretary of defense through 1945.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is often said that Cárdenas was the only president from the PRI who did not use the office to make himself wealthy. He retired to a modest home by Lake Pátzcuaro and worked the rest of his life supervising irrigation projects and promoting free medical clinics and education for the nation's poor.[PARAGRAPH:2]Lázaro Cárdenas died of cancer in Mexico City. His son Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas is a prominent Mexican politician.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Kazimierz III Wielki the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Poland[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1310 - 1370 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Casimir III was born in Kowal, at April 30, 1310. Last of the Piast Dynasty, king of Poland from 1333, the son of Wladyslaw I the Short (Wladyslaw I Lokietek).[PARAGRAPH:2]Casimir is the only Polish king who did receive and maintain the title of the great in Polish history (Boleslaw I Chrobry was once also called the great, but not today), and the title is well deserved. When he received the crown, his hold on it was in danger, as even his neighbours did not recognise his title and instead called him "king of Krakow. The economy was ruined, and country was depopulated and tired with wars. At the time of his death, it had doubled in land area (mostly through joining lands in today's Ukraine, then Duchy of Halicz), grew prosperous, wealthy and had great prospects to the future. Although he is depicted as a peaceful king in children books, he in fact waged many victorious wars and was preparing other ones just before he died.[PARAGRAPH:2]He built many new castles, reformed the Polish army, as well as Polish civil and criminal laws. At the Sejm in Wislica, March 11, 1347, he introduced salutary legal reforms in the jurisprudence of his country. He sanctioned a code of laws for Great and Little Poland, which gained for him the title of "the Polish Justinian". He founded the University of Krakow although his death stalled the development of the university (and that's why today it is called Jagiellonian instead of Casimirian). He organised a meeting of kings in Krakow in 1364 which showed the wealth of Polish kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:2]Casimir was sonless. Apparently he deemed his own descendants either unsuitable to inherit or too young. Thus, and in order to provide a clear line of succession instead of problems of uncertainty, he arranged his sister Elisabeth, Dowager Queen of Hungary, and her son Louis, King of Hungary to be his successors in Poland. Louis was proclaimed polish king in Casimir's death in 1370, but Elisabeth held much of the practical power until her death in 1380.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kasimir III.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]König Polens[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1310 - 1370 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Kasimir III. wurde am 30. April 1310 in Kowal geboren. Er wurde am 25. April 1333 König Polens, und regierte 37 Jahre lang, in denen er viele Festungen in seinem Königreich baute, das Gesetzsystem reformierte, die Universität Krakaus gründete, und, am wichtigsten von allem, viele siegreiche Kriege kämpfte. Gewinne dieser Kriegen schließen einen großen Teil der Ukraine und das Herzogtum Halytsch ein. Außerdem beachtenswert ist die Tatsache, dass er die Juden in seinem Land schützte, und diejenigen dazu ermunterte, die in anderen Ländern leben, nach Polen zu emigrieren. Zu seinen Tod, am 5. November 1370, hatte Polen eine viel gesündere Wirtschaft, und seine Größe hatte sich verdoppelt. Aus diesen Gründen nennen Historiker ihn Kasimir den Großen.

TEXT.English: [H1]Catherine II the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Empress and Autocrat of All the Russias[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1729 - 1796 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Catherine was born in Szczecin in 1729, a princess of Pomerania, a small kingdom in Prussia. At 16 she was married to Carl Peter Ulrich, the heir to the Russian throne. Catherine quickly learned Russian and joined the Russian Orthodox Church. Largely self-educated, Catherine immersed herself in the literature of the time. Endowed with both beauty and intelligence, she became strong friends (if not more) with the great thinkers of the day, including the brilliant French philosophers Rousseau and Diderot.[PARAGRAPH:2]Catherine did not lack political ambition, however. At the age of 33, with the support of the Imperial guard, she overthrew her husband, the Emperor Peter III, who was soon killed "in a hunting accident," leaving Catherine the sole ruler of Russia. As Empress, Catherine pursued an expansionist policy, fighting two successful wars against the Ottoman Empire and acquiring vast territory in southern Ukraine and the Crimea. She undertook a wide range of political reforms, attempting to shape up the notoriously corrupt and incompetent Russian bureaucracy. She curried favor with the aristocracy, expanding their already-great power over the Russian peasants.[PARAGRAPH:2]A patron of the arts, Catherine commissioned many statues and paintings. Under her rule St. Petersburg was transformed from a primitive and forbidding city into one of the most beautiful and impressive European capitals.[PARAGRAPH:2]Despite her many public successes, Catherine is best known for her private excesses. Her affairs are legendary; it has been suggested that she slept with a fairly large fraction of the Russian officers corps, not to mention her many well-publicized dalliances with a horde of well-known European politicians and artists.[PARAGRAPH:2]Catherine died at the age of 67, having lived longer than any other Romanov monarch.
TEXT.French: [H1]Catherine II (la Grande)[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Tsarine de Russie[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1729 - 1796 ap. J.C[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Catherine II naît à Stettin en 1729 et devient princesse de Poméranie, un petit royaume de Prusse. A 16 ans, elle épouse Charles Pierre Ulrich (Pierre III), l'héritier du trône de Russie. Catherine II apprend rapidement le russe et devient membre de l'Eglise orthodoxe. Très autodidacte, Catherine II se plonge dans la littérature de son temps. Non seulement belle mais très intelligente, Catherine II tisse de forts liens d'amitié (si ce n'est plus) avec les grands penseurs de l'époque, notamment Rousseau et Diderot, de brillants philosophes français.[PARAGRAPH:2]Catherine II ne manque toutefois pas d'ambition politique. A 33 ans, et avec le soutien de la garde impériale, elle renverse son mari, l'empereur Pierre III. Ce dernier meurt rapidement "dans un accident de chasse", laissant Catherine II seule à la tête de la Russie. L'impératrice Catherine II poursuit alors une politique expansionniste, menant deux batailles victorieuses contre l'empire ottoman et acquérant un vaste territoire dans le sud de l'Ukraine et en Crimée. Elle entreprend de vastes réformes politiques, visant à l'amélioration de la bureaucratie russe, notoirement corrompue et incompétente. Elle cherche à obtenir les faveurs de l'aristocratie, augmentant leurs pouvoirs déjà immenses sur les paysans russes.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mécène, Catherine II commande de nombreuses statues et peintures. Sous son règne, Saint-Pétersbourg perd son statut de ville rétrograde et inhospitalière et devient l'une des plus belles et des plus impressionnantes capitales d'Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]Les nombreux succès publics de Catherine II ne font pas oublier les désormais célèbres excès de sa vie privée. Ses aventures sont légendaires et on affirme que la majeure partie du corps d'officiers russes a connu ses charmes. Sans oublier ses badinages rendus largement publics, avec de nombreux hommes politiques et artistes européens célèbres.[PARAGRAPH:2]Catherine II meurt à l'âge de 67 ans, ayant vécu plus longtemps que tout autre monarque Romanov.
TEXT.German: [H1]Katharina die Große[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zarin von Russland[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1729 - 1796 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Katharina wurde als Prinzessin Sophie Auguste Friederike von Anhalt-Zerbst-Dornburg im preußischen Stettin geboren. Als 16-jährige heiratete sie 1745 den russischen Großfürsten Peter (den späteren Peter III.). Katharina lernte daraufhin Russisch und konvertierte zum orthodoxen Glauben. Darüber hinaus las sie sehr viel, vor allem die zeitgenössische Literatur. Die gleichsam schöne wie intelligente Katharina war mit den französischen Philosophen Rousseau und Diderot und vielen anderen bedeutenden Denkern ihrer Zeit (angeblich nicht nur) befreundet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Katharina hatte aber auch politische Ambitionen. Sie versicherte sich der Unterstützung einiger Garderegimenter und ließ sich am 9. Juli 1762 zur Kaiserin ausrufen. Peter III. wurde daraufhin gefangen genommen und in ein Landhaus bei Sankt Petersburg gebracht. Dort wurde er am 17. Juli 1762 von Anhängern der Zarin ermordet. Katahrina war nun die alleinige Herrscherin Russlands. Als Zarin verfolgte Katharina eine Expansionspolitik, kämpfte gegen das ottomanische Reich und eroberte riesige Gebiete in der südlichen Ukraine und an der Krim. Sie leitete verschiedene Reformen ein und versuchte, die korrupte und unfähige russische Bürokratie zu modernisieren. Die Ausweitung der Leibeigenschaft auf alle Bauern und die Stärkung der Adelsprivilegien führte schließlich zu einem Aufstand der Donkosaken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Katharina ließ unzählige Statuen und Gemälde fertigen und machte aus Sankt Petersburg eine der prächtigsten und beeindruckendsten Hauptstädte Europas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Trotz ihrer politischen und militärischen Erfolge sind der Nachwelt vor allem Katharinas Affären mit unzähligen Offizieren, Politikern und Künstlern im Gedächtnis geblieben.[PARAGRAPH:2]Katharina starb im Alter von 67 Jahren und war damit die älteste Regentin der Romanow-Linie.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Caterina la Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zarina di Russia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuta nel:[\BOLD] 1729 - 1796 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Caterina nacque a Szczecin nel 1729, diventando principessa di Pomerania, un piccolo regno della Prussia. A 16 anni sposò Carl Peter Ulric, l'erede al trono di Prussia, poi imparò velocemente il russo ed entrò a far parte della Chiesa Ortodossa Russa. Ricevendo un'educazione in gran parte autonoma, Caterina si immerse nella letteratura del tempo. Bella e intelligente, divenne amica intima (se non di più) dei maggiori pensatori dell'epoca, inclusi i brillanti filosofi francesi Rousseau e Diderot.[PARAGRAPH:2]Tuttavia, a Caterina non mancava certo l'ambizione politica: all'età di 33 anni, con l'appoggio della Guardia Imperiale, rovesciò suo marito, l'imperatore Pietro III, che morì poco dopo in un "incidente di caccia", lasciando Caterina come unica sovrana della Russia. Una volta imperatrice, Caterina avviò una politica espansionista, combattendo due guerre contro l'Impero Ottomano e acquisendo vasti territori a sud dell'Ucraina e della Crimea. Attivò una grande serie di riforme politiche, cercando di ridurre la ben nota corruzione e incompetenza della burocrazia russa. Si guadagnò il favore dell'aristocrazia ed espanse il proprio potere sulla popolazione russa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Grande patrona delle arti, Caterina commissionò molte statue e dipinti. Sotto il suo governo, San Pietroburgo si trasformò da città austera e primitiva in una delle più belle e impressionanti capitali europee.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nonostante i molti successi pubblici, Caterina è più famosa per i suoi eccessi privati: i suoi amanti erano quasi leggendari e si dice che abbia dormito insieme a gran parte degli ufficiali russi, per non parlare dei suoi amoreggiamenti con le orde di politici e artisti europei.[PARAGRAPH:2]Caterina morì a 67 anni, dopo aver vissuto più a lungo di ogni altro monarca dei Romanov.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Catalina la Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zarina de Rusia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1729 - 1796 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Catalina, una princesa de Pomerania (un pequeño reino de Prusia), nació en Stettin. A los 16 años contrajo matrimonio con Carl Peter Ulrich, heredero al trono de Rusia. Aprendió rápidamente el ruso y profesó la fe ortodoxa. Autodidacta en gran medida, se sumergió en la literatura de su época. Dotada de belleza e inteligencia, entabló gran amistad (como mínimo) con los grandes pensadores de su tiempo, incluidos los brillantes filósofos franceses Rousseau y Diderot.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sin embargo, no carecía de ambiciones políticas. A los 33 años, con el apoyo de la guardia imperial, derrocó a su hermano, el zar Pedro III, quien no tardaría en morir en un "accidente de caza", dejando a Catalina como dueña y señora de Rusia. Como emperatriz, Catalina llevó a cabo una política expansionista: libró dos victoriosas guerras contra el Imperio Otomano y adquirió vastos territorios en el sur de Ucrania y en Crimea. Emprendió un amplio abanico de reformas con el fin de transformar a la notoriamente corrompida e incompetente burocracia rusa. Cortejó el favor de la aristocracia, ampliando su ya importante poder sobre el campesinado ruso.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mecenas de las artes, Catalina encargó obras a numerosos escultores y pintores. Durante su reinado, San Petersburgo pasó de ser una ciudad primitiva y poco acogedora a una de las más hermosas e impresionantes capitales europeas.[PARAGRAPH:2]A pesar de sus muchos logros en el ámbito de lo público, Catalina es conocida sobre todo por los excesos de su vida privada. Sus amoríos son materia de leyendas; se ha llegado a decir que se acostó con un considerable porcentaje del cuerpo de oficiales del ejército ruso, además de sus muchos y conocidos romances con una auténtica horda de importantes políticos y artistas europeos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Catalina murió a la edad de 67 años, más vieja que ningún otro monarca Romanov.

TEXT.English: [H1]Camillo Paolo Filippo Giulio Benso[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prime Minister of Italy[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1810 - 1861 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Camillo di Cavour was a leading figure in the movement toward Italian unification. He was the founder of the original Italian Liberal Party and Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia, a position he maintained (except for a six-month resignation) throughout the Second Italian War of Independence and Garibaldi's campaigns to unite Italy. Cavour died only three months after the declaration of a united Kingdom of Italy, and thus did not live to see Venetia or Rome included in the kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cavour, as he is usually called, put forth several economic reforms in his home province of Piedmont in his earlier years, and founded the political newspaper Il Risorgimento. After being elected to the Chamber of Deputies, he quickly rose in rank through the Piedmontese government, coming to dominate the Chamber of Deputies through a union of left-center and right-center politicians. After a large rail system expansion program, Cavour became prime minister in 1852. As prime minister, Cavour successfully negotiated Piedmont's way through the Crimean War, Second Italian War of Independence, and Garibaldi's expeditions, managing to maneuver Piedmont diplomatically to become a new great power in Europe, controlling a nearly united Italy that was five times as large as Piedmont had been before he came to power.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Chandragupta II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of the Gupta Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 375 - 415 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Chandragupta was one of the most powerful emperors of the Gupta empire. His rule spanned during the Gupta Empire's zenith. The period of prominence of the Gupta dynasty is very often referred to as the Golden Age of India. Chandragupta II the Great was the son of the previous ruler, Samudragupta the Great. He attained success by pursuing both a favorable marital alliance and an aggressive expansionist policy. In this his father and grandfather set the precedent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Not much is known about the personal details of the great king. His mother, Datta Devi, was the chief queen of Samudragupta the Great. After Samudragupta's death, Ramgupta his brother took over the throne and also married Chandragupta's fiance 'Dhruvaswamini by force. The most widely accepted details have been built upon the plot of the play 'Devi-Chandraguptam' of Vishakadatta. The play is now lost but fragments have been preserved in other works (Abhinava-bharati, Sringara-prakasha, Natya-darpana, Nataka-lakshana Ratna-kosha). There even exists an Arabic work Mujmalu-t-Tawarikh which tells a similar tale of a king whose name appears to be a corruption of 'Vikramaditya'. He holds a semi-mythical status in India. It is widely believed that the great poet in Sanskrit, Mahakavi Kalidasa was one of the jewels of his royal court.[PARAGRAPH:2]The fragment from Natya-darpana mentions the king Ramagupta, the elder brother of Chandragupta, surrendering his queen Dhruvaswamini to the Saka king of the Western Kshatrapas Rudrasimha III, after a defeat at the Saka king's hands. To avoid the ignominy the Guptas decide to send Madhavasena, a courtesan and a beloved of Chandragupta, disguised as the queen. Chandragupta changes the plan and himself goes to the Saka King disguised as the queen. He then kills Rudrasimha and later his brother Ramagupta. Dhruvaswamini is then married to Chandragupta.[PARAGRAPH:2]We do not know what liberties Vishakadatta took with the incidents, but Dhruvadevi was indeed the king's chief queen as seen in the Vaisali terracotta seal that calls her 'Mahadevi' Dhruvasvamini. The Bilsad pillar inscription of their son Kumara Gupta I also refers to her as Mahadevi Dhruvadevi. A Ramagupta too is mentioned in inscriptions on Jain figures in the District Archaeological Museum, Vidisha and some copper coins found at Vidisha. The fact that the king and Dhruvadevi are the protagonists of Vishakadatta's play indicates that marrying his widowed sister-in-law was not given any significance by the playwright. Later Hindus did not view such a marriage with favour and some censure of the act is found in the Sanjan copperplate inscription of Amoghavarsha I and in the Sangali and Cambay plates of the Rashtrakuta king Govinda IV.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Allahabad pillar inscription mentions the marriage of Chandragupta II the Great with a Naga princess Kuberanaga. A pillar from Mathura referring to Chandragupta has recently been dated to 388 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chandragupta's daughter Prabhavati, by his other queen Kuberanaga, a Naga princess, was married to the powerful Vakataka king Rudrasena II.[PARAGRAPH:2]His greatest victory was his victory over the Shaka-Kshatrapa dynasty and annexation of their kingdom in Gujarat, by defeating their last ruler Rudrasimha III.[PARAGRAPH:2]His son-in-law, the Vakataka king Rudrasena II, died fortuitously after a very short reign in 390 AD, following which Prabhavatigupta ruled the Vakataka kingdom as a regent on behalf of his two sons. During this twenty-year period the Vakataka realm was practically a part of the Gupta empire. The geographical location of the Vakataka kingdom allowed Chandragupta to take the opportunity to defeat the Western Kshatrapas once for all. Many historians refer to this period as the Vakataka-Gupta age.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chandragupta II the Great controlled a vast empire, from the mouth of the Ganges to the mouth of the Indus River and from what is now North Pakistan down to the mouth of the Narmada. Pataliputra continued to be the capital of his huge empire but Ujjain too became a sort of second capital. The large number of beautiful gold coins issued by the Gupta dynasty are a testament to the imperial grandeur of that age. Chandragupta II also started producing silver coins in the Shaka tradition.[PARAGRAPH:2]Faxian (Wade-Giles Fa-hsien) was the first of three great Chinese pilgrims who visited India from the fifth to the seventh centuries AD, in search of knowledge, manuscripts and relics. He arrived during the reign of Chandragupta II and gave a general description of North India at that time. Among the other things, he reported about the absence of capital punishment, the lack of a poll-tax and land tax. Most citizens did not consume onions, garlic, meat, and wine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Culturally, the reign of Chandragupta II marked a Golden Age. This is evidenced by later reports of the presence of a circle of poets known as the Nine Gems in his court. The greatest among them was Kalidasa, who authored numerous immortal pieces of literature including The Recognition of Shakuntala. The others were the Sanskrit grammarian Amara Sinha and the astronomer-mathematician Varahamihira.[PARAGRAPH:2]The next day after the Hindu festival Diwali is called Padwa or Varshapratipada, which marks the coronation of King Vikramaditya. The Hindu Vikram-Samvat calendar was apparently started on this day and this day is celebrated as New Year's Day in Nepal where Vikram Sambat is the official calendar there, and some places in India. But, Vikram-Samvat calendar is from 57 BC. So, there was someother king by name Vikram, who started this calendar.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shak-Samvat is synchronised with the Shak-Samvat calendar, which starts around April. This calendar was initiated by Gautamiputra Satakarni who defeated the Saka king Vikramaditya, thus starting the Shalivahana era or Shaka Calendar.

TEXT.English: [H1]Charlemagne[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.747 - 814 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Charles the Great, Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, fathered a kingdom that encompassed France, Germany, Italy and much of Eastern Europe. Legends of his conquests are pervasive throughout history, and he is considered one of the great figureheads of European Chivalric society.[PARAGRAPH:2]During his lifetime Charlemagne successfully campaigned in many countries. Some wars he completed personally and others were left for his sons to finish. His first campaign was against Desiderius of Lombardy who, soon after the succession of Pope Hadrian I, marched on Rome. Charlemagne pressed into Lombardy, and after a lengthy siege (772-774), he accepted Desiderius' unconditional surrender. Desiderius would live out the remainder of his life confined to a monastery.[PARAGRAPH:2]The longest lasting and most challenging conquest of Charlemagne's reign would be that of Saxonia. It would be a theater that he would continually revisit during his lifetime. After Charlemagne's initial push into Saxonia he was continuously forced to retake previously conquered land which had rebelled against his authority. Weary of war and losing more rights and freedoms with every capitulation, the Saxons eventually accepted Charlemagne's terms, including renouncement of their national religious customs and adoption of the Christian faith and its associated Frankish customs.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charles was both a highly religious man and a philanthropist. He often built friendly relationships with other countries, such as Egypt and India, so that he could later send money in an effort to assist struggling Christians in those regions. Although much more of a conqueror than an economic or social reformer, Charles often contributed money to relieve the poor and sick in his kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charlemagne, despite being unable to write well himself, had a vast love of literature and education. Due to his conquests, Charlemagne came into contact with many different cultures and learning institutions. Having contributed considerable funding to existing monastic schools and institutions of learning, Charlemagne's era became known as the Carolingian Renaissance, with a blossoming of the arts and sciences.[PARAGRAPH:2]As a member of the Nine Worthies, a group of both fictional and real people that represented the pinnacle of chivalry during their eras, Charlemagne was the embodiment of honor in both person and position. A conqueror, a philanthropist, lover of the arts and a highly devout Christian, Charlemagne stands as one of the important figures of the first millennium, and the forefather of Central Europe as it stands today.
TEXT.French: [H1]Charlemagne[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Empereur du Saint Empire romain germanique, roi des Francs[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] vers 747 - 814 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Charles le Grand, empereur du Saint Empire romain germanique, donna naissance à un royaume qui comprenait la France, l'Allemagne, l'Italie et une grande partie de l'Europe de l'Est. Ses conquêtes furent extrêmement nombreuses et il est considéré comme l'une des grandes figures parmi les chevaliers d'Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]Au cours de sa vie, Charlemagne mena avec succès de nombreuses campagnes à travers différents pays. Il en acheva certaines de son vivant, tandis que d'autres furent terminées par son fils. Sa première campagne fut menée contre Didier de Lombardie qui, peu après la succession du pape Adrien Ier, marcha sur Rome. Charlemagne envahit la Lombardie et, après un long siège (772-774), accepta la retraite inconditionnelle de Didier de Lombardie. Didier de Lombardie vécut le reste de sa vie confiné dans un monastère.[PARAGRAPH:2]La plus longue et la plus difficile conquête du règne de Charlemagne fut celle de la Saxe, qu'il dut reconquérir plusieurs fois. Après sa première percée en Saxe, il fut constamment obligé de reprendre les terres qu'il avait précédemment conquises et qui s'étaient ensuite rebellées contre son autorité. Lassés par la guerre et perdant davantage de droits et de libertés à chaque capitulation, les saxons finirent par accepter les conditions de Charlemagne, y compris le renoncement à leurs traditions religieuses et l'adoption de la foi chrétienne et de ses traditions franques.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charles était à la foi un homme très religieux et un philanthrope. Il instaura à plusieurs reprises des relations amicales avec d'autres pays, comme l'Egypte et l'Inde, afin de pouvoir envoyer de l'argent aux chrétiens qui luttaient dans ces régions. Charles était plus un conquérant qu'un réformateur économique ou social, mais il fit souvent des dons d'argent pour venir en aide aux pauvres et aux malades de son royaume.[PARAGRAPH:2]Incapable d'écrire lui-même, Charlemagne n'en vouait pas moins une grande affection à la littérature et l'éducation. Grâce à ses conquêtes, il entra en contact avec de nombreuses cultures et institutions éducatives différentes. L'ère de Charlemagne fut connue sous le nom de Renaissance carolingienne et vit un essor considérable des arts et des sciences.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charlemagne était l'honneur personnifié, aussi bien de par ses actions que de par sa position. Il fut l'un des Neuf Preux, un groupe constitué de personnes réelles et fictives qui incarna l'idéal de la chevalerie pendant cette ère. Conquérant, philanthrope, amoureux des arts et fervent chrétien, Charlemagne est l'un des personnages les plus importants du premier millénaire et l'un des pères fondateurs de l'Europe centrale telle que nous la connaissons aujourd'hui.
TEXT.German: [H1]Karl der Große[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kaiser des Heiligen Römischen Reiches, König der Franken[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] Um 747 - 814 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Karl der Große, Kaiser des Heiligen Römischen Reiches, war Stammvater eines Königreichs, das Frankreich, Deutschland, Italien und einen Großteil Osteuropas umfasste. Die Geschichte ist voll von Legenden über seine Eroberungen, und er gilt als einer der größten Vorreiter des europäischen Rittertums.[PARAGRAPH:2]Zu seinen Lebzeiten unternahm Karl der Große erfolgreich Feldzüge in viele Länder. Manche Kriege brachte er selbst zu Ende, andere überließ er seinen Söhnen. Sein erster Feldzug erfolgte gegen Desiderius von der Lombardei, der bald nach der Thronbesteigung Papst Hadrians I. gegen Rom aufmarschierte. Karl der Große drang in die Lombardei ein und nahm nach einer langen Belagerung (772 - 774) Desiderius' bedingungslose Kapitulation an. Desiderius sollte den Rest seines Lebens in Klosterhaft verbringen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die langwierigste und schwierigste Eroberung während der Herrschaft Karls des Großen war die Sachsens. Diesen Schauplatz sollte er während seiner gesamten Lebenszeit immer wieder aufsuchen. Nach seinem ersten Vorstoß nach Sachsen war Karl der Große immer wieder gezwungen, vormals erobertes Land, das sich gegen seine Herrschaft erhoben hatte, neu einzunehmen. Kriegsmüde und unter dem Einfluss der nach jeder Niederlage wachsenden Verluste an Rechten und Freiheiten, akzeptierten die Sachsen schließlich Karls Bedingungen, darunter die Aufgabe ihrer eigenen Naturreligion, die Konversion zum Christentum und die Annahme der damit verbundenen fränkischen Bräuche.[PARAGRAPH:2]Karl der Große war sowohl ein tiefgläubiger Mensch als auch ein Wohltäter. Er unterhielt oft freundschaftliche Beziehungen zu anderen Ländern, etwa Ägypten und Indien, so dass er später Geld dorthin schicken konnte, um bedürftigen Christen in diesen Regionen zu helfen. Obwohl er eher ein Eroberer als ein wirtschaftlicher oder sozialer Reformer war, leistete Karl viele Beiträge, um den Armen und Kranken in seinem Reich zu helfen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Obwohl Karl der Große selbst nicht gut schreiben konnte, hatte er eine große Vorliebe für Literatur und Bildung. Durch seine Eroberungen kam Karl der Große viel mit verschiedenen Kulturen und Bildungseinrichtungen in Kontakt. Da er bestehende Klosterschulen und Bildungseinrichtungen finanziell stark förderte, wurde die Epoche Karls des Großen als die Karolingische Renaissance bekannt, in der Kunst und Wissenschaft eine Blütezeit erlebten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Als Mitglied der Neun Guten Helden, einer Gruppe sowohl fiktiver wie realer Personen, die in ihrer jeweiligen Zeit die Blüte des Rittertums darstellten, verkörperte Karl der Große die Tugend der Ehre sowohl persönlich als auch als Herrscher. Als Eroberer, Menschenfreund, Kunstliebhaber und tiefgläubiger Christ, gehört Karl der Große zu den wichtigen Figuren des ersten Jahrtausends und ist der Gründervater Mitteleuropas, wie wir es heute kennen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Carlo Magno[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Imperatore del Sacro Romano Impero, re dei Franchi[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] ca. 747 - 814 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Carlo Magno, imperatore del Sacro Romano Impero, creò un regno che comprendeva Francia, Germania, Italia e gran parte dell'Europa orientale. Le leggende delle sue conquiste permeano la storia ed è considerato una delle figure più importanti della società cavalleresca europea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante la sua vita, Carlo Magno ha condotto campagne di successo in molti Paesi. Alcune guerre le ha completate personalmente, altre sono state terminate dai figli. La sua prima campagna fu contro Desiderio, re dei Longobardi, che poco dopo l'elezione di papa Adriano I marciò su Roma. Carlo Magno penetrò in Lombardia e, dopo un lungo assedio (772-774), accettò la resa incondizionata di Desiderio, che passò il resto della propria vita confinato in un monastero.[PARAGRAPH:2]La conquista più lunga e impegnativa di Carlo Magno fu quella della Sassonia, un teatro di scontri che avrebbe visto continuamente durante la propria vita. Dopo la prima penetrazione, infatti, fu continuamente costretto a riconquistare terre precedentemente occupate che si erano ribellate alla sua autorità. Stanchi della guerra e dopo aver perso più diritti e libertà a ogni successiva conquista, i Sassoni alla fine accettarono i termini di Carlo Magno, compresa la rinuncia ai costumi religiosi nazionali e l'adozione della fede cristiana e dei costumi franchi a essa associati.[PARAGRAPH:2]Carlo era un uomo molto religioso e un filantropo. Spesso istituì relazioni amichevoli con altri Paesi, come Egitto e India, in modo da poter inviare più tardi dei soldi nel tentativo di aiutare i cristiani in difficoltà in quelle regioni. Nonostante fosse più un conquistatore che un riformatore economico o sociale, Carlo spesso usò del denaro per aiutare i poveri e i malati del suo regno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Carlo Magno, nonostante le sue difficoltà nel leggere e nello scrivere, amava immensamente la letteratura e l'educazione. Grazie alle sue conquiste entrò in contatto con molte culture e scuole diverse. Per i suoi contributi alle scuole monastiche e alle istituzioni scolastiche, l'era di Carlo Magno fu conosciuta come il Rinascimento carolingio e fu caratterizzata da un fiorire di arte e scienza.[PARAGRAPH:2]Quale membro dei Nove Prodi, un gruppo di personaggi reali e fittizi scelti per rappresentare gli ideali della cavalleria, Carlo Magno era la personificazione dell'onore sia come persona sia come posizione. Un conquistatore, un filantropo, amante delle arti e devoto cristiano, Carlo Magno si pone come una delle figure più importanti del primo millennio e il progenitore dell'Europa centrale per come la conosciamo oggi.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Carlomagno[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperador del Sacro Imperio Romano, rey de los francos[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] c.747 - 814 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Carlos el Grande, emperador del Sacro Imperio Romano, gobernó un reino que incluía Francia, Alemania, Italia y buena parte de Europa oriental. Sus conquistas han alcanzado carácter legendario y se le considera una de las figuras capitales de la sociedad caballeresca europea.[PARAGRAPH:2]A lo largo de su vida, Carlomagno emprendió con éxito numerosas campañas. Algunas de sus guerras las completó en persona, mientras que otras las dejó en manos de sus sucesores. La primera de sus campañas fue contra Desiderio de Lombardía quien, poco después de la muerte del Papa Adriano I, había marchado contra Roma. Carlomagno invadió Lombardía y, tras un prolongado asedio (772-774), aceptó la rendición incondicional de Desiderio. El vencido pasaría el resto de su vida confinado en un monasterio.[PARAGRAPH:2]La más importante y duradera conquista de Carlomagno fue Sajonia. Sería un escenario que visitaría continuamente a lo largo de su vida. Tras la invasión inicial de Sajonia, Carlomagno se vio forzado una y otra vez a reconquistar tierras ya conquistadas que se habían rebelado contra su autoridad. Cansados de la guerra, los sajones, conscientes de que cada capitulación les costaba más derechos y libertades, acabaron por aceptar los términos de Carlomagno, incluido el abandono de su religión nacional y la adopción de la fe cristiana, así como el resto de las costumbres francas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Carlos fue tanto un hombre muy religioso como un filántropo. En numerosas ocasiones estableció lazos de amistad con otros países, como Egipto y la India, para poder enviar fondos a sus necesitadas comunidades cristianas. Aunque tuvo mucho más de hombre de guerra que de reformista económico o social, Carlos realizó numerosas contribuciones económicas para aliviar el sufrimiento de los pobres y los enfermos de su reino.[PARAGRAPH:2]A pesar de que él mismo apenas sabía leer, Carlomagno profesaba un hondo amor a la literatura y la educación. Gracias a sus conquistas, entró en contacto con muchas culturas e instituciones educativas diferentes. Su reinado, caracterizado por importantes donaciones a escuelas monásticas y otras instituciones educativas, se conoció como Renacimiento Carolingio, y supuso un florecimiento de las artes y las ciencias.[PARAGRAPH:2]Miembro de los Nueve Varones de la Fama (un grupo de personajes ficticios y reales que representaban el pináculo de las virtudes caballerescas en sus respectivas épocas), Carlomagno era la encarnación del honor, tanto por su persona como por su posición. Conquistador, filántropo, amante de las artes y gran devoto cristiano, Carlomagno es una de las figuras más importantes del primer milenio y el auténtico creador de la idea de Europa, tal como la conocemos hoy.

TEXT.English: [H1]Charles V[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Holy Roman Emperor[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1500 - 1558 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] Charles V (24 February 1500 - 21 September 1558) was ruler of the Burgundian territories (1506-1555), King of Spain (1516-1556), King of Naples and Sicily (1516-1554), Archduke of Austria (1519-1521), King of the Romans (or German King), (1519-1556 but did not formally abdicate until 1558) and Holy Roman Emperor (1530-1556 but did not formally abdicate until 1558). In Spain, though he is often referred to as Carlos V, he ruled officially as Carlos I, hence Charles I of Spain.[PARAGRAPH:2] Charles V's reign introduced the first documented use of the styles of His Majesty or His Imperial Majesty. Because of his far-reaching territories he was described as ruling an Empire "in which the sun does not set". Born in 1500, Charles inherited a vast empire from his parents. When his father Philip I died in 1516 Charles inherited control over The Netherlands, Luxembourg, Artois and Franche-Comte (or Free County of Burgundy). In 1516 his maternal grandfather Ferdinand II died and he inherited Aragon, Navarre, Granada, Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, Spanish America, and joint kingship with his mother (who was insane) over Castile. Then in 1519 when his grandfather Maximilian I died, Charles inherited the Hapsburg lands in Austria and was elected Holy Roman emperor.[PARAGRAPH:2] During Charles' reign, the territories in New Spain were considerably extended by conquistadores like Hernan Cortes and Francisco Pizarro, who brought the Aztec and Inca empires to fall in little more than a decade. Combined with the circumnavigation of the globe in 1522, this gave to Charles a strong impression of his divine mission to become the leader of a christian world. The conquests also provided the state treasury with enormous amounts of bullion. The conquistador Bernal Diaz had already observed: "We came to serve God and our Majesty, ... and also to get rich." In 1550, Charles convened a conference at Valladolid in order to consider the morality of the force used against the indigenous populations of Spanish America. Charles was also known for introducing slaves from Spain to this region.[PARAGRAPH:2] In 1556 Charles abdicated his various titles, giving his personal empire to his son, Philip II of Spain, and the Holy Empire to his brother, Ferdinand. Charles retired to the monastery of Yuste in Extremadura, but continued to correspond widely and kept an interest in the situation of the empire. He suffered from severe gout and some scholars think Charles V decided to abdicate after a gout attack in 1552 forced him to postpone an attempt to recapture the French city of Metz, where he was later defeated. Charles died on September 21, 1558. Twenty-six years later his remains were transferred to the Royal Pantheon of The Monastery of San Lorenzo de El Escorial.
TEXT.German: [H1]Karl V.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]König von Spanien, Kaiser des Heiligen Römischen Reiches Deutscher Nationen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1500 - 1558 v. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Karl V. war von 1516 an König Karl I. von Spanien und von 1519 auch Kaiser des Heiligen Römischen Reiches deutscher Nation. Am 23. August 1556 verzichtete er zugunsten seines Sohnes auf den spanischen Thron und zugunsten seines Bruders auf die Kaiserwürde. Durch die neuen Besitzungen in Amerika regierte Karl V. über ein Reich, in dem die Sonne nie unterging.

TEXT.English: [H1]Mao Zedong[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1893 - 1976 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Born of fairly well-to-do peasant stock in Hunan, Mao was trained in Chinese classics and received a modern education. Observing the oppressive social conditions besetting China, Mao became one of the original members of the Chinese Communist Party, where he worked to recruit peasants to the new party. The party was then engaged in a running guerilla war with Chaing Kai-shek, ruler of "Nationalist" China.[PARAGRAPH:2]Now a commander of one of the People's armies, Mao found himself in danger of encirclement and destruction. He famously led his ragtag force of 90,000 men, women and children on the grueling "Long March," a 6,000 mile trek through some of the most unpleasant terrain China has to offer. He arrived at the city of Yan'an having lost more than half of his force, but emerging as the undisputed leader of the Chinese Communist party.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937-45), Mao fought both the Chinese Nationalist forces and the Japanese until the United States forced Japan's surrender in 1945. With the Japanese now out of the way, the communists concentrated their efforts against the Nationalists, and by 1949 they drove Chaing's forces off the mainland to the island province of Taiwan.[PARAGRAPH:2]In total control of (mainland) China, Mao sought to keep his people imbued with revolutionary vigor, and in 1958 he instituted his "Great Leap Forward." This piece of political thinking resulted in the deaths of approximately twenty million Chinese, and easily set back China's development by 30 years. Not yet satisfied, in 1966 Mao and his wife initiated the "Cultural Revolution," a ten-year period in which China's artists, intellectuals, moderate politicians and other unenlightened or unlucky folk were imprisoned and killed or sent out to work the fields until they died or were judged "reeducated" by the workers. This adventure in social engineering killed perhaps one million people and further delayed China's emergence as a great world power.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mao died in 1976, beloved by his people. To summarize him as a man, it could be said that Mao was a great war leader, an exceptional political infighter, and an unbelievably brutal dictator.
TEXT.French: [H1]Mao Zedong[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dictateur chinois (Président du Parti communiste chinois)[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1893 - 1976 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Né dans une famille de paysans relativement aisés du Hunan, Mao fait des études classiques et reçoit une éducation moderne. Observant les conditions sociales oppressives qui accablent la Chine, Mao devient l'un des premiers membres du Parti communiste chinois. Travaillant pour le compte de ce nouveau parti, il est chargé d'y faire adhérer des paysans. Le parti s'engage ensuite dans une guérilla ouverte avec Tchang Kaï-chek, le chef du parti "nationaliste" chinois.[PARAGRAPH:2]A la tête d'une des armées du peuple, Mao risque l'encerclement et la destruction. Il parvient toutefois à conduire ses troupes désordonnées, composées de 90 000 hommes, femmes et enfants lors de la célèbre Longue marche de plus de 9 600 km à travers certaines des régions les plus hostiles de Chine. A son arrivée dans la ville de Yan'an, il a déjà perdu plus de la moitié de ses hommes, mais il apparaît comme le leader incontesté du Parti communiste chinois.[PARAGRAPH:2]Au cours de la Deuxième Guerre sino-japonaise (1937-45), Mao lutte à la fois contre les forces nationalistes chinoises et contre les Japonais, jusqu'à ce que les Etats-Unis poussent le Japon à capituler en 1945. Les Japonais étant désormais hors d'état de nuire, les communistes concentrent leurs efforts contre les nationalistes et en 1949, ils obligent les forces de Tchang Kaï-chek à quitter le continent chinois et à se réfugier dans la province insulaire de Taiwan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Contrôlant toute la Chine (continentale), Mao cherche à entretenir la force révolutionnaire de la population et en 1958, il institue le "Grand bond en avant". Ce programme conduit à la mort de près de vingt millions de Chinois et fait reculer le développement de la Chine de 30 ans. Mao n'est toujours pas satisfait et en 1966, avec sa femme, il lance la "Révolution culturelle". Pendant dix ans, les artistes, intellectuels, politiciens modérés et autres personnes stupides ou malchanceuses sont emprisonnés et tués, envoyés dans les campagnes pour travailler la terre jusqu'à ce qu'ils meurent ou soient considérés comme "rééduqués" par les travailleurs. Cette expérience d'ingénierie sociale provoque sans doute la mort d'un million de personnes et retarde davantage l'émergence de la Chine en tant que grande puissance mondiale.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mao meurt en 1976, adulé par son peuple. Pour résumer la personnalité de cet homme, on peut dire que Mao était un grand chef de guerre, un adversaire politique exceptionnel et un dictateur excessivement brutal.
TEXT.German: [H1]Mao Tse-tung[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chinesischer Diktator (Vorsitzender der KP Chinas)[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1893 - 1976 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mao wurde in Hunan als Sohn einer relativ wohlhabende Bauernfamilie geboren. Er las die chinesischen Klassiker und erhielt eine moderne Erziehung. Unter dem Eindruck der sozialen Verhältnisse in China schloss er sich der kommunistischen Partei an und versuchte fortan, andere Bauern zum Beitritt zu bewegen. Nach dem gescheiterten Herbsternte-Aufstand im September 1927 zog sich Mao mit einer Gruppe der Streitkräfte in das Jinggang-Gebirge zurück, um sich später im Grenzgebiet der Provinzen Jiangxi und Fujian niederzulassen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Oktober 1934 stand Maos Rote Armee der chinesischen Sowjetrepublik in der Jiangxi-Provinz am Rande der Vernichtung durch die Truppen Chiang Kai-sheks. Die Kommunisten entkamen, indem sie sich kreisförmig nach Norden in Richtung Yan'an zurückzogen. 1935 erreichten nur 20.000 der anfangs 90.000 Soldaten Yan'an. Allerdings gab der lange Marsch der KP Chinas genug Zeit, sich zu erholen und den Norden Chinas neu aufzubauen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im 2. Weltkrieg kämpfte Mao gegen die japanischen Invasoren, bevor er nach der Kapitulation Japans den Kampf gegen die Führung der Republik China bzw. die chinesischen Nationalisten aufnahm. 1949 vertrieben Maos Truppen die nationalistischen Kuomintang unter Führung Chiang Kai-sheks nach Taiwan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mao kontrollierte nun das chinesische Festland und versuchte den revolutionären Eifer der Chinesen im Jahr 1958 mit dem "Großen Sprung nach vorn" zu stärken. Diese politische Fehlentscheidung sollte etwa 20 Millionen Chinesen das Leben kosten und Chinas Entwicklung um etwa 30 Jahre zurückwerfen. Um seine Macht zu festigen, leitete Mao die "Große proletarische Kulturrevolution" ein, in deren Verlauf mehrere Millionen Künstler, Intellektuelle und gemäßigte Politiker getötet oder von Maos Roten Garden "umerzogen" wurden. Chinas Aufstieg zur Weltmacht wurde dadurch erneut zurückgeworfen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Als Mao 1976 starb, wurden seine Vertrauten verhaftet. Aus heutiger Sicht war Mao gleichzeitig Staatsmann und skrupelloser Diktator.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mao Tse Tung[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dittatore della Cina (Presidente del Partito Comunista Cinese)[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] 1893 - 1976 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Nato in una famiglia contadina discretamente agiata di Hunan, Mao venne istruito nei classici Cinesi e ricevette un'educazione moderna. Osservando la oppressive condizioni sociali della Cina, Mao divenne uno dei primi membri del Partito Comunista Cinese, dove si adoperò per reclutare nuovi membri tra i contadini. In seguito, il partito ingaggiò una lunga guerriglia contro Chaing Kai-shek, il capo dei Nazionalisti della Cina.[PARAGRAPH:2]Al comando di uno degli eserciti del popolo, Mao si ritrovò circondato e a rischio dell'annientamento: non perdendosi d'animo, guidò il suo variegato esercito di 90.000 uomini, donne e bambini nella faticosa "Lunga Marcia", una camminata di oltre 9000 chilometri attraverso le ardue terre della Cina. Quando arrivò nella città di Yan'an, aveva perso più della metà delle proprie forze, ma era diventato il leader indiscusso del Partito Comunista Cinese.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante la Seconda Guerra Cino-Giapponese (1937-1945), Mao lottò contro le Forze Nazionaliste della Cina e i Giapponesi, finché gli Stati Uniti non costrinsero quest'ultimo alla resa, nel 1945. Una volta liberi dalla minaccia giapponese, i Comunisti concentrarono i propri sforzi contro i Nazionalisti e nel 1949 ricacciarono le forze di Chaing dal continente, relegandole nell'isola di Taiwan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Una volta ottenuto il controllo totale del territorio continentale della Cina, Mao cercò di mantenere vivo il vigore rivoluzionario dei proprio sostenitori e nel 1958 istituì il suo "grande passo in avanti": questo progetto politico portò alla morte di circa venti milioni di cinesi e riportò indietro lo sviluppo del paese di 30 anni. Non soddisfatto, nel 1966 Mao e sua moglie diedero inizio alla "Rivoluzione Culturale", un periodo di dieci anni in cui gli artisti, gli intellettuali, i politici moderati e altre figure non illuminate o sfortunate vennero imprigionate e uccise, oppure mandate nei campi di lavoro, dove morivano o venivano "rieducati" dai lavoratori. Questa epurazione uccise probabilmente un milione di persone e rallentò ulteriormente l'emergere della Cina come potenza mondiale.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mao morì nel 1976, amato dal suo popolo. Per riassumere la sua vita, si può dire che Mao fu un grande leader militare, un politico interno eccezionale e un dittatore incredibilmente brutale.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Mao Zedong[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dictador de China (presidente del Partido Comunista Chino)[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1893 - 1976 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Nacido en el seno de una acomodada familia campesina de Hunan, Mao se educó en las tradiciones clásicas chinas, aunque también recibió una educación moderna.
