TEXT.English: [TAB]Cavalry is composed of soldiers trained to fight on horseback. Because of their speed, cavalry units were often used for reconnaissance missions and hit-and-run raids on enemy installations and troops. Although warriors fighting from horseback with a variety of weapons date back to ancient Egypt, horse-mounted cavalry as we generally think of it today actually began in the late 1700s. Under Napoleon, the cavalry became an elite force, frequently deployed simultaneously with foot soldiers to mask the movements of the main battle force.[PARAGRAPH:1]Cavalry were used extensively in the American Civil War, and in other conflicts throughout the mid to late 19th century. When the repeating rifle replaced earlier single-shot firearms, horse-mounted troops became easy targets for infantrymen. The South African War, from 1899 to 1902, was the last major conflict where cavalry played an important role. Today, the roles once performed by horse-mounted cavalry have been assumed by troops utilizing armored assault vehicles and aircraft.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La cavalerie regroupe des soldats entraînés à se battre à cheval. Du fait de sa vitesse de déplacement, elle a souvent été utilisée pour des missions de reconnaissance ou des raids éclair contre l'ennemi. Même s'il y avait déjà des combattants à cheval sous l'ancienne Egypte, la cavalerie telle qu'on se la représente aujourd'hui remonte au XVIIIe siècle. Sous Napoléon, la cavalerie est devenue une armée d'élite, souvent utilisée parallèlement à l'infanterie pour dissimuler les mouvements du gros de l'armée.[PARAGRAPH:1]La cavalerie a joué un rôle primordial lors de la Guerre Civile américaine et dans d'autres conflits de la deuxième moitié du XIXe siècle. Mais avec l'apparition des fusils à répétition, les cavaliers sont devenus des cibles faciles. La Guerre des Boërs, en Afrique du Sud (1899-1902), a été le dernier conflit majeur au cours duquel la cavalerie a joué un rôle important. Aujourd'hui, elle a été remplacée par des soldats se déplaçant en véhicules blindés ou en hélicoptères.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kavallerie besteht aus reiterfahrenen Soldaten, die wegen ihrer Schnelligkeit oftmals zur Erkundung und für Blitzangriffe auf feindliche Einrichtungen und Truppen eingesetzt wurden. Zwar wurden bereits im alten Ägypten berittene, mit diversen Waffen ausgerüstete Kämpfer eingesetzt, die moderne Kavallerie bevölkerte jedoch erst gegen Ende des 18. Jahrhunderts die Schlachtfelder. Unter Napoleon wurde die Kavallerie in den Stand der Elitestreitkräfte erhoben, die häufig zusammen mit Fußtruppen vorausgeschickt wurden, um die Aufmerksamkeit des Feindes von der nachrückenden Hauptstreitmacht abzulenken.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ab etwa Mitte bis zum späten 19. Jahrhundert griffen die Militärstrategen während des Amerikanischen Bürgerkrieges und in anderen kriegerischen Auseinandersetzungen vielfach auf die Kavallerie zurück. Als dann aber die früheren Einzelschussgewehre durch Repetiergewehre ersetzt wurden, stellten berittene Truppen leichte Ziele für die Infanterie dar, und so war der Burenkrieg von 1899 bis 1902 der letzte große Konflikt, in dem die Kavallerie eine bedeutende Rolle spielte. Heute haben gepanzerte Angriffsfahrzeuge und Kampfflugzeuge die Aufgaben der ehemals vorherrschenden Kavallerieeinheiten übernommen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La cavalleria è formata da soldati a cavallo allenati a combattere in sella. Grazie alla loro velocità, le unità di cavalleria venivano spesso impiegate per missioni di ricognizione e attacchi mordi-e-fuggi contro le postazioni e le truppe nemiche. Anche se i guerrieri a cavallo esistevano già nell'antico Egitto, la nascita della cavalleria come la intendiamo oggi risale al 1700. Sotto Napoleone, la cavalleria diventò arma di élite, spesso utilizzata in combinazione con la fanteria per mascherare i movimenti del grosso dell'esercito.[PARAGRAPH:1]Questa forza ebbe anche un vasto impiego durante la Guerra Civile Americana e in altri conflitti, fino al termine del XIX secolo. Quando i fucili a ripetizione presero il posto delle armi a ricarica, le unità di cavalleria diventarono un facile bersaglio per la fanteria. La Guerra Sudafricana, tra il 1899 e il 1902, fu l'ultimo grande conflitto in cui la cavalleria ebbe un ruolo di primo piano. Oggi questo ruolo viene ricoperto dai veicoli corazzati da assalto e dagli aerei.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La caballería está formada por soldados entrenados para luchar a caballo. Gracias a su velocidad, las unidades de caballería solían ser empleadas en misiones de reconocimiento y ataques relámpago contra las instalaciones y tropas enemigas. Aunque la práctica de la lucha a caballo, con variedad de armas diferentes, se remonta al Egipto antiguo, la caballería tal como la concebimos hoy en día aparece a finales del siglo XVIII. En tiempos de Napoleón, se convirtió en una fuerza de elite, desplegada habitualmente junto con soldados de infantería para ocultar los movimientos del grueso del ejército.[PARAGRAPH:1]La caballería se usó ampliamente en la Guerra de Secesión y otros conflictos de la segunda mitad del siglo XIX. Cuando el rifle de repetición reemplazó a las armas anteriores de un solo disparo, las tropas montadas se convirtieron en presa fácil para la infantería. La Guerra de los Bóers, de 1899 a 1902, fue el último conflicto de envergadura en el que la caballería desempeñó un papel importante. Hoy día, su papel ha sido asumido por tropas que utilizan vehículos blindados de asalto y unidades aéreas.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The warriors of the Celtic tribes were widely feared by the inhabitants of the more civilized regions on the northern side of the Mediterranean. The Celts were known as tall, wild barbarians who fought with a savage fury. Conspicuous for their bravery, there are numerous accounts of Celts charging naked into battle with total disregard for their own safety. The Celts would often paint their bodies different colors to increase the intimidation factor. When clothed, the Celtic fighters wore brightly colored shirts and trousers, featuring striped or checkered patterns for decoration. They sometimes wore bronze helmets decorated with horns or wings in order to make themselves look even taller. The Celts were also head hunters, cutting off the heads of their defeated foes to serve as trophies. This was a way for a warrior to win great respect in Celtic society, and it may have served some religious purpose as well. The Romans were justifiably terrified of this practice and would often kill themselves rather than be taken captive by the Celts.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Celts are believed to have invented mail armor, which the Romans would adopt from them after the Gaulish sack of Rome in 390 BC. In battle, most Celtic warriors were probably equipped with spears, a simple weapon and easy to produce in large numbers. However, the Celts are much more famous for their use of large, two-handed iron swords. The Celts were the first to create these broadswords, which were used for slashing at the enemy (very different from the Roman short sword, which was entirely limited to stabbing). Celtic chieftains or other high-ranking figures were the ones most likely to carry these swords.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Celtic warriors were individually brave and fearsome fighters; however, they were also famously undisciplined. There was virtually no unit drill, and thus no unit cohesion: Celtic battles were wild melees in which every warrior fought as he thought best. Thus, while unmatched in personal combat, the Celtic warrior fared poorly against the group unity and strict discipline of the Roman legion.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Celtic tribes had almost no political unity either. Regarding each other with fear and suspicion and constantly engaged in petty internecine squabbles over territory, they were unable to pull together to face the approaching Roman threat. Facing this divided foe, General Julius Caesar was able to conquer Gaul in under a decade.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les guerriers des tribus celtes suscitent la crainte auprès des habitants des régions les plus civilisées du rivage nord de la Méditerranée. On dit que les Celtes sont aussi de grands et sauvages barbares, qui font preuve d'une violente fureur au combat. Leur bravoure est remarquable : il existe de nombreux récits évoquant des Celtes s'engageant nus dans la bataille et méprisant totalement leur propre sécurité. Les Celtes peignent souvent leur corps de différentes couleurs pour intimider davantage. Lorsqu'ils sont habillés, les combattants celtes portent des chemises et des pantalons aux couleurs vives et aux motifs à rayures ou à damiers. Ils portent parfois des casques de bronze décorés de cornes ou d'ailes pour les faire paraître encore plus grands. Les Celtes sont aussi des chasseurs de têtes, tranchant la tête des ennemis qu'ils battent pour s'en servir comme trophées. Cette pratique permet à un guerrier de jouir d'un grand respect dans la société celtique et joue peut-être aussi un rôle religieux. Les Romains sont à juste titre terrifiés par cette coutume, et préfèrent souvent se suicider plutôt que d'être capturés par les Celtes.[PARAGRAPH:1]On pense que les Celtes ont inventé la cotte de mailles, que les Romains adoptent après le pillage de Rome par les Gaulois, en 390 av. J.-C. Pendant la bataille, la majorité des guerriers celtes est sans doute équipée de lances, une arme simple et facile à produire en grandes quantités. Cependant, les Celtes sont bien plus connus pour leur utilisation de grandes épées à deux mains en fer. Ils sont les premiers à fabriquer ces épées de chevalerie qui servent à donner de grands coups à leurs ennemis, alors que l'épée romaine, bien plus courte, sert uniquement à poignarder. Ce sont essentiellement les chefs celtes et autres personnes de rang important qui portent ces épées.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les guerriers celtes sont de redoutables et téméraires guerriers, mais ils sont aussi connus pour leur indiscipline. L'unité du groupe n'est pas travaillée et il n'y a donc pas de cohésion. Les combats celtiques sont de sauvages mêlées dans lesquelles chaque guerrier combat de son mieux. S'ils sont inégalés au combat individuel, les guerriers celtiques s'en sortent moins bien face à l'unité de groupe et la stricte discipline des légions romaines.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les tribus celtiques n'ont par ailleurs presque pas d'unité politique. Se regardant mutuellement avec crainte et suspicion, et sans cesse engagées dans de mesquines luttes intestines pour des territoires, elles sont incapables de faire le moindre effort pour contrer la menace romaine qui approche. Face à cet ennemi divisé, le général Jules César parvient à conquérir la Gaule en moins d'une décennie.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Krieger der keltischen Stämme waren von den Bewohnern der zivilisierteren Regionen im nördlichen Mittelmeerraum gefürchtet. Die Kelten galten als große, wilde Babaren, die mit grausamer Wut kämpften. Es gibt zahlreiche Aufzeichnungen, die beweisen, wie mutig die Kelten ohne jede Rücksicht auf ihre eigene Sicherheit nackt in den Kampf zogen. Häufig bemalten sie ihre Körper, um den Einschüchterungseffekt zu erhöhen. Wenn sie angezogen waren, trugen sie grell gefärbte Hemden und Hosen, die zu Dekorationszwecken auch gestreift oder kariert gemustert sein konnten. Manchmal trugen sie auch Bronzehelme mit aufgesetzten Hörnern oder Flügeln, die sie noch größer erscheinen lassen sollten. Die Kelten waren außerdem Kopfjäger, das bedeutet, sie schnitten ihren geschlagenen Feinden die Köpfe ab und nahmen sie als Trophäen mit. Auf diese Art erwarb sich ein Krieger den Respekt der keltischen Gesellschaft - darüber hinaus kann diese Vorgehensweise auch einem religiösen Zweck gedient haben. Die Römer waren von diesem Verhalten zu Recht schockiert und nahmen sich daher lieber selbst das Leben, als in die Gefangenschaft der Kelten zu geraten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Man nimmt an, dass die Kelten den Kettenpanzer erfunden haben, den die Römer nach der Eroberung Roms durch die Gallier im Jahr 390 vor Christus übernahmen. Im Gefecht waren die meisten keltischen Krieger mit Speeren ausgerüstet, einer einfachen Waffe, die sich problemlos in großen Mengen herstellen ließ. Bekannter sind sie allerdings für den Einsatz großer beidhändiger Eisenschwerter. Die Kelten waren die ersten, die solche Breitschwerter anfertigten, mit denen sie ihre Gegner aufschlitzten (im Unterschied zu den römischen Kurzschwertern, die ausschließlich zum Stechen oder Stoßen geeignet waren). Diese Schwerter wurden hauptsächlich von keltischen Häuptlingen oder anderen hochrangigen Persönlichkeiten getragen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die keltischen Krieger waren jeder für sich genommen mutige und Furcht einflößende Kämpfer, aber sie waren auch bekannt dafür, dass sie so gut wie keine Disziplin aufwiesen. Es gab praktisch keine Truppenübungen und damit auch keinen Truppenzusammenhalt. Das keltische Kampfgebaren bestand in wilden Nahkämpfen, in denen jeder Krieger so kämpfte, wie er es für am besten hielt. Obwohl sie im Kampf Mann gegen Mann kaum zu übertrumpfen waren, kamen die keltischen Krieger daher gegen den Zusammenhalt und die strenge Disziplin der römischen Legionen nicht an.[PARAGRAPH:1]In den keltischen Stämmen gab es auch keinerlei politischen Zusammenhalt. Da sie sich gegenseitig mit Furcht und Argwohn betrachteten und ständig in kleinliche, aber mörderische Zänkereien über territoriale Ansprüche gerieten, waren sie nicht in der Lage, gemeinsam gegen die bevorstehende römische Bedrohung anzukämpfen. Diese scheinbar unüberwindbare Uneinigkeit ermöglichte es dem Feldherrn Julius Cäsar, Gallien in weniger als zehn Jahren komplett zu erobern.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I guerrieri delle tribù celtiche erano molto temuti dagli abitanti delle regioni più civilizzate dell'area a nord del Mediterraneo. I Celti erano noti per la loro altezza e per la furia selvaggia con cui combattevano. Barbari ma coraggiosi, vi sono numerosi aneddoti di Celti che caricavano nudi in battaglia con totale sprezzo del pericolo. Spesso i Celti si dipingevano il corpo di vari colori per risultare più intimidatori. Se combattevano abbigliati, i Celti indossavano pantaloni e maglie colorate con decorazioni a strisce o a quadri. A volte indossavano degli elmi con corna o ali per sembrare più alti. I Celti erano anche cacciatori di teste, ossia decapitavano i nemici e consideravano le loro teste dei trofei, con i quali si guadagnava il rispetto della comunità e che forse avevano anche degli usi religiosi. I Romani erano, a ragione, terrorizzati da questa pratica e spesso preferivano uccidersi da soli piuttosto che morire per mano dei Celti.[PARAGRAPH:1]Pare che siano stati i Celti a inventare la corazza a maglie, poi adottata dai Romani dopo il sacco di Roma del 390 a.C.. In battaglia i guerrieri celti probabilmente portavano con sé delle lance, un'arma semplice da produrre in grandi quantità. Tuttavia essi sono famosi per le loro spade di ferro a due mani. Essi furono i primi a utilizzare questi spadoni, che servivano a squarciare il nemico (a differenza della spada corta dei Romani, che serviva a pugnalare). Probabilmente erano i capitani o gli "ufficiali" a servirsi degli spadoni.[PARAGRAPH:1]Individualmente, i guerrieri celti erano coraggiosi e impavidi, ma in gruppo erano anche indisciplinati. Non vi erano esercitazioni di gruppo e quindi non c'era coesione di gruppo: le battaglie dei Celti si riducevano a mischie caotiche in cui ciascuno combatteva come meglio credeva. E così, se nell'uno contro uno erano imbattibili, quando dovevano lottare contro le disciplinate legioni romane i Celti si trovavano in enorme difficoltà.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le tribù celtiche non conoscevano neanche la coesione politica. Impegnate com'erano a guardarsi di traverso e con sospetto l'una con l'altra e a lottare per insignificanti dispute territoriali, non furono capaci di unirsi per affrontare la minaccia che veniva da Roma. Data la divisione interna del nemico, Giulio Cesare fu in grado di conquistare tutta la Gallia in meno di un decennio.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los guerreros de las tribus celtas eran muy temidos por los habitantes de las regiones más civilizadas de la orilla septentrional del Mediterráneo. Se les consideraba bárbaros altos y salvajes que luchaban con una furia brutal. Famosos por su valentía, existen numerosos testimonios de celtas que cargaban desnudos a la batalla, sin la menor preocupación por su seguridad. A menudo se pintaban el cuerpo de diferentes colores para intimidar más aún a sus enemigos. Cuando iban vestidos, llevaban camisas y pantalones de brillantes colores, con motivos de rayas o cuadros como decoración. Algunas veces llevaban yelmos de bronce con cuernos o alas para parecer aún más altos. Los celtas eran además cazadores de cabezas: decapitaban a sus enemigos caídos y se llevaban las cabezas como trofeos. En la sociedad celta, los guerreros podían obtener mucho respeto por este medio, que tal vez tuviese también un significado religioso. Como es lógico, los romanos le tenían mucho miedo a esta práctica y a menudo se quitaban la vida antes de dejarse capturar por los celtas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Se cree que fueron los celtas los que inventaron la cota de mallas, que los romanos adaptarían tras el saqueo de Roma en el 390 a. C. En la batalla, la mayoría de los guerreros celtas iban equipados con lanzas, un arma sencilla y fácil de producir en gran cantidad. Sin embargo, se les conocía más por su uso de grandes espadones de hierro. Fueron los primeros en utilizar este tipo de armas, que se empleaban para dar tajos (a diferencia de la espada corta de los romanos, más adaptada a las puñaladas). Los caudillos celtas (u otros personajes de importancia) eran los que solían llevar estas armas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Individualmente, los guerreros celtas eran adversarios valientes y temibles. Sin embargo, también eran famosos por su indisciplina. Casi no existía la instrucción por unidades y, como consecuencia, tampoco la cohesión: entre los celtas, las batallas eran salvajes escaramuzas en las que cada guerrero luchaba como consideraba mejor. Por eso, aunque no tenían rival en el combate individual, los ejércitos celtas se encontraban en inferioridad frente a la unidad y la estricta disciplina de las legiones romanas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Además, las tribus celtas carecían casi por completo de unidad política. Se miraban unas a otras con miedo y suspicacia y estaban constantemente enfrentadas en mezquinas disputas territoriales, por lo que fueron incapaces de unirse frente a la amenaza romana. Enfrentado a un enemigo dividido, el general Julio César pudo conquistar la Galia en menos de una década.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Repeating crossbows have a long history, with the oldest accurate written record dating to the Han dynasty (ca. 20-220 A.D.) in China. The Chinese repeating crossbow, the Chu-ko-nu, is an extremely simple piece of equipment. It is claimed to have been invented by Chinese strategist Zhuge Liang (181-234 A.D.), which is arguable since the earliest drawings of the weapon have been found from the buried library of Chu, dating all the way back to 250 B.C. The Chinese repeating crossbow saw its last serious action in the Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895, where photographs show repeating crossbows as common weapons among Manchurian troops. The basic construction of this weapon has remained mostly unchanged since its invention, making it one of the longest-lived mechanical weapons.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les arbalètes à tirs multiples ne sont pas une invention récente. La plus ancienne trace écrite date de la dynastie chinoise Han (vers 20-220 ap. J.-C.). L'arbalète à répétition chinoise, le Cho-Ko-Nu (ou Chu-Ko-Nu), est une arme extrêmement simple, qui aurait été inventée par le stratège chinois Zhuge Liang (181-234 ap. J.-C.), bien que des représentations de l'arme datant de 250 av. J.-C. aient été découvertes dans la bibliothèque enfouie des Zhou. L'arbalète à répétition chinoise fut notamment utilisée lors de la guerre Sino-japonaise (1894-1895), des photographies d'époque montrant que l'arme était très répandue dans l'armée Mandchoue. Cette arme, restée pratiquement inchangée depuis son invention, est l'une des armes mécaniques les plus durablement utilisées.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Repetierarmbrüste haben eine lange Geschichte und wurden erstmals während der Han-Dynastie (ca. 20-220 nach Christus) in China eingesetzt. Die chinesische Repetierarmbrust (Chu-ko-nu) ist eine sehr einfache Waffe. Angeblich wurde sie vom chinesischen Strategen Zhuge Liang (181-234) erfunden. Dies ist allerdings zweifelhaft, da die ältesten Zeichnungen dieser Waffe bei Ausgrabungsarbeiten in der Bibliothek von Chu gefunden und auf 250 vor Christus datiert wurden. Die chinesische Repetierarmbrust wurde zuletzt im Chinesisch-Japanischen Krieg 1894/95 als Standardwaffe der mandschurischen Soldaten eingesetzt. Dies belegen verschiedene zeitgenössische Fotografien. Der Grundaufbau der Waffe hat sich im Laufe der Jahrhunderte kaum verändert. Nicht zuletzt deshalb ist die Repetierarmbrust die dienstälteste mechanische Waffe der Welt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Le balestre a ripetizione hanno una lunga storia, che affonda le proprie radici nella dinastia Han in Cina (tra circa il 20 e il 200 d. C.) La balestra a ripetizione cinese, chiamata Chu-ko-nu, era un'arma molto semplice, probabilmente inventata dallo stratega Zhuge Liang (181-234 d. C.) per via dei disegni rinvenuti nella biblioteca sepolta di Chu, risalente al 250 a. C. La balestra a ripetizione Cinese è stata utilizzata con successo fino alla Guerra Cino-Giapponese del 1894-1895: alcune foto ritraggono dei soldati della Manciuria mentre impugnano quest'arma. La costruzione di queste armi è rimasta pressoché invariata dal tempo della sua invenzione, rendendola una delle armi meccaniche più durature della storia.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Las ballestas repetidoras tienen una dilatada historia, y su primera mención escrita se remonta a la dinastía Han (ca. 20-220 d. C.), en China. La ballesta repetidora china, o chu-ko-nu, es un artefacto extremadamente sencillo. Su invención se ha atribuido al estratega chino Zhuge Liang (181-234 d. C.), cosa que parece factible si tenemos en cuenta que los primeros diseños de este arma, encontrados en la biblioteca enterrada de Chu, datan del 250 a. C. La ballesta repetidora china vivió su canto del cisne durante la Guerra Chino-Japonesa de 1894-95, y su uso generalizado entre las tropas manchúes está documentado por diversos testimonios fotográficos. El diseño básico de esta arma ha permanecido casi intacto desde su aparición, lo que la convierte en una de las armas mecánicas de mayor longevidad de la historia.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The chariot was the earliest means of transportation in combat other than man's own powers of locomotion. The earliest known chariots, shown in Sumerian depictions from about 2500 BC, were not true chariots but four-wheeled carts with solid wooden wheels, heavy and cumbersome and lacking a pivoting front axle. The Hyksos apparently introduced the Assyrian chariot into Egypt shortly thereafter, where it was perfected for transportation and warfare. Within 500 years, Egyptian, Hittite and Palestinian chariots were extraordinarily light and maneuverable vehicles, the wheels and tires in particular exhibiting great sophistication in design and fabrication. Egyptian war chariots were drawn by either two or three horses, which were harnessed by means of chest girths secured by a pole and a yoke.[PARAGRAPH:1]The decline of the war chariot by the end of the 2nd millennium BC was probably related to the spread of iron weaponry, but it was surely related also to the breeding of horses with sufficient strength and stamina to carry an armed man into battle. Armed horsemen replaced the chariot in most Mediterranean civilizations. The use of chariots in war lingered in areas of slower technological advance, but in classical Egypt they were retained mainly for ceremonial functions.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le char de guerre fut le premier moyen de locomotion autre que la marche à pied utilisé pour la guerre. Les plus anciens chars connus, qui apparaissent sur des représentations sumériennes datant d'environ 2 500 av. J.-C., n'étaient pas de véritables chars, mais plutôt des charrettes à quatre roues en bois, lourdes, encombrantes et dépourvues d'essieu à l'avant. Un peu plus tard, les Hyksôs introduisirent le char assyrien en Egypte, où il fut amélioré pour le transport et la guerre. Moins de 500 ans après, les Egyptiens, les Hittites et les Palestiniens possédaient des chars incroyablement légers et manoeuvrables, munis de roues extrêmement sophistiquées. Les chars de guerre égyptiens étaient tirés par deux ou trois chevaux, attelés par des sangles fixées à un joug.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le déclin du char, vers la fin du deuxième millénaire av. J.-C., est probablement lié à l'apparition massive des armes en fer, mais aussi très certainement à l'apparition de races de chevaux suffisamment forts et endurants pour transporter un homme à la bataille. Le char fut ainsi remplacé dans la plupart des civilisations méditerranéennes par des cavaliers armés. L'utilisation des chars pour la guerre a perduré dans des régions moins avancées techniquement, mais dans l'Egypte antique, son emploi était limité à des fonctions de cérémonie.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Streitwagen war mit Ausnahme der eigenen Fortbewegungsfäigkeit des Menschen das früeste Transportmittel im Kampf. Die früesten Streitwägen, bekannt aus sumerischen Darstellungen von ca. 2500 vor Christus, waren keine echte Streitwägen, sondern schwere, schlecht zu manövrierende vierrädrige Karren mit soliden Holzrädern, die noch keine lenkbare Vorderachse besaßen. Vermutlich waren es die Hyksos, die kurz darauf den assyrischen Streitwagen nach Ägypten brachten, wo er für Transport- und Kampfzwecke optimiert wurde. Innerhalb von 500 Jahren wurden die von Ägyptern, Hethitern und Palästinensern verwendeten Streitwagen außerordentlich leicht manövrierfähig, wobei vor allem die Räder und Reifen besonders durchdacht gestaltet und verarbeitet waren. Die ägyptischen Kriegsstreitwagen wurden von entweder zwei oder drei Pferden gezogen, die mit Hilfe eines Brustgeschirrs angespannt waren, das durch ein Gestänge und einen Bügel gesichert war.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Niedergang des Kriegsstreitwagens gegen Ende des 2. Jahrtausends vor Christus stand allem Anschein nach im Zusammenhang mit dem vermehrten Einsatz von Eisenwaffen - fest steht allerdings auch, dass die Verdrängung dieser Gefährte aus dem Militärwesen etwas mit der Aufzucht von Pferderassen zu tun hatte, die über ausreichend Kraft und Kondition verfügten, um einen bewaffneten Soldaten in die Schlacht tragen zu können. In den meisten Zivilisationen des Mittelmeerraums wurde der Streitwagen durch bewaffnete Reiter ersetzt. In Regionen, in denen der technologische Fortschritt nur langsam Einzug hielt, wurden Streitwagen auch weiterhin im Gefecht eingesetzt, im klassischen Ägypten dienten sie hingegen in erster Linie nur noch für zeremoniellen Zwecken.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La biga fu il primo mezzo di trasporto in combattimento al di là del potere locomotorio umano. I primi esemplari conosciuti, rappresentati in dipinti sumeri intorno al 2500 a. C., non erano vere bighe, ma carri con quattro ruote di legno, pesanti e ingombranti, senza un asse sterzante anteriore. Pare che siano stati gli Hyksos a introdurre il carro assiro in Egitto poco tempo dopo, un mezzo perfetto per il trasporto e per la guerra. Per 500 anni, i carri egizi, ittiti e palestinesi furono veicoli straordinariamente leggeri e manovrabili; in particolare, le ruote e i loro rivestimenti mostravano una notevole cura nel progetto e nella fabbricazione. I carri da guerra egizi erano trainati da due o tre cavalli, i quali erano bardati al petto e fissati al carro con un paletto e un giogo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il declino del carro da guerra, alla fine del secondo millennio a. C., fu dovuto probabilmente alla diffusione delle armi in ferro, ma sicuramente anche alle nuove razze di cavalli, dotate di forza e resistenza sufficienti a trasportare un uomo armato in battaglia. I cavalieri armati sostituirono il carro nella maggior parte delle civiltà mediterranee. L'uso dei carri in guerra continuò nelle aree tecnologicamente meno progredite, ma nell'Egitto classico furono conservati solamente per funzioni cerimoniali.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El carro es el más antiguo medio de transporte militar, aparte de los medios de locomoción naturales del hombre. Los primeros carros de los que se tiene noticia, representados en imágenes sumerias datadas alrededor del 2500 a.C., no eran carros en el sentido estricto de la palabra, sino más bien carromatos con cuatro sólidas ruedas de madera, pesados y torpes, desprovistos de eje central pivotante. Según parece, los hicsos introdujeron poco después el carro asirio en Egipto, donde fue perfeccionado como medio de transporte y artefacto bélico. Antes de que transcurrieran quinientos años, los egipcios, hititas y palestinos habían desarrollado carros extraordinariamente livianos y maniobrables. En especial, las ruedas y llantas exhibían enorme sofisticación en su diseño y fabricación. Los carros de guerra de los egipcios eran tirados por dos o tres caballos, cuyos arreos consistían en cinchas pectorales fijadas por una barra y un yugo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Posiblemente, el declive del carro de guerra a finales del II milenio a. C. estuviera relacionado con la generalización del armamento de hierro y, con toda seguridad, con la aparición de razas de caballos con la fuerza y resistencia necesarias para transportar un hombre armado. Los jinetes armados reemplazaron al carro en la mayoría de las civilizaciones mediterráneas. Los carros de guerra siguieron utilizándose en áreas atrasadas desde el punto de vista tecnológico, pero en el Egipto clásico se conservaron principalmente por razones ceremoniales.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Cidainh was an ancient Celtic chariot, drawn by a team of two horses controlled by a driver and with a warrior riding on the back. Tt was constructed from wood and wicker-work, with one-piece iron rims for the wheels (probably a Celtic invention). Another Celtic innovation was the free-hanging axle, suspended from the platform with rope and possibly even with a leather suspension system. This resulted in a much smoother and controlled ride on rough terrain.[PARAGRAPH:1]Julius Caesar provides the only significant eyewitness report of Celtic chariot warfare: "Their mode of fighting with their chariots is this: firstly, they drive about in all directions and throw their weapons and generally break the ranks of the enemy with the very dread of their horses and the noise of their wheels; and when they have worked themselves in between the troops of horse, leap from their chariots and engage on foot. The charioteers in the meantime withdraw some little distance from the battle, and so place themselves with the chariots that, if their masters are overpowered by the number of the enemy, they may have a ready retreat to their own troops. Thus they display in battle the speed of horse, together with the firmness of infantry; and by daily practice and exercise attain to such expertness that they are accustomed, even on a declining and steep place, to check their horses at full speed, and manage and turn them in an instant and run along the pole, and stand on the yoke, and thence betake themselves with the greatest celerity to their chariots again."
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Albion Legion or British Legion were foreign volunteer units that fought under Simón Bolívar against Spain for the independence of Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, and Peru. They were composed of over seven thousand volunteers, mainly Napoleonic War veterans from Great Britain and Ireland, as well as some German veterans and some locals recruited after arriving in South America. Volunteers in the British Legion were motivated by a combination of both genuine political and mercenary motives.[PARAGRAPH:1]Their greatest achievements were at Boyacá (1819), Carabobo (1821), and Pichincha (1822), which secured independence for Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador. They also took part of the last major campaign of the Independence wars, culminating in the Battle of Ayacucho in Peru (1824), which marked the end of the Spanish rule in South America. The British Legions fought until the end of the wars, their number much depleted.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The junzi is a Chinese philosophical term often translated as "gentleman" or "superior person" and employed by both the Duke of Wen in the I-ching and Confucius in his works to describe the ideal man.[PARAGRAPH:1]In Confucianism, Sage is the ideal personality, however, it is very hard to become and so Confucius created the junzi, gentleman, which can be achieved by an individual. Later, Zhu Xi defined junzi as second only to the sage. There are many characteristics of junzi. Junzi' can live with poverty. Junzi does more and speaks less. A junzi is loyal, obedient and knowledgeable. Junzi disciplines himself. Among these, Ren is the core of becoming the junzi.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the potential leader of a nation, a son of the ruler is raised to have a superior ethical and moral position while gaining inner peace through his virtue. To Confucius, the junzi sustained the functions of government and social stratification through his ethical values. Despite its literal meaning, any righteous man willing to improve himself can become a junzi.[PARAGRAPH:1]On the contrary, the xiaoren (small or petty person") does not grasp the value of virtues and seeks only immediate gains. The petty person is egotistic and does not consider the consequences of his action in the overall scheme of things. Should the ruler be surrounded by xiaoren as opposed to junzi, his governance and his people will suffer due to their small-mindness. Examples of such xiaoren individuals can range from those who continually indulge in sensual and emotional pleasures all day to the career politician who is interested merely in power and fame; neither sincerely aims for the long-term benefit of others.[PARAGRAPH:1]The junzi enforces his rule over his subjects by acting virtuously himself. It is thought that his pure virtue would lead others to follow his example. The ultimate goal is that government behaves much like family. Thus at all levels filial piety promotes harmony and the junzi acts as a beacon for this piety.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The modern corvette appeared during World War II as an easily built patrol and convoy escort vessel. The British naval designer William Reed drew up a small ship based on the single-shaft Smiths Dock Company whale catcher Southern Pride, whose simple design and mercantile construction standards lent itself to rapid production in large numbers in small yards unused to naval work. First Lord of the Admiralty Winston Churchill, later Prime Minister, had a hand in reviving the name "corvette". During the arms buildup leading to World War II, the term "corvette" was almost attached to the Tribal-class destroyer. The Tribals were so much larger than and sufficiently different from other British destroyers that some consideration was given to resurrecting the classification of "corvette" and applying it to them. This idea was dropped, and the term applied to small, mass-produced antisubmarine escorts such as the Flower class of World War II. The first modern corvettes were the Flower class (Royal Navy corvettes were named after flowers, and ships in Royal Canadian Navy service took the name of smaller Canadian cities and towns). Their chief duty was to protect convoys throughout the Battle of the Atlantic and on the routes from the UK to Murmansk carrying supplies to the Soviet Union. The Flower-class corvette was originally designed for offshore patrol work, and was not ideal as an antisubmarine escort; they were really too short for open ocean work, too lightly armed for antiaircraft defense, and little faster than the merchantmen they escorted, a particular problem given the faster German U-boat designs then emerging. They were very seaworthy and manoeuvrable, but living conditions for ocean voyages were appalling. Because of this, the corvette was superseded in the Royal Navy as the escort ship of choice by the frigate, which was larger, faster, better armed, and had two shafts. However, many small yards could not produce vessels of frigate size, so an improved corvette design, the Castle class, was introduced later in the war, with some remaining in service until the mid-1950s.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A gunship is an armed helicopter. They are the cavalry of the modern army, designed to reconnoiter enemy positions, deploy special forces deep behind enemy lines, and so forth. However, modern gunships are armed with armor-piercing missiles and heavy, quick-firing machine guns; with these, a gunship can wreck havoc on enemy tanks and troops.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gunships first saw extensive service in the Vietnam War. The Soviet Union employed gunships in Afghanistan, and the US has used them to great effect in all its recent conflicts.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ground troops defend themselves from gunships with SAMs (surface-to-air missiles). When the CIA supplied Afghan guerillas with such weapons during the Afghanistan war; the Afghans used the SAMs with such devastating effect that they virtually crippled the Soviet war effort.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les hélicoptères de combat sont des hélicoptères disposant d'un armement. Ils forment la cavalerie moderne et sont conçus pour effectuer des missions de reconnaissance, pour transporter des forces spéciales derrière les lignes ennemies, etc. Certains hélicoptères de combat modernes disposent également de missiles perforants et de mitrailleuses lourdes à tir rapide. Ils peuvent ainsi anéantir des blindés ou des troupes d'infanterie.[PARAGRAPH:1]La première utilisation massive des hélicoptères de combat remonte à la guerre du Viêt-Nam. L'Union Soviétique a utilisé ces appareils en Afghanistan et les Etats-Unis les ont engagés dans tous les conflits récents.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les troupes terrestres se défendent contre les hélicoptères avec des missiles sol-air. Lors de la guerre d'Afghanistan, la CIA avait fourni ce type d'armes aux résistants afghans qui les ont si bien utilisés, qu'ils ont pratiquement paralysé l'effort de guerre des Soviétiques.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kampfhubschrauber sind gepanzerte Helikopter. Als Kavallerie moderner Armeen dienen sie primär der Ortung und Zerstörung feindlicher Stellungen und dem Truppentransport. Moderne Kampfhubschrauber sind mit panzerbrechenden Raketen und schweren MGs bestückt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Kampfhubschrauber kamen erstmals während des Vietnamkriegs flächendeckend zum Einsatz. Die Sowjetunion setzte Kampfhubschrauber erstmals in Afghanistan ein. Heute gehören sie zu den wichtigsten taktischen Waffen der amerikanischen Streitkräfte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die größte Gefahr droht Kampfhubschraubern von Boden-Luft-Raketen. Als die CIA in den 80er Jahren afghanische Rebellen mit Raketenwerfern versorgte, verzeichneten die russischen Truppen beträchtliche Verluste an Kampfhubschraubern.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'elicottero da guerra è un velivolo armato pesantemente e rappresenta la cavalleria degli eserciti moderni. Questi velivoli sono stati concepiti per identificare la posizione dei nemici, schierare le truppe nel cuore delle linee nemiche e via discorrendo. I moderni elicotteri da guerra sono equipaggiati con missili perforanti e pesanti mitragliatrici a ripetizione: con questo arsenale, gli elicotteri sono in grado di seminare distruzione tra i carri armati e i soldati nemici.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gli elicotteri da guerra vennero usati seriamente per la prima volta durante la Guerra del Vietnam. L'Unione Sovietica utilizzò elicotteri da combattimento in Afghanistan, mentre gli Stati Uniti li hanno impiegati in tutte le recenti operazioni militari.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le truppe di terra si difendono da questi elicotteri utilizzando i SAM (missili terra-aria): l'utilizzo di queste armi rovinò i piani dell'Unione Sovietica, quando missili terra-aria vennero forniti all'Afghanistan dalla CIA.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El helicóptero de combate es un vehículo aéreo artillado. Forman la caballería de los ejércitos modernos, encargados de misiones tales como el reconocimiento de las posiciones enemigas, el despliegue de las fuerzas especiales tras sus líneas y cosas así. Sin embargo, los modernos helicópteros de combate están armados con ametralladoras pesadas de gran cadencia de fuego. Con ellas pueden sembrar el caos entre los tanques y las tropas enemigas.[PARAGRAPH:1] Los helicópteros de combate empezaron a utilizarse exhaustivamente en la Guerra de Vietnam. La Unión Soviética los utilizó en Afganistán y EE. UU. ha hecho buen uso de ellos en todos los conflictos en los que ha participado en los últimos años.[PARAGRAPH:1] Las tropas de tierra se defienden de ellos con misiles tierra-aire. Cuando, durante la guerra de Afganistán, la CIA equipó a los guerrilleros con estas armas, los afganos emplearon los misiles con un efecto tan devastador que acabaron por desbaratar virtualmente la maquinaria bélica soviética.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A sophisticated and technologically advanced urban culture is evident in the Indus Valley Civilization making them the first urban centers in the region. The quality of municipal town planning suggests the knowledge of urban planning and efficient municipal governments which placed a high priority on hygiene, or, alternatively, accessibility to the means of religious ritual.[PARAGRAPH:1]As seen in Harappa, Mohenjo-Daro and the recently partially excavated Rakhigarhi, this urban plan included the world's first known urban sanitation systems: see hydraulic engineering of the Indus Valley Civilization. Within the city, individual homes or groups of homes obtained water from wells. From a room that appears to have been set aside for bathing, waste water was directed to covered drains, which lined the major streets. Houses opened only to inner courtyards and smaller lanes. The house-building in some villages in the region still resembles in some respects the house-building of the Harappans.[PARAGRAPH:1]The ancient Indus systems of sewerage and drainage that were developed and used in cities throughout the Indus region were far more advanced than any found in contemporary urban sites in the Middle East and even more efficient than those in many areas of Pakistan and India today. The advanced architecture of the Harappans is shown by their impressive dockyards, granaries, warehouses, brick platforms, and protective walls. The massive walls of Indus cities most likely protected the Harappans from floods and may have dissuaded military conflicts.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A swami sometimes abbreviated "sw." is an ascetic or yogi who has been initiated into the religious monastic order founded by some religious teacher. It is believed to be originally used for the ones who were initiated into to the Advaita Vedanta movement started by Adi Shankara. The usage of this word is not just for a yogi but also used for a religious guru, with or without disciples.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original grenadier was a specialized assault soldier designed to attack enemy fortifications. The grenadier was equipped with grenades, small metal balls filled with gunpowder. The grenadiers would approach the enemy's works, light and throw their grenades, and then rush the works in the resulting confusion and panic.[PARAGRAPH:1]As time progressed, the early grenades were abandoned, primarily because improvements in musketry and massed fire techniques made it highly likely that the grenadier would get shot while in the act of throwing the grenade. The term "grenadier" remained, however, and it was used to denote elite troops until the First World War.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les premiers grenadiers étaient des soldats spécialisés dans l'attaque de forteresses. Ils étaient équipés de grenades, de petites boules en métal remplies de poudre à canon. Le grenadier s'approchait des positions ennemies, allumait et lançait les grenades, puis donnait l'assaut alors que régnaient la confusion et la panique.[PARAGRAPH:1]Plus tard, ces grenades primitives seront abandonnées, les progrès réalisés dans le domaine des armes à feu et des techniques de tir groupés rendant l'approche extrêmement difficile : les grenadiers risquaient en effet de se faire tuer en lançant les grenades. Le terme "grenadier" a néanmoins perduré et a désigné, jusqu'à la Première Guerre mondiale, les troupes d'élites.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ursprünglich waren Grenadiere Offensiveinheiten für Angriffe auf feindliche Festungen. Die mit einer Frühform der Granate bewaffneten Grenadiere näherten sich einer feindlichen Stellung und sorgten mit ihren Granaten für Verwirrung und Panik.[PARAGRAPH:1]Aufgrund verbesserter Musketen wurden die Grenadiere bald überflüssig, zumal immer mehr Grenadiere im Sperrfeuer der Verteidiger fielen. Lediglich der Begriff "Grenadier" blieb als Bezeichnung für Elitetruppen bis zum 1. Weltkrieg erhalten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I granatieri erano dei soldati d'assalto specializzati nell'attaccare le fortificazioni nemiche. Il granatiere era equipaggiato con delle granate, piccole sfere di metallo piene di polvere da sparo. I granatieri si avvicinavano alle costruzioni nemiche, accendevano le loro munizioni e poi le scagliavano gettando i rivali nel panico e nella confusione.[PARAGRAPH:1]Con il passare del tempo, vennero abbandonate le prime granate rudimentali in favore dei moschetti e di altre armi da fuoco. Il termine "granatiere" è rimasto in voga e veniva usato per identificare le truppe d'élite fino alla Prima Guerra Mondiale.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Originalmente, los granaderos eran soldados de asalto especializados en el ataque a las fortificaciones enemigas que iban equipados con granadas, pequeñas esferas de metal llenas de pólvora. Se aproximaban a las posiciones enemigas, encendían sus granadas, las lanzaban y, a continuación, aprovechando la confusión y el pánico provocados, lanzaban su ataque.[PARAGRAPH:1]Con el paso del tiempo, estas granadas primitivas fueron abandonándose, principalmente porque los avances en el diseño de los mosquetes y las técnicas de fuego coordinado hacían muy probable que el granadero fuera abatido mientras estaba lanzando la granada. Sin embargo, el término "granadero" pervivió y se empleó como sinónimo de soldado de elite hasta la Primera Guerra Mundial.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Hoplites were well-trained citizen-soldiers of ancient Greece. Armed with spears and durable armor, they fulfilled the heavy infantry role in most engagements. Hoplites are tightly packed groupings of eight or sixteen rows of soldiers, who move and attack in unison, scattering less densely organized enemy forces. Hoplites worked well against the forces of the day, but broke down when facing more mobile and well-trained professional soldiers. The Roman legions victory over the Macedonian phalanx at Pydna in 168 BC effectively ended the phalanx's battlefield usefulness.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]By the time Ibn Battuta visited the Mali Empire during the reign of Mansa Suleyman, an elite corps among the military was present at court. These men were an outgrowth of the ton-tigui that had fought alongside Sundjata and his immediate predecessors known as the farari ("braves"). Each farariya ("brave") was a cavalry commander with officers and warriors beneath him. However, the roles of the farariya were not all identical. Farari served as ton-tigi of the Gbara, governors of far off provinces or simply field commanders. Many forms of the farariya titles would be used by Mali's successor states such as Songhay.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A horse archer (or horsed archer or mounted archer) is a cavalryman armed with a bow. Because using a bow requires a horseman to let go of the reins with both hands, horse archers need superb equestrian skills. Horse archery is typically associated with steppe nomads.[PARAGRAPH:1]The weapon of choice for horse archers was the recurve bow, because it was compact enough to shoot from a horse and retained sufficient range and penetrating power. The most serious threat to horse archers was arrows, and they could wheel away out of bowshot after every attack. Mounted archers therefore needed little or no armor and could ride light, fast mounts such as ponies. This made them cheap to equip and increased their strategic mobility.[PARAGRAPH:1]A drawback of horse archers was that the movements of a running horse disturbed the accuracy of the shot. After the invention of the stirrup, horse archers would stand up in their stirrups to absorb the motion of the horse. Another method to facilitate accurate shooting was to time shots between the strides of the horse.[PARAGRAPH:1]Horse archers were eventually made obsolete by the development of modern firearms.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les archers montés, ou archers à cheval, sont des cavaliers armés d'un arc. Ces guerriers devaient être des cavaliers hors pair, car ils devaient, pour tirer, lâcher les rênes des deux mains. L'archer à cheval est un concept directement associé aux nomades de la steppe.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'arme de prédilection des archers montés est l'arc recourbé, suffisamment court pour tirer à cheval, et disposant d'une portée et d'une puissance de pénétration raisonnables. La menace la plus sérieuse pour les archers montés était justement les flèches, et ils se repliaient fréquemment après chaque assaut. De ce fait, les archers montés n'avaient pas besoin d'armure et disposaient de montures légères et rapides, comme des poneys. Ils coûtaient donc peu cher à équiper et avaient une grande mobilité.[PARAGRAPH:1]Un des problèmes des archers montés était que le balancement des chevaux lancés au galop limitait la précision du tir. Après l'invention des étriers, les archers pouvaient tirer en se tenant debout sur ces derniers pour limiter le balancement. Une autre méthode utilisée pour améliorer la précision consistait à faire coïncider le tir avec la foulée du cheval.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les archers montés disparurent avec l'apparition des armes à feu modernes.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Berittene Bogenschützen sind mit Bögen bewaffnete Einheiten der Kavallerie. Da ein Bogenschütze aufgrund seiner Waffe die Zügel nicht festhalten kann, muss er ein perfekter Reiter sein. Nicht zuletzt deshalb setzen vor allem Nomadenvölker berittene Bogenschützen ein.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die bevorzugte Waffe der berittenen Bogenschützen war der kompakte Recurve-Bogen. Dieser konnte auch von einem Reiter abgefeuert werden und hatte eine bemerkenswerte Reichweite und Durchschlagskraft. Die größte Gefahr drohte einem berittenen Bogenschützen durch die Pfeile anderer Bogenschützen. Um diesen auszuweichen, trugen berittene Bogenschützen meist nur leichte Rüstungen und setzten ausschließlich leichte und wendige Pferde ein.[PARAGRAPH:1]Da die Bewegungen des Pferdes die Treffsicherheit der Bogenschützen beeinträchtigten, ritten diese nach der Erfindung der Steigbügel stehend, um die Bewegungen des Pferdes auf diese Weise auszugleichen. Andere Bogenschützen stimmten ihre Schüsse auf die Schrittfrequenz des Pferdes ab, um ihre Treffsicherheit zu verbessern.[PARAGRAPH:1]Einhergehend mit der Entwicklung moderner Schusswaffen verloren die Bogenschützen schließlich an Bedeutung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un arciere a cavallo è un soldato di cavalleria armato di arco; per scoccare le frecce con l'arco, il soldato a cavallo deve lasciare le redini e quindi deve avere delle abilità equestri notevoli. Gli arcieri a cavallo sono tipici delle popolazioni nomadi delle steppe.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'arma preferita era l'arco ricurvo, che consentiva una buona maneggevolezza insieme a una potenza di penetrazione sufficiente a trapassare armature. Il pericolo maggiore per questo tipo di unità erano le frecce; gli arcieri a cavallo avevano bisogno di poca armatura ed erano in grado di cavalcare animali rapidi. Queste caratteristiche rendevano estramente economiche queste unità e ne aumentavano il valore strategico.[PARAGRAPH:1]Uno degli svantaggi degli arcieri a cavallo è la precisione: il movimento degli equini rendeva particolarmente difficile prendere la mira. Dopo l'invenzione delle staffe, gli arcieri le usavano per alzarsi in piedi e assorbire le vibrazioni del movimento. Un altro metodo consisteva nello scoccare le frecce a intervalli regolari coincidenti con il passo del cavallo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gli arcieri a cavallo divennero obsoleti con lo sviluppo delle armi da fuoco moderne
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El arquero a caballo (o arquero montado) es un jinete armado con un arco. Como tiene que soltar las riendas para poder usar su arco, ha de ser un jinete extraordinario. Los arqueros a caballo son típicos de los pueblos nómadas de las estepas.[PARAGRAPH:1]El arma preferida por los arqueros a caballo era el arco compuesto, porque era lo bastante compacto como para dispararse desde un caballo sin menoscabo de su alcance y capacidad de penetración. La mayor amenaza para ellos la representaban otros arqueros, y siempre podían conjurarla situándose más allá de su alcance después de cada ataque. Por ello, los arqueros a caballo apenas necesitaban armadura, y podían emplear monturas ligeras, como los ponis. Esto los convertía en tropas baratas y aumentaba su movilidad estratégica.[PARAGRAPH:1]Su principal desventaja era que el movimiento del caballo reducía la precisión del arquero. Tras la invención del estribo, los jinetes empezaron a levantarse sobre ellos para absorber el movimiento del caballo. Otro método que permitía aumentar la precisión consistía en aprovechar entre zancada y zancada del caballo para disparar.[PARAGRAPH:1]La aparición de las armas de fuego modernas acabó por dejar obsoletos a los arqueros a caballo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Hittites were renowned charioteers. They developed a new chariot design that had lighter wheels, with four spokes rather than eight. It could hold 3 warriors as the wheel was placed in the middle of the chariot and not at the back as in the Egyptian chariots. Fast, powerful and dangerous, they were used to great effect against the enemies of the Hittites. The Battle of Kadesh in 1299 BC between Hatti and Egypt is likely to have been the largest chariot battle ever fought, involving some five thousand chariots.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Indian people are remarkably sturdy and hard-working. Their compact, wiry frames can stand up to the most difficult labor in some of the world's most difficult climates - of which there is a remarkable abundance in the Indian subcontinent, including desert, jungle, and perilously high mountains. Yet across all of this terrain can be found temples, shrines, and fortresses - monuments to the strength and determination of the hardy Indian people.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Indiens sont extrêmement robustes et travailleurs. Leur constitution fine et nerveuse leur permet de résister aux travaux les plus pénibles sous des climats extrêmes, comme ceux du désert, de la jungle ou de la haute montagne, largement répandus sur le sous-continent indien. C'est ainsi que l'on trouve, dans ces régions hostiles, temples, forteresses et tombeaux, qui apparaissent comme autant de témoignages de la force et de la détermination du peuple indien.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Inder sind hart arbeitende Menschen. Dank ihres drahtigen Körperbaus können sie in den lebensfeindlichen Wüsten, Urwäldern und Gebirgsregionen Indiens überleben. Trotz dieser schwierigen Lebensumstände findet man in ganz Indien Tempel, Schreine, Festungen und andere Symbole der Stärke und Entschlossenheit des indischen Volkes.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli Indiani sono dei grandi lavoratori incredibilmente forti. La loro costituzione robusta e asciutta gli permette di eseguire anche i lavori più duri nelle zone dal clima più ostile, come il subcontinente Indiano, ricco di deserti, giungle e montagne molto alte e pericolose. Malgrado ciò, lungo tutte queste strade si possono trovare templi, santuari e fortezze, monumenti alla forza e alla determinazione della fiera popolazione Indiana.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los hindúes son notablemente robustos y trabajadores. Sus cuerpos compactos y fibrosos pueden soportar el trabajo más duro en algunos de los climas más difíciles, muy abundantes en el subcontinente indio, como el desierto, la selva y las altas y peligrosas montañas. Sin embargo, en todos estos lugares se pueden encontrar templos, santuarios y fortalezas, monumentos a la fortaleza y la determinación de los vigorosos hindúes.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Aucac was the lowest rank in the Inca Army. The Inca Army was a multi-ethnic army charged with defending the sovereignty of the Inca Empire, expanding its borders, and putting down rebellions. It was also often used for political purposes, such as executions or coups.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the Incan Empire grew in size and population, the army did the same. At the height of the empire (under the reigns of Tupac Yupanqui and Huayna Capac), the army grew to approximately 200,000 men.[PARAGRAPH:1]The militaristic nature of the Incan monarchy caused great emphasis to be placed on the army and the position of the common soldier. Soldiers were given food and clothing and state aid was also provided for a soldier's family to ensure that agricultural production did not suffer due to the absence of a productive worker. For these reasons full-time soldiers were held in high regard and they even occupied their own position in the socio-political pyramid.[PARAGRAPH:1]When the army returned to Cuzco following a successful campaign they were received by women and children as heroes in a ceremony held in their honor. The ceremony took place in the Plaza de Armas in Cuzco and consisted of exhibiting the plunder and parading the prisoners as a symbol of the victory.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Guptas seem to have relied heavily on infantry archers, and the bow was one of the dominant weapons of their army. The Hindu version of the longbow was composed of metal, or more typically bamboo, and fired a long bamboo cane arrow with a metal head. Unlike the composite bows of Western and Central Asian foes, bows of this design would be less prone to warping in the damp and moist conditions often prevalent to the region. The Indian longbow was reputedly a powerful weapon capable of great range and penetration and provided an effective counter to invading horse archers. Iron shafts were used against armored elephants and fire arrows were also part of the bowmen's arsenal. India historically has had a prominent reputation for its steel weapons. One of these was the steel bow. Due to its high tensility, the steel bow was capable of long range and penetration of exceptionally thick armor. These were less common weapons than the bamboo design and found in the hands of noblemen rather than in the ranks. Archers were frequently protected by infantry equipped with shields, javelins, and longswords.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]An imam is an Islamic leadership position. It is most commonly in the context of a worship leader of a mosque and Muslim community by Sunni Muslims. In this context, Imams may lead Islamic worship services, serve as community leaders, and provide religious guidance. For Shi'a Muslims, the Imam has a more central meaning and role in Islam through the concept of Imamah. Imam may also be used in the form of a title for renowned Muslim scholars.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The bulk of the fighting hosts were made of up general purpose levies and volunteers, but most Kongo polities maintained a small core of dedicated soldiers- nucleus of a standing army. Special detachments and commands called lucanzos were also used for various missions, and one such under a commander called Kakula ka Kabasa was defeated by the Portuguese in 1586 when crossing a river. Other special troops sometimes used included elite scouting units, the pombos, who sometimes ran with, and kept up with horses when they were used in the region. The pombos also performed pursuit duties. "Light" and "heavy" troop types were recognized. The light troops were far more numerous, and relied more on individual skill and technique (dodging spears for example). The "heavies" were more disciplined and relied on stronger defensive weapons and formations. A limited number such types operated in the Kongo kingdom, and were armed with shields, unlike other forces. They were reputedly the best soldiers in the country. Tactical units were recognized, from basic sections of 100-125 men, to larger units of 500, called mozengos or embalos. Groupings of these units made up a specific field force that could number up to 15,000 troops.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Similar to the European knights, Japanese samurai were landowners who volunteered military service in exchange for a larger warlord's protection. Their handsome lacquer armor gave them durable protection on the battlefield. The warrior code of "Bushido" placed exacting restrictions on their behavior, both on the field of battle and off. One such tenet was that samurai of opposing forces must seek each other out and battle one on one. While their armor provided some safety from early gunpowder weapons, soon more advanced weaponry and skilled marksmen relegated them to administrative and leadership roles. The samurai caste was abolished in 1868.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Equivalent des chevaliers européens, les samouraïs japonais étaient des nobles guerriers qui se mettaient volontairement au service d'un seigneur contre sa protection. Leurs superbes armures laquées leur offraient une bonne protection sur le champ de bataille. Ces guerriers s'astreignaient à des règles de comportement très strictes, sur et hors du champ de bataille, règles définies par le "Bushidô," le code de leur caste. Ainsi, lors des batailles, les samouraïs devaient se battre entre eux en duel. Si leurs armures les protégeaient convenablement des tirs des premières armes à feu, l'apparition d'armes plus performantes et de tireurs d'élite les relégua rapidement à des tâches administratives ou de direction. La caste des samouraïs fut abolie en 1868.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ähnlich wie die Ritter in Europa waren die japanischen Samurai im Wesentlichen Grundbesitzer, die im Austausch für die Gewährung umfangreicherer Protektion seitens ihrer Lehnsherren freiwillig ihre militärischen Dienste zur Verfügung stellten. Ihre kleidsame Lackrüstung bot ihnen auf dem Schlachtfeld guten Schutz. Die Samurai hielten sich an den strengen Ehrenkodex des "Bushido", der sowohl ihr Verhalten im Kampf als auch im Privatleben klar regelte. Eine der hierin enthaltenen Vorschriften besagt, dass sich feindlich gegenüberstehende Samurai stets herausfordern und grundsätzlich Mann gegen Mann bekämpfen müssen. Ihre Rüstung bot zwar einen gewissen Schutz gegen die ersten Schusswaffen, doch fortgeschrittene Waffentechnik und fähige Schützen drängten sie in Verwaltungs- und Führungsrollen zurück. Im Jahre 1868 wurde die Kaste der Samurai abgeschafft.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Simili ai cavalieri europei, i samurai Giapponesi erano dei proprietari terrieri che fornivano volontariato militare in cambio di protezione dei grandi signori della guerra. Grazie alla loro bellissima armatura laccata, erano molto resistenti sul campo di battaglia. Il codice del guerriero, il "Bushido", imponeva ai samurai un comportamento integerrimo in combattimento e nella vita di tutti i giorni. Una regola fondamentale era che in combattimento i samurai dovevano affrontarsi uno contro uno. Inizialmente, le loro armature riuscivano a proteggere i samurai dalle prime armi da fuoco, ma ben presto l'avvento di armi più potenti e di tiratori scelti li relegò a ruoli amministrativi e di comando. La casta dei samurai venne abolita nel 1868.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Similares a los caballeros europeos, los samuráis japoneses eran terratenientes que se presentaban voluntariamente al servicio militar a cambio de la protección de un señor más poderoso. Sus bellas armaduras lacadas les daban una protección duradera en el campo de batalla. El código del ?bushido? del guerrero sometía su comportamiento a unas rígidas reglas, tanto dentro como fuera del campo de batalla. Una de ellas era que los samuráis de los ejércitos enfrentados debían buscarse los unos a los otros y combatir individualmente. Aunque su armadura les daba cierta protección ante las primeras armas de pólvora, los avances en armamento y la mejora en la puntería de los tiradores pronto les relegó a tareas administrativas y de liderato. La casta samurái fue abolida en el año 1868.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Longbowmen were highly skilled archers capable of firing up to six arrows a minute over long distances into massed enemy formations. Using bows constructed from a type of wood called Yew, they used arrows specifically designed to penetrate chainmail armor -- even plate if close enough. Frequently they would comprise approximately four-fifths of an army, and their devastating attacks helped to reverse the dominance of knights in warfare. Only lightly-armored, they enjoyed a great mobility advantage should their opponents survive their barrages.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once gunpowder began to find applications in the military, their use began to wane. Guns allowed foot soldiers the same effectiveness against knights, but without the decades of training required to be proficient with the longbow.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les archers longs étaient particulièrement adroits et pouvaient tirer jusqu'à six flèches par minute sur des troupes ennemies compactes situées à bonne distance. Ils utilisaient des arcs en bois d'if et des flèches spécialement conçues pour traverser les cotes de mailles, voire même, à courte distance, les armures de plaques. Jusqu'à quatre cinquièmes des armées étaient composés d'archers, leurs attaques dévastatrices ayant mis fin à la prédominance des chevaliers sur le champ de bataille. N'ayant pas de lourde armure, les archers bénéficiaient d'une grande mobilité, leur permettant de fuir si l'ennemi franchissait leur tir de barrage.[PARAGRAPH:1]Leur déclin correspond à l'apparition des armes à feu. Les canons étaient en effet tout aussi efficaces contre les chevaliers, mais ne nécessitaient pas, contrairement à l'arc, des années d'entraînement.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Langbogenschützen waren hervorragend ausgebildete Bogenschützen, die bis zu sechs Pfeile pro Minute über große Entfernungen hinweg auf feindliche Truppenformationen abschießen konnten. Ihre Bögen waren aus Eibenholz gefertigt, und die Pfeile wurden speziell entwickelt, um Kettenpanzer - bei geringerem Abstand auch Plattenpanzer - zu durchdringen. Meist waren vier Fünftel der Fußsoldaten in einer Armee Langbogenschützen, deren vernichtenden Angriffe letztlich auch dazu führten, dass die bis dahin nahezu uneingeschränkte Dominanz der Ritter auf dem Schlachtfeld endete. Weil sie lediglich leicht gerüstet waren, hatten die Langbogenschützen einen bedeutenden Mobilitätsvorteil gegenüber gegnerischen Kämpfern, die ihrem Sperrfeuer entkommen konnten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem Schießpulver für militärische Zwecke entdeckt worden war, wurden nach und nach immer weniger Langbogenschützen im Kampf eingesetzt, denn durch die Nutzung von Schusswaffen war es Fußsoldaten auch ohne die jahrelange Ausbildung zum versierten Langbogenschützen möglich, genauso effizient gegen Ritter zu Felde zu ziehen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli arcieri con arco lungo erano unità altamente addestrate, in grado di scoccare fino a sei frecce al minuto, su lunghe distanze, contro formazioni nemiche ammassate. Usando archi costruiti in legno di tasso, essi usavano frecce progettate specificamente per penetrare l'armatura a maglie e perfino quella a placche, se vicini a sufficienza. Spesso, costituivano i quattro quinti dell'esercito e i loro attacchi devastanti aiutarono a rovesciare il dominio dei cavalieri in battaglia. Protette solo in modo leggero, queste unità godevano di una grande mobilità, nel caso in cui i loro avversari fossero sopravvissuti ai loro tiri di sbarramento.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quando la polvere da sparo trovò applicazione in ambito militare, l'impiego degli arcieri cominciò a ridursi. Le armi da fuoco consentirono ai fanti la medesima efficacia contro i cavalieri, ma senza i decenni di addestramento richiesti per essere efficaci con l'arco lungo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Eran arqueros extremadamente hábiles, capaces de disparar hasta seis flechas por minuto contra grandes formaciones enemigas. Armados con arcos de madera de tejo, utilizaban unas flechas diseñadas especialmente para perforar cotas de malla... e incluso corazas a corta distancia. A menudo formaban aproximadamente las cuatro quintas partes del ejército y sus devastadores ataques contribuyeron a eclipsar la preponderancia de los caballeros en el campo de batalla. Utilizaban solo armadura ligera, lo que les proporcionaba una gran movilidad, para el caso de que el enemigo sobreviviera a sus descargas.[PARAGRAPH:1]El uso bélico de la pólvora significó el principio de su decadencia. Las armas de fuego proporcionaban a los soldados la misma eficacia contra la caballería pesada, pero sin las décadas de entrenamiento necesarias para aprender a manejar el arco largo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Warfare among the Mayans was a bloody and constant affair, serving both economic and religious purposes. Most leaders demanded tribute from conquered city-states in order to increase their own standing. Yet equally important was the capture of victims for sacrifice. This was the domain of the dreaded Holkan. Elite warriors armed with slingshots, stones and razor-sharp spears, the Holkans were trained specifically to capture enemies alive, to provide fodder for ever-hungry sacrificial altars.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Pour les Mayas, la guerre est une activité sanglante et permanente, qui sert des buts à la fois économiques et religieux. Le tribut payé par les villes conquises leur permet d'augmenter leur train de vie et les prisonniers capturés sont offerts en sacrifice aux dieux. Ces captures sont effectuées par les redoutables holkans. Guerriers d'élite armés de lance-pierres et de lances aiguisées comme des lames de rasoir, les holkans sont spécialement entraînés pour capturer leurs ennemis vivants, afin de les offrir en sacrifice à leurs insatiables divinités.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Krieg unter den Maya war eine blutige und dauerhafte Angelegenheit, die zugleich wirtschaftlichen und religiösen Zwecken diente. Die meisten Staatsoberhäupter verlangten Tribut von eroberten Stadtstaaten, um ihr eigenes Ansehen zu erhöhen. Die Gefangennahme von Opfern war jedoch ebenso wichtig. Dies war das Spezialgebiet der gefürchteten Holkan. Die Holkan waren Elitekrieger, ausgerüstet mit Schleudern, Steinen und rasiermesserscharfen Speeren, die dazu gefertigt wurden, Feinde lebendig gefangen zu nehmen, damit diese als Futter für die nimmersatten Altäre dienen konnten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Per i Maya la guerra era una questione sanguinosa e continua, che aveva scopi sia economici sia religiosi. Molti capi pretendevano dei tributi dalle città-stato conquistate in modo da poter incrementare la propria posizione. Altrettanto importante era la cattura di vittime per i sacrifici. Era qui che entravano in gioco i temuti Holkan. Ottimi guerrieri armati con fionde, pietre e lance affilatissime, gli Holkan erano addestrati a catturare vivi i nemici, in maniera da procurare offerte per gli assetati altari sacrificali.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Entre los mayas, la guerra era una realidad sangrienta y constante, al servicio de fines tanto económicos como religiosos. La mayoría de los líderes exigía tributos a las ciudades-estado conquistadas para mejorar su posición. Igualmente importante era la captura de víctimas para los sacrificios. Aquí es donde entraba en juego el temido holkan. Guerrero de élite armado con hondas, piedras y lanzas afiladas como navajas, el holkan estaba entrenado específicamente para capturar vivos a los enemigos que servirían de combustible a los siempre voraces altares.

TEXT.English: [TAB]At its height, the Mali Empire stretched half-way across Africa, and included many subordinate tribes. To keep order, the Mali employed a huge standing army. During war, the Mali often fought as "skirmishers" - soldiers who fan out in loose formation to protect the main force's flanks or front. The Mali skirmishers were lightly-armed archers in that force, famed for their courage and their marksmanship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A son apogée, l'Empire du Mali s'étendait sur la moitié de l'Afrique, et comprenait de nombreuses tribus soumises. Pour maintenir l'ordre, le Mali entretenait une immense armée permanente et, lors des conflits, menait souvent une guerre d'escarmouche : des soldats se déployaient en formation relâchée pour protéger les flancs ou l'avant du gros de l'armée. Ces unités étaient des archers légèrement armés, réputés pour leur courage et leur adresse au tir.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In seiner Blütezeit erstreckte sich das Großreich Mali über halb Afrika und herrschte über zahlreiche untergeordnete Stämme. Um die Ordnung zu sichern, unterhielten die Mali eine gewaltige Armee. Die Soldaten kämpften nicht selten als so genannte "Plänkler". Sie schwärmten also in loser Formation aus, um die Flanken und die Front ihrer Hauptstreitmacht zu schützen. Die Plänkler der Mali waren für ihren Mut und ihre Treffsicherheit berühmte leicht gepanzerte Bogenschützen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Nel suo momento di massimo splendore, l'Impero del Mali si estendeva per più di metà Africa e includeva moltissime tribù subordinate. Per mantenere l'ordine venne assemblato un potente esercito: durante la guerra, ci furono molti scontri tra "combattenti" che si muovevano liberamente per proteggere il gruppo principale. I combattenti del Mali erano soldati armati di archi leggeri e famosi per il loro coraggio e la loro mira.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]En su apogeo, el imperio de Malí se extendía por la mitad de África e incluía en su seno a numerosas tribus sometidas. Para mantener el orden, los malíes utilizaban un ejército permanente de enormes dimensiones. En la guerra, solían luchar como "hostigadores": soldados desplegados en formación abierta para cubrir los flancos o el frente del grueso del ejército. Los hostigadores malíes eran arqueros poco armados, famosos por su valor y su puntería.

TEXT.English: [TAB]During the Middle Ages sword technology improved, and the sword became a very advanced weapon. It was frequently used by men in battle, particularly during an attack. The spatha type remained popular throughout the Migration period and well into the Middle Ages. Vendel Age spathas were decorated with Germanic artwork (not unlike the Germanic bracteates fashioned after Roman coins). The Viking Age saw again a more standardized production, but the basic design remained indebted to the spatha.[PARAGRAPH:2]Around the 10th century, the use of properly quenched hardened and tempered steel started to become much more common than in previous periods. The Frankish 'Ulfberht' blades (the name of the maker inlaid in the blade) were of particularly consistent high quality. Charles the Bald tried to prohibit the export of these swords, as they were used by Vikings in raids against the Franks.[PARAGRAPH:2]Wootz steel which is also known as Damascus steel was a unique and highly prized steel developed on the Indian subcontinent as early as the 5th century BC. Its properties were unique due to the special smelting and reworking of the steel creating networks of iron carbides described as a globular cementite in a matrix of pearlite. The use of Damascus steel in swords became extremely popular in the 16th and 17th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was only from the 11th century that Norman swords began to develop the crossguard (quillons). During the Crusades of the 12th to 13th century, this cruciform type of arming sword remained essentially stable, with variations mainly concerning the shape of the pommel. These swords were designed as cutting weapons, although effective points were becoming common to counter improvements in armour, especially the 14th-century change from chain mail to plate armour.
TEXT.French: [TAB]During the Middle Ages sword technology improved, and the sword became a very advanced weapon. It was frequently used by men in battle, particularly during an attack. The spatha type remained popular throughout the Migration period and well into the Middle Ages. Vendel Age spathas were decorated with Germanic artwork (not unlike the Germanic bracteates fashioned after Roman coins). The Viking Age saw again a more standardized production, but the basic design remained indebted to the spatha.[PARAGRAPH:2]Around the 10th century, the use of properly quenched hardened and tempered steel started to become much more common than in previous periods. The Frankish 'Ulfberht' blades (the name of the maker inlaid in the blade) were of particularly consistent high quality. Charles the Bald tried to prohibit the export of these swords, as they were used by Vikings in raids against the Franks.[PARAGRAPH:2]Wootz steel which is also known as Damascus steel was a unique and highly prized steel developed on the Indian subcontinent as early as the 5th century BC. Its properties were unique due to the special smelting and reworking of the steel creating networks of iron carbides described as a globular cementite in a matrix of pearlite. The use of Damascus steel in swords became extremely popular in the 16th and 17th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was only from the 11th century that Norman swords began to develop the crossguard (quillons). During the Crusades of the 12th to 13th century, this cruciform type of arming sword remained essentially stable, with variations mainly concerning the shape of the pommel. These swords were designed as cutting weapons, although effective points were becoming common to counter improvements in armour, especially the 14th-century change from chain mail to plate armour.
