Diese neue Technologie wurde während des 2. Weltkrieges eingesetzt, um die deutsche V-2 zu bauen, die erste echte Lenkrakete. Wissenschaftliche Entwicklungen nach dem 2. Weltkrieg brachten noch leistungsfähigere und zielgenauere Raketen mit enormen Reichweiten hervor. Heute werden sie auch für nicht militärische Zwecke eingesetzt, z.B. zum Abschuss von Satelliten und zur Erforschung des Weltraums.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I razzi sono dei proiettili alimentati dall'espulsione di gas generati all'interno di una camera di combustione. I primi razzi a combustibile solido vennero inventati dai Cinesi nel XIII secolo: come carburante veniva utilizzata una mistura simile alla polvere da sparo. Malgrado i razzi siano stati usati per incendiare i palazzi e le vele delle navi per più di 500 anni, si è dovuto attendere il XIX secolo per vedere utilizzato il potere esplosivo di queste armi su un campo di battaglia.[PARAGRAPH:2]La ricerca e gli sforzi di scienziati come Robert Goddard nel XX secolo hanno migliorato la produzione dei razzi, rendendoli sempre più veloci e controllabili. Durante la Seconda Guerra Mondiale, questa nuova tecnologia venne utilizzata per creare il V-2 tedesco, il primo vero missile teleguidato. Gli sviluppi scientifici successivi alla Seconda Guerra Mondiale hanno migliorato ulteriormente la potenza e la gittata dei razzi. I razzi vengono anche utilizzati per scopi pacifici come il lancio di satelliti o l'esplorazione dello spazio.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los cohetes son proyectiles propulsados por la expulsión de gases generados en una cámara de combustión. Los primeros cohetes de combustible sólido, inventados por los chinos en el siglo XIII, empleaban una mezcla similar a la pólvora. Aunque los cohetes se han usado durante casi quinientos años en la guerra para incendiar edificios y velámenes, hasta principios del siglo XIX no se usaron en combate los primeros y toscos cohetes explosivos.[PARAGRAPH:2]La labor de investigación y diseño de científicos como Robert Goddard en el siglo XX perfeccionó su diseño y permitió fabricar cohetes más rápidos y controlados. Durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial, esta nueva tecnología se usó para crear la V-2 alemana, el primer misil guiado. Los desarrollos científicos desde la Segunda Guerra Mundial se han aplicado a adaptar el cohete para su uso en armas más potentes y precisas, dotadas de un alcance increíble. El cohete también tiene aplicaciones pacíficas, como el lanzamiento de satélites y la exploración espacial.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Artificial satellites are spacecraft that maintain an orbit around a celestial body. What differentiates an orbit from other types of space flight is it doesn't require any additional propulsion. Satellites can hold a number of different orbits. One type is a polar orbit, which causes the spacecraft to pass over the north and south poles. Another is an equatorial orbit, which causes the satellite to circle the Earth's equator. The farther the orbit from the surface of the earth, the longer it takes to complete a circuit of the earth. If the vessel uses an equatorial orbit at a distance of 22,300 miles from Earth, it can achieve geo-synchronous orbit, which causes the satellite to remain stationary over a specific area.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les satellites artificiels sont des engins spatiaux en orbite autour d'un corps céleste. Ce qui différencie une orbite d'un autre type de vol spatial est qu'elle n'implique pas l'utilisation d'un système de propulsion. Il existe de nombreuses orbites différentes. Il y a ainsi l'orbite polaire : l'engin spatial passe au-dessus des pôles nord et sud. Il existe aussi l'orbite équatoriale : le satellite longe l'Equateur. Plus l'orbite est éloignée de la surface de la Terre, plus l'engin mettra de temps pour faire le tour de la planète. Un engin en orbite équatoriale à 36 000 Km de la Terre peut effectuer une orbite géosynchrone, c'est-à-dire qu'il reste stationnaire au-dessus d'une zone spécifique.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Künstliche Satelliten sind unbemannte Raumflugkörper, die in der Umlaufbahn eines Planeten kreisen. Die orbitale Raumfahrt unterscheidet sich von der herkömmlichen Raumfahrt vor allem dadurch, dass kein zusätzliches Antriebssystem vorhanden sein muss. Satelliten können eine Reihe von Orbitalbahnen einschlagen, so zum Beispiel einen Polarorbit, der den Raumflugkörper über den Nord- und den Südpol steuert. Eine weitere Orbitalbahn ist der Äquatorialorbit, wobei der Satellit entlang des Erdäquators kreist. Je weiter die Umlaufbahn von der Erdoberfläche entfernt ist, desto länger dauert die vollständige Umkreisung der Erde. Wenn der Raumflugkörper im Äquatorialorbit eine Entfernung von etwa 36.000 Kilometern von der Erde erreicht, tritt er in die geostationäre Umlaufbahn ein, wodurch sich der Satellit dauerhaft nur noch innerhalb eines bestimmten Bereichs fortbewegt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I satelliti artificiali sono navicelle spaziali che mantengono un'orbita attorno a un corpo celeste. Ciò che differenzia un'orbita dagli altri tipi di volo spaziale è la mancanza del requisito di propulsione da parte della prima. I satelliti possono avere più orbite diverse: un tipo è quella polare, che fa passare la navicella attraverso il Polo Nord e il Polo Sud; un altro tipo è l'orbita equatoriale, che fa passare il satellite lungo l'equatore terrestre. Più lontana è l'orbita dalla superficie della Terra, più tempo occorre per completare il giro del pianeta. Se il satellite segue un'orbita equatoriale alla distanza di 36.000 Km dalla Terra, entra in un'orbita geostazionaria, il che significa che esso rimane stazionario sopra un'area specifica del globo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los satélites artificiales son naves espaciales que mantienen una órbita alrededor de un cuerpo celeste. Lo que diferencia una órbita de otras clases de vuelo espacial es que no requiere propulsión adicional. Los satélites pueden describir distintos tipos de órbitas. Una de ellas es la órbita polar, que hace que la nave sobrevuele los polos norte y sur. Otra es la órbita ecuatorial, que hace que el satélite rodee la Tierra por el ecuador. Cuanto más alejada esté la órbita de la superficie de la tierra, más tiempo tarda en completar una circunferencia alrededor del planeta. Si la nave emplea una órbita ecuatorial a una distancia de 35.890 km de la Tierra, puede alcanzar la órbita geosíncrona, lo que hace que el satélite permanezca fijo sobre un área específica.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Superconductivity is a property of certain metals and ceramics that allows them to conduct electricity with absolutely no resistance. This superconductive property only emerges at extremely cold temperatures, meaning that their creation demands an in-depth knowledge of low-temp techniques.[PARAGRAPH:2]Since its discovery, the superconductor has found its way into high-power magnets, MRIs (magnetic resonance imagers) and power storage devices that would never have been possible without its unique properties. An interesting side effect of the superconductor is the production of a powerful magnetic field that can produce a levitating effect, called the Meissner Effect, which some hope to translate into the hovering vehicles that were once nothing more than the dreams of science-fiction fans.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La supraconductivité est une propriété de certains métaux et céramiques, qui leur permet de conduire l'électricité sans aucune résistance. Cette supraconductivité n'apparaît qu'à des températures extrêmement froides, ce qui signifie que leur création exige une connaissance approfondie des techniques de basse température.[PARAGRAPH:2]Depuis sa découverte, le supraconducteur a trouvé son application dans les aimants à haute puissance, les IRM (Imagerie à résonance magnétique) et les appareils de stockage d'énergie qui n'auraient jamais pu exister sans ses propriétés uniques. Un des effets secondaires intéressants du supraconducteur est la production d'un puissant champ magnétique capable de produire un effet de lévitation, appelé effet Meissner, que certains espèrent pouvoir utiliser pour créer les véhicules flottants qui jadis n'existaient que les rêves des fans de science-fiction.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Supraleitfähigkeit ist eine Eigenschaft bestimmter Metalle und Keramikstoffe, die Strom ohne jeglichen Widerstand leiten. Diese Supraleitfähigkeit tritt nur bei extrem niedrigen Temperaturen auf, d. h. ihre Herstellung erfordert genaue Kenntnisse entsprechender Techniken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Seit ihrer Entdeckung werden Supraleiter in Hochleistungsmagneten, MRTs (Magnetresonanztomographien) und Stromspeichergeräten eingesetzt, die ohne deren einzigartige Eigenschaften niemals denkbar wären. Ein interessanter Nebeneffekt des Supraleiters ist die Erzeugung eines starken Magnetfelds, das einen Schwebeeffekt, Meißner-Effekt genannt, verursachen kann, den manche bei Schwebefahrzeugen einsetzen möchten, die einst nur in der Phantasie der Science-Fiction-Fans existierten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La superconduttività è la proprietà di alcuni metalli e ceramiche di condurre elettricità senza alcuna resistenza. La superconduttività compare solo a temperature molto basse, il che significa che la loro creazione implica una profonda conoscenza di tecniche produttive alle basse temperature.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dalla loro scoperta, i superconduttori hanno trovato impiego in magneti ad alto potenziale, MRI (apparecchi di imaging con risonanza magnetica) e in accumulatori, e non sarebbe stato possibile crearli senza le loro proprietà particolari. Un interessante effetto collaterale dei superconduttori è la produzione di un potente campo magnetico in grado di creare un effetto di levitazione, chiamato Effetto Meissner, che molti sperano di convertire per la creazione di veicoli in grado di volare a punto fisso, cosa che una volta era solo un sogno degli appassionati di fantascienza.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La superconductividad es la propiedad de ciertos materiales metálicos y cerámicos que les permite conducir la electricidad sin ofrecer prácticamente ninguna resistencia. Esta característica solo se manifiesta a temperaturas muy bajas, lo que significa que la creación de estos materiales exige un profundo conocimiento de crio-técnicas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Desde su descubrimiento, los superconductores se han utilizado en la construcción de imanes de gran potencia, MRI (imágenes por resonancia magnética) y dispositivos de almacenamiento de energía que hasta entonces nunca habían sido posibles. Un interesante efecto secundario de la superconducción es la producción de potentes campos magnéticos que generan un efecto de levitación (llamado el efecto Meissner). Existen proyectos para emplear este efecto en la propiedad de vehículos flotantes como los que hasta hace poco eran patrimonio exclusivo de la ciencia-ficción.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An artist is a person engaged in one or more of any of a broad spectrum of activities related to creating art, practicing the arts, and/or demonstrating an art. The common usage in both everyday speech and academic discourse is a practitioner in the visual arts only. The term is often used in the entertainment business, especially in a business context, for musicians and other performers (less often for actors). "Artiste" (the French for artist) is a variant used in English only in this context. Use of the term to describe writers, for example, is certainly valid, but less common, and mostly restricted to contexts like criticism.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Citizenship is the status of a person recognized under the custom or law of a state that bestows on that person (called a citizen) the rights and the duties of citizenship. That may include the right to vote, work and live in the country, the right to return to the country, the right to own real estate, legal protections against the country's government, and protection through the military or diplomacy. A citizen may also be subject to certain duties, such as a duty to follow the country's law, to pay taxes, or to serve in the military. A person may have multiple citizenships and a person who does not have citizenship of any state is said to be stateless. Nationality is often used as a synonym for citizenship in English - notably in international law - although the term is sometimes understood as denoting a person's membership of a nation (a large ethnic group). In some countries, e.g. the United States, the United Kingdom, nationality and citizenship can have different meanings.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]An engineer is a professional practitioner of engineering, concerned with applying scientific knowledge, mathematics, and ingenuity to develop solutions for technical, societal and commercial problems. Engineers design materials, structures, and systems while considering the limitations imposed by practicality, regulation, safety, and cost.[PARAGRAPH:1]The work of engineers forms the link between scientific discoveries and their subsequent applications to human needs and quality of life.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A general, without prefix or suffix (and sometimes referred to informally as a "full general"), is usually the most senior type of general, above lieutenant general and directly below field marshal. Usually it is the most senior peacetime rank, with more senior ranks (for example, field marshal, air chief marshal, fleet admiral) being used only in wartime, or as honorary titles.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some armies, however, the rank of captain general, general of the army, army general or colonel general occupied or occupies this position. Depending on circumstances and the army in question, these ranks may be considered to be equivalent to a "full" general or to a field marshal.[PARAGRAPH:1]The rank of general came about as a "captain-general", the captain of an army in general (i.e., the whole army). The rank of captain-general began appearing around the time of the organisation of professional armies in the 17th century. In most countries "captain-general" contracted to just "general".
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A merchant is a businessperson who trades in commodities produced by others, in order to earn a profit. The status of the merchant has varied during different periods of history and amongst different societies. Merchants have often been the subject of works of art.[PARAGRAPH:1]A merchant class characterizes many pre-modern societies. Its status can range from high (the members even eventually achieving titles such as that of Merchant Prince or Nabob) to low, as in Chinese culture, owing to the presumed distastefulness of profiting from "mere" trade rather than from labor or the labor of others as in agriculture and craftsmanship.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the Greco-Roman world merchants typically did not have high social status, though they may have enjoyed great wealth, and there were exceptions, such as in Syria and Palestine in late antiquity, where merchants did have a high social position.[PARAGRAPH:1]Medieval attitudes toward merchants in the West were strongly influenced by criticism of their activities by the Christian church, which closely associated their activities with the sin of usury.[PARAGRAPH:1]From around 1300 to the 1800s a large number of European Chartered and Merchant Companies were established to utilize international trading opportunities, for instance the Company of Merchant Adventurers of London, Chartered in 1407.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A priest is a person authorized to perform the sacred rituals of a religion, especially as a mediatory agent between humans and one or more deities. They also have the authority or power to administer religious rites; in particular, rites of sacrifice to, and propitiation of, a deity or deities. Their office or position is the priesthood, a term which also may apply to such persons collectively.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priests have existed since the earliest of times (see Proto-indo-European trifunctional hypothesis) and in the simplest societies, most likely as a result of agricultural surplus and consequent social stratification. The necessity to read sacred texts and keep temple or church records helped foster literacy in many early societies. Priests exist in many religions today, such as all or some branches of Judaism, Christianity, Shintoism, Hinduism. They are generally regarded as having positive contact with the deity or deities of the religion to which they subscribe, often interpreting the meaning of events and performing the rituals of the religion. There is no common definition of the duties of priesthood between faiths; but generally it includes mediating the relationship between one's congregation, worshippers, and other members of the religious body, and its deity or deities, and administering religious rituals and rites. These often include blessing worshipers with prayers of joy at marriages, after a birth, and at consecrations, teaching the wisdom and dogma of the faith at any regular worship service, and mediating and easing the experience of grief and death at funerals - maintaining a spiritual connection to the afterlife in faiths where such a concept exists. Administering religious building grounds and office affairs and papers, including any religious library or collection of sacred texts, is also commonly a responsibility - for example, the modern term for clerical duties in a secular office refers originally to the duties of a cleric. The question of which religions have a "priest" depends on how the titles of leaders are used or translated into English. In some cases, leaders are more like those that other believers will often turn for advice on spiritual matters, and less of a "person authorized to perform the sacred rituals" For example, clergy in Roman Catholicism and Orthodox Christianity are priests, but in Protestant Christianity they are typically minister and pastor. The terms priest and priestess are sufficiently generic that they may be used in an anthropological sense to describe the religious mediators of an unknown or otherwise unspecified religion.[PARAGRAPH:1]In many religions, being a priest or priestess is a full-time position, ruling out any other career. Many Christian priests and pastors choose or are mandated to dedicate themselves to their churches and receive their living directly from their churches. In other cases it is a part-time role. For example in the early history of Iceland the chieftains were titled goði, a word meaning "priest". As seen in the saga of Hrafnkell Freysgoði, however, being a priest consisted merely of offering periodic sacrifices to the Norse gods and goddesses; it was not a full-time role, nor did it involve ordination.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some religions, being a priest or priestess is by human election or human choice. In Judaism the priesthood is inherited in familial lines.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A scientist, in a broad sense, is one engaging in a systematic activity to acquire knowledge. In a more restricted sense, a scientist may refer to an individual who uses the scientific method. The person may be an expert in one or more areas of science. This article focuses on the more restricted use of the word. Scientists perform research toward a more comprehensive understanding of nature, including physical, mathematical and social realms.[PARAGRAPH:1]Philosophy can be seen as a distinct activity and which many consider not to be a science. It is aimed towards a more comprehensive understanding of intangible aspects of reality and experience that cannot be physically measured.[PARAGRAPH:1]Scientists are also distinct from engineers, those who design, build and maintain devices for particular situations. When science is done with a goal toward practical utility, it is called applied science. An applied scientist may not be designing something in particular, but rather is conducting research with the aim of developing new technologies and practical methods. When science is done with an inclusion of intangible aspects of reality it is called natural philosophy.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Espionage is often part of an institutional effort by a government or commercial concern. However, the term is generally associated with state spying on potential or actual enemies primarily for military purposes. Spying involving corporations is known as industrial espionage.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the most effective ways to gather data and information about the enemy (or potential enemy) is by infiltrating the enemy's ranks. This is the job of the spy (espionage agent). Spies can bring back all sorts of information concerning the size and strength of an enemy army. They can also find dissidents within the enemy's forces and influence them to defect. In times of crisis, spies can also be used to steal technology and to sabotage the enemy in various ways. Counterintelligence operatives can feed false information to enemy spies, protecting important domestic secrets, and preventing attempts at subversion. Nearly every country has very strict laws concerning espionage, and the penalty for being caught is often severe. However, the benefits that can be gained through espionage are generally great enough that most governments and many large corporations make use of it to varying degrees.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A statesman is usually a politician, diplomat or other notable public figure who has had a long and respected career at the national or international level.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A merchant is a businessperson who trades in commodities produced by others, in order to earn a profit. The status of the merchant has varied during different periods of history and amongst different societies. Merchants have often been the subject of works of art.[PARAGRAPH:1]A merchant class characterizes many pre-modern societies. Its status can range from high (the members even eventually achieving titles such as that of Merchant Prince or Nabob) to low, as in Chinese culture, owing to the presumed distastefulness of profiting from "mere" trade rather than from labor or the labor of others as in agriculture and craftsmanship.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the Greco-Roman world merchants typically did not have high social status, though they may have enjoyed great wealth, and there were exceptions, such as in Syria and Palestine in late antiquity, where merchants did have a high social position.[PARAGRAPH:1]Medieval attitudes toward merchants in the West were strongly influenced by criticism of their activities by the Christian church, which closely associated their activities with the sin of usury.[PARAGRAPH:1]From around 1300 to the 1800s a large number of European Chartered and Merchant Companies were established to utilize international trading opportunities, for instance the Company of Merchant Adventurers of London, Chartered in 1407.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A priest is a person authorized to perform the sacred rituals of a religion, especially as a mediatory agent between humans and one or more deities. They also have the authority or power to administer religious rites; in particular, rites of sacrifice to, and propitiation of, a deity or deities. Their office or position is the priesthood, a term which also may apply to such persons collectively.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priests have existed since the earliest of times (see Proto-indo-European trifunctional hypothesis) and in the simplest societies, most likely as a result of agricultural surplus and consequent social stratification. The necessity to read sacred texts and keep temple or church records helped foster literacy in many early societies. Priests exist in many religions today, such as all or some branches of Judaism, Christianity, Shintoism, Hinduism. They are generally regarded as having positive contact with the deity or deities of the religion to which they subscribe, often interpreting the meaning of events and performing the rituals of the religion. There is no common definition of the duties of priesthood between faiths; but generally it includes mediating the relationship between one's congregation, worshippers, and other members of the religious body, and its deity or deities, and administering religious rituals and rites. These often include blessing worshipers with prayers of joy at marriages, after a birth, and at consecrations, teaching the wisdom and dogma of the faith at any regular worship service, and mediating and easing the experience of grief and death at funerals - maintaining a spiritual connection to the afterlife in faiths where such a concept exists. Administering religious building grounds and office affairs and papers, including any religious library or collection of sacred texts, is also commonly a responsibility - for example, the modern term for clerical duties in a secular office refers originally to the duties of a cleric. The question of which religions have a "priest" depends on how the titles of leaders are used or translated into English. In some cases, leaders are more like those that other believers will often turn for advice on spiritual matters, and less of a "person authorized to perform the sacred rituals" For example, clergy in Roman Catholicism and Orthodox Christianity are priests, but in Protestant Christianity they are typically minister and pastor. The terms priest and priestess are sufficiently generic that they may be used in an anthropological sense to describe the religious mediators of an unknown or otherwise unspecified religion.[PARAGRAPH:1]In many religions, being a priest or priestess is a full-time position, ruling out any other career. Many Christian priests and pastors choose or are mandated to dedicate themselves to their churches and receive their living directly from their churches. In other cases it is a part-time role. For example in the early history of Iceland the chieftains were titled goði, a word meaning "priest". As seen in the saga of Hrafnkell Freysgoði, however, being a priest consisted merely of offering periodic sacrifices to the Norse gods and goddesses; it was not a full-time role, nor did it involve ordination.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some religions, being a priest or priestess is by human election or human choice. In Judaism the priesthood is inherited in familial lines.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A scientist, in a broad sense, is one engaging in a systematic activity to acquire knowledge. In a more restricted sense, a scientist may refer to an individual who uses the scientific method. The person may be an expert in one or more areas of science. This article focuses on the more restricted use of the word. Scientists perform research toward a more comprehensive understanding of nature, including physical, mathematical and social realms.[PARAGRAPH:1]Philosophy can be seen as a distinct activity and which many consider not to be a science. It is aimed towards a more comprehensive understanding of intangible aspects of reality and experience that cannot be physically measured.[PARAGRAPH:1]Scientists are also distinct from engineers, those who design, build and maintain devices for particular situations. When science is done with a goal toward practical utility, it is called applied science. An applied scientist may not be designing something in particular, but rather is conducting research with the aim of developing new technologies and practical methods. When science is done with an inclusion of intangible aspects of reality it is called natural philosophy.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Though laws and systems vary, as property, slaves may be bought and sold. Slaves can be held from the time of their capture, purchase or birth, and deprived of the right to leave, to refuse to work, or to demand compensation. Historically, slavery was institutionally recognized by most societies; in more recent times, slavery has been outlawed in all countries, but it continues through the practices of debt bondage, serfdom, domestic servants kept in captivity, certain adoptions in which children are forced to work as slaves, child soldiers, and forced marriage. Slavery is officially illegal in all countries, but there are still an estimated 20 million to 36 million slaves worldwide. Mauritania was the last jurisdiction to officially outlaw slavery (in 1981/2007), but about 10% to 20% of its population is estimated to live in slavery.[PARAGRAPH:1]Slavery has existed before written history and has existed in many cultures. Most slaves today are debt slaves, largely in South Asia, who are under debt bondage incurred by lenders, sometimes even for generations. Human trafficking is primarily used for forcing women and children into sex industries.

TEXT.English: [H1]Conditional Spawns[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain civilizations in Dawn of Civilization only spawn when the right conditions are met. These civilizations are Byzantium, Italy, Thailand, Argentina and Brazil. Their requirements are listed below: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Byzantium:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Greece has to be dead [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be alive [ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls Rome, the Byzantine spawn can be prevented by having a Solid stability [NEWLINE][BOLD]Italy:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be dead [ICON_BULLET]There has to be at least one independent city on the Italian peninsula [NEWLINE][BOLD]Thailand:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Always spawns if the Khmer are dead [ICON_BULLET]Also spawns if the Khmer stability is Shaky or lower [ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls the Khmer, Shaky stability is sufficient to prevent the Thai spawn [NEWLINE][BOLD]Argentina:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Argentine spawn area must not be Solid [NEWLINE][BOLD]Brazil:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Brazilian spawn area must not be Solid[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also allows to configure the spawn of the following civilizations: Tamils, Tibet, Moors, Poland and Congo. While their default setting is to appear in every game, this can be modified by editing the GlobalDefinesAlt.xml file in Assets\XML\. A value of 0 means that the civilization will not appear in the game, while a value greater than 1 means that the civilization will only appear in one out of that many games on average. For instance, setting the value for Poland to 3 means that Poland has a 1/3 chance to appear in your game. However, this setting will be ignored if you are playing as a civilization in the vicinity. For example, when playing Russia, Poland will always appear, regardless of its spawn setting.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Congresses[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses in Rhye's and Fall represent the phenomenon of informal institutionalization of international politics that began during the 19th century. This includes the idea of the balance of power which manifested itself in the Congress of Vienna and the Concert of Europe, but also international conferences on territorial claims such as the Berlin Congress. They also represent other diplomatic exchanges of territory like the Louisiana Purchase.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses take place as soon as the first civilization discovers Nationalism and regularly occur every 15 turns. The ten most powerful civilizations of the world will be invited, and each of them can either claim a city or request to found a colony on unsettled territory. If the majority of civilizations agrees, the request is granted and the city will change hands or a settler will be created on the demanded empty spot. While the human player can decide on claims by voting YES, NO or ABSTAIN, the AI will make its own decisions based on a variety of factors. These include the legitimacy of the claim (e.g. if the claimed city is historical for the civilization or if it already has culture there), the relationship to the demanding and controlling civilizations, including their own interest in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]If a player claim was considered legitimate by an AI, but not granted because of insufficient relations, or if a player city has been granted to another civilization by the AI, the player can choose a number of options to influence the vote of AI civilizations in their favor. This can happen either through bribery (offering gold) or manipulation (expending espionage points). The player can spend varying amounts of both resources depending on how much they consider influencing their votes necessary. Another way to influence the AI is by agreeing to their own claims in the same congress - or at least avoiding to vote against them![PARAGRAPH:2]If all attempts fail and the congress still gives away one of your cities, you still have the opportunity to refuse handing it over. But be careful, this may cause some of the civilizations that agreed to the request to go to war over your contempt for their decision! The more votes were in favor of reassigning the city, the likelier an individual civilization is to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses are disrupted by global wars, under which different rules apply. A global war takes place when at least half the military power of the world is at war with each other. During these times, no congresses occur because the world is settling its differences on the battlefield instead of the negotiation table. However, when such a global war ends (by the main belligerents agreeing to peace), peace is enforced on all belligerents and a new congress is called to restore order after the war. Such a congress differs from normal congresses in that only belligerents are invited, that only civilizations on the winning side are allowed to make demands, and that it is impossible to request colonizing free territory. Civilizations that have lost the war still can vote on all claims, however. Congresses completely come to an end when the United Nations are built because their formalized approach to multilateral diplomacy makes congresses obsolete. [NEWLINE]If you are familiar with Congresses from Rhye's and Fall, you will notice multiple significant changes and improvements over the previous system, some of which have already been mentioned: [ICON_BULLET]In addition to periodic congresses, congresses can also occur after global wars [ICON_BULLET]Participants can also request to settle free territory [ICON_BULLET]A streamlined interaction process so that the entire congress can be resolved in one turn [ICON_BULLET]Significant improvements in computation times [ICON_BULLET]When voting on a claim, the camera centers on the plot or city in question [ICON_BULLET]The option to influence a civilization's decision is only offered when there is actually a chance of success [ICON_BULLET]Attempts to influence a decision are now specific to a certain claim and can be used both to achieve agreement to an own claim and disagreement with a claim on your own cities [ICON_BULLET]There is no limit on how many civilizations can be attempted to be influenced during the same Congress [ICON_BULLET]In addition to bribery by offering gold, votes can also be manipulated by expending espionage [ICON_BULLET]More sophisticated AI decisionmaking: it now takes the legitimacy of the claim, its relations to the claimant and owner, and its own interest in the city into account [ICON_BULLET]More global AI decisionmaking: your own voting behavior influences how the AI treats your claims and the claims against you, global opinion influences how likely AIs are to go to war over a refused claim [ICON_BULLET]No more multiple assignments during the same Congress: if more than one civilization have successfully claimed the same city, it goes to the civilization that received the most votes in favor
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Continents, Countries and Unique Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye has split the World Map into separate continents. No longer will a wonder built in China have an effect on a city in South Africa. With this magic, Rhye also further subdivided the world into countries, even assigning historically accurate city names to individual tiles. These names will be your guide for the UHVs. For most of the territory UHVs (Control the Balkans, Control Mesopotamia, etc.) you will be required to control up to 3 cities in the area. Rome is the most stringent, requiring 2 cities in Iberia, 3 cities in Gaul, 1 city in Britain, 2 cities in Africa, 4 cities in Greece and Byzantium and 2 cities in Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the regions that pertain to your UHV are shown in the tile tooltip when hovering over the relevant tiles.
TEXT.French: [H1]Continents, pays et victoires historiques uniques[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye a divisé le monde en continents séparés. Une merveille construite en Chine n'aura donc plus aucun effet sur une ville en Afrique du Sud. Avec sa magie, Rhye a continué de diviser le monde pour créer des pays et a même attribué à des cases des noms de villes historiquement exacts. Ces noms vous serviront de repère pour remporter les victoires historiques uniques (VHU). Pour la plupart des VHU de territoire (Contrôler les Balkans, Contrôler la Mésopotamie, etc.), vous devrez contrôler jusqu'à trois villes dans la zone. C'est avec Rome qu'il sera le plus difficile d'y parvenir, car vous devrez contrôler trois villes en Ibérie, trois en France, trois en Afrique du Nord, deux en Allemagne, une en Angleterre et trois en Italie.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kontinente, Länder und Einzigartige Historische Siege[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye hat die Weltkarte in separate Kontinente aufgeteilt, somit hat ein in China errichtetes Wunder nun keine Auswirkungen mehr auf eine Stadt in Südafrika. Darüber hinaus weist die Karte natürlich auch Länder aus und den einzelnen Geländefeldern innerhalb dieser Länder sind die historisch korrekten Städtenamen zugewiesen, welche Sie wiederum zu Ihren Einzigartigen Historischen Siegen (EHS) führen. Bei den meisten territorialen EHS ("Bringen Sie den Balkan unter Ihre Kontrolle", "Bringen Sie Mesopotamien unter Ihre Kontrolle" etc.) müssen Sie bis zu 3 Städte in der betreffenden Region in Ihren Besitz bringen. Besonders hohe Anforderungen stellt dagegen Rom, denn hier müssen Sie gleich 3 Städte in Iberien, 3 in Frankreich, 3 in Nordafrika, 2 in Deutschland, 1 in England und 3 in Italien einnehmen.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the Regionen, die für Ihren EHS relevant sind, werden im Tooltip angezeigt, wenn Sie mit dem Cursor auf das entsprechende Feld zeigen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Continenti, paesi e Vittorie Storiche uniche[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha diviso la mappa mondiale in continenti separati. Una meraviglia costruita in Cina non avrà più effetto su una città in Sud Africa. In questo modo Rhye ha anche ulteriormente suddiviso il mondo in Paesi, assegnando addirittura nomi precisi di città alle singole caselle. Questi nomi saranno la tua guida per le vittorie storiche. Per la maggior parte delle vittorie storiche legate ai territori (controlla i Balcani, controlla la Mesopotamia, ecc.) ti verrà chiesto di controllare 3 città nella zona. Roma è la più difficile, visto che servono 3 città in Spagna, 3 in Francia, 3 nell'Africa settentrionale, 2 in Germania, 1 in Inghilterra e 3 in Italia.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Continentes, países y victorias históricas únicas[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha dividido el mapamundi en continentes separados. Una maravilla construida en China ya no producirá efectos en Sudáfrica. De la misma manera, Rhye también ha dividido el mundo en países, y ha asignado nombres de ciudades históricas con precisión a las casillas individuales. Esos nombres te servirán de guía para las victorias históricas. En la mayoría de las victorias históricas territoriales (controlar los Balcanes, controlar Mesopotamia, etc.) tendrás que controlar hasta 4 ciudades de la zona. Roma es la más estricta, pues exige 3 ciudades en la península Ibérica, 3 en Francia, 3 en el norte de África, 2 en Alemania, 1 en Inglaterra y 3 en Italia.

TEXT.English: [H1]Diplomatic Institutions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [BOLD]Apostolic Palace[\BOLD] and [BOLD]United Nations[\BOLD] have seen some changes in Dawn of Civilizations. Several rules have been modified and certain resolutions were to increase their impact and make them more interesting to interact with. General changes: [ICON_BULLET]Instead of being directly proportional to population, the number of votes of a civilization are now proportional to the square root of its population. This reduces the influence of large civilizations and makes cooperation with smaller civilizations more important. [ICON_BULLET]Defying resolutions now follows different rules for the two institutions. [ICON_BULLET]When a civilization attempts to win a diplomatic victory, its own votes and the votes of its vassals are disregarded. Instead it needs to win a majority among the remaining votes. This way, the diplomatic victory truly requires diplomacy, and cannot be achieved by military subjugation. [H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Apostolic Palace elections triggered by constructing Saint Peter's Basilica [ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote. [ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it. [ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply. [ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade). [ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half. [ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization. [ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution. [H2]United Nations[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions. [ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents. [ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.
TEXT.German: No Translation
