Um mehr Platz für anlegende Schiffe zu schaffen, können die Kais durch Piers und Molen ergänzt werden.[PARAGRAPH:2]An den Flussufern großer Städte haben sich die einstmals wichtigen Transportaktivitäten zu Schiff an die Stadtränder oder nach außerhalb verlagert. Der Name Kai ist für diese Uferbefestigungen jedoch erhalten geblieben. Sie dienen oft als Promenade oder Boulevard. Beispiele dafür sind der Quai d'Orsay (mit dem Außenministerium) am linken Seine-Ufer in Paris, der Bund in Shanghai oder der Franz-Josefs-Kai am stadtseitigen Ufer des Donaukanals in Wien.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An armory is a building in which weapons and ammunition are distributed, stored, maintained, or produced. While dedicated armories have existed throughout history, the need for them increased significantly with the development of interchangeable parts and the mechanically intricate workings of modern firearms. Swords, bows, and even muskets could conceivably be maintained using only conveniently portable tools, but machined components for a rifle or machine gun require concentrated facilities.[PARAGRAPH:2]The increasingly elaborate organization of armories and arsenals has formed a key element of the rise of logistics in modern militaries. An army with large, well-organized, well-maintained stockpiles of weapons has a major advantage over an irregular or ill-equipped force that lacks them.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Bathing is a common (though not universal) human custom. It is both pleasurable and utilitarian; it ensures that the body is not covered in noxious substances, and is often considered highly relaxing. It can also kill pests and parasites by submersion in water, especially with the addition of various soaps and other chemical substances. In many cultures, bathing also has a spiritual function; ensuring purity of the spirit as well as purity of the body.[PARAGRAPH:2]Primitive societies generally bathe in naturally occurring bodies of water, but this is impractical in a large city. Even if customs permit the level of public undress this would require, there would be too many people making use of the same water supply. Therefore, public, communal bathing systems and bathhouses were a popular and common form of public infrastructure in large cities. Examples of public bathing infrastructure were found in (but not necessarily limited to) the ancient Indus valley, in classical Greece and (famously) Rome, in Japan and the Ottoman Empire, in Indonesia, and in Scandinavia up to the present day.[PARAGRAPH:2]Public (and indeed private) bathing declined in Europe during the Middle Ages due to religious strictures encouraging increased body modesty and condemning bathhouses as sites for prostitution. However, increased awareness of sanitary needs and greater availability of fresh water in the industrial era led to a resurgence, first of publicly available baths that allowed relatively greater privacy than in Roman times, and later of private bathing facilities in every individual home with the rise of indoor plumbing.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A department store or magazine is a retail establishment offering a wide range of consumer goods in different product categories known as "departments". In modern major cities, the department store made a dramatic appearance in the middle of the 19th century, and permanently reshaped shopping habits, and the definition of service and luxury. Similar developments were under way in London (with Whiteleys), in Paris (Le Bon Marché in 1852) and in New York (with Stewart's).[PARAGRAPH:2]Department stores today have sections that sell the following: clothing, furniture, home appliances, toys, cosmetics, houseware, gardening, toiletries, sporting goods, do it yourself, paint, and hardware and additionally select other lines of products such as food, books, jewelry, electronics, stationery, photographic equipment, baby products, and products for pets. Customers check out near the front of the store or, alternatively, at sales counters within each department. Some are part of a retail chain of many stores, while others may be independent retailers. In the 1970s, they came under heavy pressure from discounters. Since 2010, they have come under even heavier pressure from online stores.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]An electrical grid is an interconnected network for delivering electricity from suppliers to consumers. It consists of generating stations that produce electrical power, high voltage transmission lines that carry power from distant sources to demand centers, and distribution lines that connect individual customers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Power stations may be located near a fuel source, at a dam site, or to take advantage of renewable energy sources, and are often located away from heavily populated areas. They are usually quite large to take advantage of the economies of scale. The electric power which is generated is stepped up to a higher voltage at which it connects to the electric power transmission network.[PARAGRAPH:2]The bulk power transmission network will move the power long distances, sometimes across international boundaries, until it reaches its wholesale customer (usually the company that owns the local electric power distribution network).[PARAGRAPH:2]On arrival at a substation, the power will be stepped down from a transmission level voltage to a distribution level voltage. As it exits the substation, it enters the distribution wiring. Finally, upon arrival at the service location, the power is stepped down again from the distribution voltage to the required service voltage(s).[PARAGRAPH:2]Electrical grids vary in size from covering a single building through national grids which cover whole countries, to transnational grids which can cross continents.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Historically an estate comprises the houses and outbuildings and supporting farmland and woods that surround the gardens and grounds of a very large property, such as a country house or mansion. It is the modern term for a manor, but lacks the latter's now abolished jurisdictional authority. It is an "estate" because the profits from its produce and rents are sufficient to support the household in the house at its center, formerly known as the manor house. Thus "the estate" may refer to all other cottages and villages in the same ownership as the mansion itself, covering more than one former manor. Examples of such great estates are Woburn Abbey in Bedfordshire, England, and Blenheim Palace, Oxfordshire built to replace the former manor house of Woodstock.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Although large mills and workshops were established in ancient China, Rome and the Middle East, the Venice Arsenal provides one of the first examples of a factory in the modern sense of the word. Founded in 1104 in Venice, Republic of Venice, several hundred years before the Industrial Revolution, it mass-produced ships on assembly lines using manufactured parts. The Venice Arsenal apparently produced nearly one ship every day and, at its height, employed 16,000 people.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many historians regard Matthew Boulton 's Soho Manufactory (established in 1761 in Birmingham) as the first modern factory. (Other claims might be made for John Lombe 's silk mill in Derby (1721), or Richard Arkwright 's Cromford Mill (1771) purpose built to fit the equipment it held and taking the material through the various manufacturing processes.) One historian, Jack Weatherford, contends that the first factory was in Potosa, for processing silver ingot slugs into coins, because there was so much silver being mined close by. See City and Factory Life for more background concerning factory conditions.[PARAGRAPH:2]British colonies in the late 18th century built factories simply as buildings where a large number of laborers gathered to perform hand labor, usually in textile production. This proved more efficient for administration and for the distribution of raw materials to individual laborers than earlier methods of manufacturing such as cottage industries or the putting-out system.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cotton mills used inventions such as the steam engine and the power loom to pioneer the industrial factory of the 19th century, where precision machine tools and replaceable parts allowed greater efficiency and less waste.[PARAGRAPH:2]Between 1820 and 1850, the non-mechanized factories supplanted the traditional artisan shops as the predominant form of manufacturing institution. Even though the theory on why and how the non-mechanized factories gradually replaced the small artisan shops is still ambiguous, what is apparent is that the larger-scale factories enjoyed technological gains and advance in efficiency over the small artisan shops. In fact, the larger scale forms of factory establishments were more favorable and advantageous over the small artisan shops in terms of competition for survival.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Pharmacists are allied health professionals who practice in pharmacy, the field of health sciences focusing on safe and effective medication use. The role of the pharmacist has shifted from the classical "lick, stick, and pour" dispensary role (that is, "lick & stick the labels, count & pour the pills"), to being an integrated member of the health care team directly involved in patient care. Pharmacists undergo university-level education to understand biochemical mechanisms of action of drugs, drug uses and therapeutic roles, side effects, potential interactions, and monitoring parameters. This is mated to education in anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology. Professional interpretation and communication of this specialized knowledge to patients, physicians, and other health care providers are functions which pharmacists provide, and are central to the provision of safe and effective drug therapy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The most common pharmacist positions are that of a community pharmacist (also referred to as "retail pharmacist" or "dispensing chemist"), or a hospital pharmacist, where they instruct and counsel on the proper use and adverse effects of medically prescribed drugs and medicines. In most countries, the profession is subject to professional regulation. Depending on the legal scope of practice, pharmacists may contribute to prescribing (also referred to as "pharmacist prescriber") and administering certain medications (e.g. immunizations in some jurisdictions). Pharmacists may also practice in a variety of other settings, including industry, research, academia, military, and government.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Archaeological evidence for the Old Babylonian school system suggests that scribal education was small-scale and usually took place in private homes. School tablets have been found in private residences in many sites across Mesopotamia. Some houses, where particularly large numbers of school tablets were unearthed, have been interpreted by archaeologists as "school houses" or homes in which scribal education almost certainly took place. The best example of this is House F in the city of Nippur. Nearly one and a half thousand fragments of tablets were found at this house. They date to the 17th century BCE (short chronology) (the early part of Samsu-iluna's reign), and the majority of them were students' school exercises. Two other possible "school houses" are located at the site of Ur. The first is a house called No. 7 Quiet Street, where a smaller number of school texts was found in situ and date to the late 18th or early 17th century BCE (short chronology) (reigns of Rim-Sin II or as late as Samsu-iluna year 11). The second is a house called No. 1 Broad Street, where a larger number of school tablets was discovered. Some texts from No. 1 Broad Street may date to as late as Samsu-iluna year 11 (1674 BCE short chronology, 1738 middle chronology). Unfortunately, it is unclear whether this house is the school texts' original place of use. Another Old Babylonian home in which scribal training took place is the house of a man named Ur-Utu, located in the ancient city of Sippar-Amnanum.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The practice of communication by written documents carried by an intermediary from one person or place to another almost certainly dates back nearly to the invention of writing. However, development of formal postal systems occurred much later. The first documented use of an organized courier service for the diffusion of written documents is in Egypt, where Pharaohs used couriers for the diffusion of their decrees in the territory of the State (2400 BC).[PARAGRAPH:2]The first credible claim for the development of a real postal system comes from Ancient Persia but the point of invention remains in question. The best documented claim (Xenophon) attributes the invention to the Persian King Cyrus the Great (550 BC), while other writers credit his successor Darius I of Persia (521 BC). Other sources claim much earlier dates for an Assyrian postal system, with credit given to Hammurabi (1700 BC) and Sargon II (722 BC). Mail may not have been the primary mission of this postal service, however. The role of the system as an intelligence gathering apparatus is well documented, and the service was (later) called angariae, a term that in time turned to indicate a tax system. The Old Testament (Esther, VIII) makes mention of this system: Ahasuerus, king of Medes, used couriers for communicating his decisions.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Persian system worked on stations (called Chapar-Khaneh), where the message carrier (called Chapar) would ride to the next post, whereupon he would swap his horse with a fresh one, for maximum performance and delivery speed. Herodotus described the system in this way: "It is said that as many days as there are in the whole journey, so many are the men and horses that stand along the road, each horse and man at the interval of a day's journey; and these are stayed neither by snow nor rain nor heat nor darkness from accomplishing their appointed course with all speed".[PARAGRAPH:2]The economic growth and political stability under the Mauryan empire (322-185 BC) saw the development of impressive civil infrastructure in ancient India. The Mauryans developed early Indian mail service as well as public wells, rest houses and other facilities for the common public. Common chariots called Dagana were sometimes used as mail chariots in ancient India.[PARAGRAPH:2]In ancient times the kings, emperors, rulers, zamindars or the feudal lords protected their land through the intelligence services of specially trained police or military agencies and courier services to convey and obtain information through runners, messengers and even through pigeons. The chief of the secret service, known as the postmaster, maintained the lines of communication... The people used to send letters to their distant relatives through their friends or neighbors.[PARAGRAPH:2]Early stamps of India were watermarked with an elephant's head. [PARAGRAPH:2]In South India, the Wodeyar dynasty (1399 - 1947) of the Kingdom of Mysore used mail service for espionage purposes thereby acquiring knowledge related to matters that took place at great distances.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 18th century the postal system in India had reached impressive levels of efficiency. According to British national Thomas Broughton, the Maharaja of Jodhpur sent daily offerings of fresh flowers from his capital to Nathadvara (320 km) and they arrived in time for the first religious Darshan at sunrise. Later this system underwent complete modernization when the British Raj established its full control over India. The Post Office Act XVII of 1837 provided that the Governor-General of India in Council had the exclusive right of conveying letters by post for hire within the territories of the East India Company. The mails were available to certain officials without charge, which became a controversial privilege as the years passed. On this basis the Indian Post Office was established on October 1, 1837.[PARAGRAPH:2]China enjoyed postal relay stations since the Han dynasty (206 BC-220 AD). During the Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan, China was integrated into the much larger Örtöö system of the Mongol Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first well documented postal service is that of Rome. Organized at the time of Augustus Caesar (62 BC-AD 14), it may also be the first true mail service. The service was called cursus publicus and was provided with light carriages called rhedÃ¦ with fast horses. Additionally, there was another slower service equipped with two-wheeled carts (birolÃ¦) pulled by oxen. This service was reserved for government correspondence. Another service for citizens was later added.[PARAGRAPH:2]Genghis Khan installed an empire-wide messenger and postal station system named Örtöö within the Mongol Empire. During the Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan, this system also covered the territory of China. Postal stations were used not only for the transmission and delivery of official mail, but were also available for traveling officials, military men, and foreign dignitaries. These stations aided and facilitated the transport of foreign and domestic tribute, and trade in general. By the end of Kublai Khan's rule there were more than 1400 postal stations in China alone, which in turn had at their disposal about 50000 horses, 1400 oxen, 6700 mules, 400 carts, 6000 boats, over 200 dogs and 1150 sheep.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stations were 15 to 40 miles apart and had reliable attendants working for the mail service. Foreign observers, such as Marco Polo have attested to the efficiency of this early postal system.[PARAGRAPH:2]Another important postal service was created in the Islamic world by the caliph Mu'awiyya; the service was called barid, by the name of the towers built to protect the roads by which couriers travelled.[PARAGRAPH:2]Well before the Middle Ages and during them, homing pigeons were used for pigeon post, taking advantage of a singular quality of this bird, which when taken far from its nest is able to find his way home due to a particularly developed sense of orientation. Messages were then tied around the legs of the pigeon, which was freed and could reach his original nest.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mail has been transported by quite a few other methods throughout history, including dogsled, balloon, rocket, mule, pneumatic tubes and even submarine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many religious orders had a private mail service, notably Cistercians ' one connected more than 6,000 abbeys, monasteries and churches. The best organization however was created by the Knights Templar. The newly instituted universities too had their private services, starting from Bologna (1158).[PARAGRAPH:2]Popular illiteracy was accommodated through the service of scribes. Illiterates who needed to communicate dictated their messages to a scribe, another profession now quite generally disappeared.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1505, Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I established a postal system in the Empire, appointing Franz von Thurn und Taxis to run it. The Thurn and Taxis family, then known as Tassis, had operated postal services between Italian city states from 1290 onwards. Following the abolition of the Empire in 1806 the Thurn and Taxis postal system continued as a private organisation, continuing to exist into the postage stamp era before finally being absorbed into the postal system of the new German Empire after 1871.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the United Kingdom, prior to 1840 the postal system was expensive, confusing and seen as corrupt. Letters were paid for by the recipient rather than the sender, and were charged according to the distance the letter had travelled and the number of sheets of paper it contained. If there is one man who can be said to have changed the face of the postal service forever it is Sir Rowland Hill, with his reforms of the postal system based on the concept of penny postage, and his solution of pre payment. In his proposal Hill also called for official pre-printed envelopes and adhesive postage stamps as alternative ways of getting the sender to pay for the postage, at a time when prepayment was optional, which led to the invention of the postage stamp, the Penny Black.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was around this time nationalization and centralization of most postal systems took place. Today, the study of mail systems is known as postal history.[PARAGRAPH:2]The postal system was important in the development of modern transportation. Railroads carried railway post offices. During the 20th century, air mail became the transport of choice for inter-continental mail. Postmen started to utilize mail trucks. The handling of mail became increasingly automated.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Internet came to change the conditions for physical mail. E-mail (and in recent years social networking sites) became a fierce competitor, but online auctions and Internet shopping opened new business opportunities as people often get items bought online through the mail.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A sewer is an artificial conduit (or pipe) or system of conduits used to carry and remove sewage (human liquid waste) and to provide drainage. In the 21st century developed world, sewers are usually pipelines that begin with connecting pipes from buildings to one or more levels of larger underground horizontal mains, which terminate at sewage treatment facilities. Vertical pipes, called manholes, connect the mains to the surface. Sewers are generally gravity powered, though pumps may be used if necessary. [PARAGRAPH:2]The earliest covered sewers uncovered by archaeologists are in the regularly planned cities of the Indus Valley Civilization. In ancient Rome, the Cloaca Maxima, considered a marvel of engineering, disgorged into the Tiber. In medieval European cities, small natural waterways used for carrying off wastewater were eventually covered over and functioned as sewers. London's River Fleet is such a system. Open drains along the center of some streets were known as 'kennels' (= canals, channels).
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A chiefdom is a form of hierarchical political organization in non-industrial societies usually based on kinship, and in which formal leadership is monopolized by the legitimate senior members of select families or 'houses'. These elites form a political-ideological aristocracy relative to the general group.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Unlike traditional monarchies, where rule is hereditary and passed down the family line, under an elective system rulers are chosen by election. Elective systems differ from democracies in that the monarch is generally chosen for life and the right to vote is limited to a small groups of magnates or special members of the aristocracy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Elective systems were prominent in medieval central Europe. In the Holy Roman Empire, the elective system was codified over the centuries to a group of Prince Electors choosing the next Emperor. The Polish king was also elected, first by a small group of nobles, later by the entire noble class. Other European examples include early Scandinavian kings and the Doge of Venice. Outside of Europe, the Mansa of the Mali Empire and the Tlatoani of the Aztec Triple Alliance were selected and confirmed by a privileged council. The selection of the Mongol Great Khan could also be considered an elective monarchy.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A one-party state is a type of state in which one political party has the right to form the government, usually based on the existing constitution. All other parties are either outlawed or allowed to take only a limited and controlled participation in elections. One-party states explain themselves through various methods. Most often, proponents of a one-party state argue that the existence of separate parties runs counter to national unity. Others argue that the one party is the vanguard of the people, and therefore its right to rule cannot be legitimately questioned. The Soviet government argued that multiple parties represented the class struggle, which was absent in Soviet society, and so the Soviet Union only had one party: The Communist Party.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Most one-party states have been ruled either by parties following the ideology of Marxism–Leninism and international solidarity (such as the Soviet Union for most of its existence), or by parties following some type of nationalist or fascist ideology (such as Italy under Benito Mussolini), or by parties that came to power in the wake of independence from colonial rule. One-party systems often arise from decolonization because one party has had an overwhelmingly dominant role in liberation or in independence struggles.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Citizenship describes the legal codification of the relationship between a state and its people. Instead of being just being a subject at the whim of the power of their ruler, the status of citizen comes with certain rights and obligations towards the state. The prime example of citizenship was the Roman Republic. Initially, only inhabitants of Rome could be citizens, which came with access to the Roman legal system, protection from enslavement, and political participation. Over the course of Roman history citizenship was gradually expanded to other populations under Roman rule, which furthered their integration into Roman society.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept of citizenship continued during the Roman Empire and entered the Western legal tradition. During the Middle Ages, citizenship was replaced by serfdom as the dominant form of social relationship, however the practice continued in independent cities. Modern European states, and later almost all states in the world, conferred citizenship to all its peoples for essentially the same reason the Roman Republic did.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Meritocracy is a political philosophy holding that power should be vested in individuals almost exclusively based on ability and talent. Advancement in such a system is based on performance measured through examination and/or demonstrated achievement in the field where it is implemented. According to scholarly consensus, the earliest example of an administrative meritocracy, based on civil service examinations, dates back to Ancient China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept originates, at least by the sixth century BC, when it was advocated by the Chinese philosopher Confucius, who "invented the notion that those who govern should do so because of merit, not of inherited status. This sets in motion the creation of the imperial examinations and bureaucracies open only to those who passed tests."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]As the Qin and Han dynasties developed a meritocratic system in order to maintain power over a large, sprawling empire, it became necessary for the government to maintain a complex network of officials. Prospective officials could come from a rural background and government positions were not restricted to the nobility. Rank was determined by merit, through the civil service examinations, and education became the key for social mobility. After the fall of the Han Dynasty, the nine-rank system was established during the Three Kingdoms period.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Centralism describes a form of political organisation where all administrative decisions are made or controlled by the central government situated in the capital. Centralism stands in contrast to more decentralised forms of government such as feudalism or federalism. Ancient China has long had a tradition of central government, where all decisions were carried out by a central bureaucracy loyal to the Emperor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]In Europe, feudalism meant that the monarch only had limited power over his domains, since it had to be carried out through noble vassals. In the early modern period, European monarchs sought to increase their power by centralising decisions to the royal court. Archetypal for this development was France under Louis XIV, where the nobility was forced to attend the court at Versailles, so the monarch was able to exert control over them. In consequence, the bureaucracy was expanded to implement royal policy across the country. Other European states quickly emulated the success of this French model.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A constitution is a set of fundamental principles or established precedents according to which a state or other organization is governed. These rules together make up, i.e. constitute, what the entity is. When these principles are written down into a single document or set of legal documents, those documents may be said to embody a written constitution; if they are written down in a single comprehensive document, it is said to embody a codified constitution. Some constitutions (such as the constitution of the United Kingdom) are uncodified, but written in numerous fundamental Acts of a legislature, court cases or treaties.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]What is sometimes called the "enlightened constitution" model was developed by philosophers of the Age of Enlightenment such as Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, and John Locke. The model proposed that constitutional governments should be stable, adaptable, accountable, open and should represent the people (i.e., support democracy). The United States Constitution, ratified June 21, 1788, was influenced by the writings of Polybius, Locke, Montesquieu, and others. The document became a benchmark for republicanism and codified constitutions written thereafter.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A traditionalist society is based on oral traditions and long established ways of doing things. Its authority is difficult to question, since no modern figure can easily claim the right to change what was established by the ancestors. This can be a great weakness of the system when times change, but so long as the basic mechanisms of existence remain stable, the tradition-oriented culture gains a strong sense of its own values, and feels powerful ties to the legacy of its own ancestors. As society became more settled, existing customs grew formalized and expanded. Priests and scribes served as guardians of collective social memory by keeping track of longstanding precedents and rituals, often dating back centuries to quasi-legendary founding heroes. Rulers sought to empower themselves by following the rites and policies established by such traditions.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Manorialism was an essential element of feudal society. It was the organizing principle of rural economy that originated in the Roman villa system of the Late Roman Empire, and was widely practiced in medieval western and parts of central Europe. It was slowly replaced by the advent of a money-based market economy and new forms of agrarian contract. Manorialism was characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a Lord of the Manor, supported economically from his own direct landholding in a manor (sometimes called a fief), and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under the jurisdiction of himself and his manorial court. These obligations could be payable in several ways, in labor (the French term corvée is conventionally applied), in kind, or, on rare occasions, in coin.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Individualism is the moral stance, political philosophy, ideology, or social outlook that emphasizes the moral worth of the individual. Individualists promote the exercise of one's goals and desires and so value independence and self-reliance and advocate that interests of the individual should achieve precedence over the state or a social group, while opposing external interference upon one's own interests by society or institutions such as the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Liberalism is the belief in the importance of individual freedom. This belief is widely accepted in the United States, Europe, Australia and other Western nations, and was recognized as an important value by many Western philosophers throughout history, in particular since the Enlightenment.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]While very early societies had a strong state control over the economy, for example in grain storage and distribution, as goods became more complex and trade routes more far reaching, it has become harder for them to exert control over trade. Long distance trade usually took place without state interference by private individuals. For instance, most traders along the silk route organised without any involvement of the involved states. Likewise, states would withdraw from regulating trade and let it pass freely throughout their borders.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Regulated Trade describes a government trade policy that seeks to influence foreign trade to the benefit of its national industries. With the Ming dynasty, China started to close off its economy to foreign trade, and likewise Japan forbade interaction with foreign merchants. Besides protecting local craftsmen, this was also meant to keep out dangerous ideas from abroad. In Europe, increasing trade regulation coincided with colonialism. This particular form of regulated trade, Mercantilism, was focused on importing raw goods from the colonies to produce manufactured goods at the exclusion of foreign economies.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Free Enterprise (also referred to as Laissez-faire economic policy) is an economic system in which transactions between private parties are free from government intervention such as regulation, privileges, tariffs, and subsidies. The doctrine of laissez-faire became an integral part of nineteenth-century European liberalism. Just as liberals supported freedom of thought in the intellectual sphere, so were they equally prepared to champion the principles of free trade and free competition in the sphere of economics. The state was to be merely a passive policeman, protecting private property and administering justice, but not interfering with the affairs of its citizens. Businessmen, and particularly British industrialists, were quick to associate these principles with their own economic interests.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Animism is the religious belief that objects, places, and creatures all possess a distinct spiritual essence. Potentially, animism perceives all things—animals, plants, rocks, rivers, weather systems, human handiwork, and perhaps even words—as animated and alive.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Animism is the oldest known type of belief system in the world that even predates paganism. It is still practiced in a variety of forms in many traditional societies. Animism is used in the anthropology of religion as a term for the belief system of many indigenous tribal peoples, especially in contrast to the relatively more recent development of organized religions. Although each culture has its own different mythologies and rituals, "animism" is said to describe the most common, foundational thread of indigenous peoples' "spiritual" or "supernatural" perspectives. The animistic perspective is so widely held and inherent to most animistic indigenous peoples that they often do not even have a word in their languages that corresponds to "animism", or even "religion".
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Deification (also called Apotheosis) describes raising a human to the status of a God, either posthumously or during their lifetime. These deified rulers used their divine status to cement their authority, and in turn had the duty to secure the support of the gods for their populace. The most well-known examples of deified rulers are the Egyptian pharaohs. Likewise, Chinese emperors justified their rule by having the Mandate of Heaven. Even though the Greco-Roman world had a more republican outlook on government, the Greeks had a tradition of deifying heroes. With the onset of the Roman Empire, emperors were venerated as gods. A similar tradition existed in many Hindu kingdoms in India, Indochina and Indonesia.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Clergy refers to a hierarchical and institutional structure within a religion. In particular, the clergy itself is the religious leadership present in various organised religions. The names of members of the clergy vary from religion to religion, but their duties are often similar: interpreting existing religious texts and traditions, resolving open religious questions, and administering the religious organisation itself. Since religion is often an important aspect in the legitimisation of secular power, clergy can often be involved in worldly government or even hold such power itself. The various Christian denominations are the most prominent examples here. The leader of Catholic Christianity, the Pope, once exercised control over much of Italy, and bishops and monastic orders used to rule regions of Europe without any dependence on a higher monarch.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Monasticism or monkhood is a religious way of life in which one renounces worldly pursuits to devote oneself fully to spiritual work. Monastic life plays an important role in many Christian churches, especially in the Catholic and Orthodox traditions. Similar forms of religious life also exist in other faiths, most notably in Buddhism, but also in Hinduism and Jainism, although the expressions differ considerably. A religion with focus on monasticism generally is less organised, and concentrated on several monastic orders instead of a central hierarchical order.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Tolerance is the acceptance of an action, object, or person which one dislikes or disagrees with, where one is in a position to disallow it but chooses not to. It has also been defined as "to bear or endure" or "to nourish, sustain or preserve" or as "a fair, objective, and permissive attitude toward those whose opinions, beliefs, practices, racial or ethnic origins, etc., differ from one's own; freedom from bigotry" too. Toleration may signify "no more than forbearance and the permission given by the adherents of a dominant religion for other religions to exist, even though the latter are looked on with disapproval as inferior, mistaken, or harmful."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]There is only one verb to tolerate and one adjective tolerant, but the two nouns tolerance and toleration have evolved slightly different meanings. Tolerance is a state of mind that implies non-judgmental acceptance of different lifestyles or beliefs, whereas toleration indicates the act of putting up with something that one disapproves of. Historically, most incidents and writings pertaining to toleration involve the status of minority and dissenting viewpoints in relation to a dominant state religion.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sovereignty is the full right and power of a governing body over itself, without any interference from outside sources or bodies. A civilisation that has lost the power to assert its own sovereignty has essentially been destroyed or at least subordinated. On the other hand, Sovereignty itself implies that the civilisation exerts no influence over anything else than its core territory.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A civilisation that is focused on Conquest perpetuates itself through constant military expansion. This is generally the case for societies that inhabit territory insufficient to support it and that are forced to expand to meet their needs. However, expansionism can also be the cultural norms: societies that value military prowess require constant warfare for new generations of leaders to prove their worth. While such a culture can make a civilisation quite adept at warfare, it also leads to economies that are heavily reliant on the influx of wealth brought about by looting and tribute. In consequence, they are at risk of collapse as soon they suffer their first military setback. This can be seen for example by the rapid military expansion of Alexander's Macedon Empire or the Mongol Empire under the Great Khans.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Many Asian civilisations regarded tributary relationships as being more desirable than outright control. Tribute would pacify surrounding powers as well as provide additional income, while requiring no direct military control over defeated enemies. This was especially useful in the relationship with far away powers or those which inhabited rough terrain. Various Chinese dynasties throughout history sought to receive tribute both from the nomads to its north as well as states in South East Asia. The Mongol Empire used the same practice, for example for the fractured states in medieval Russia. In South East Asia, the Mandala system was almost entirely built around tributaries, where important centers such as Ayutthaya, Java or Angkor only kept informal control over their sphere of influence.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Isolationist civilisations have deliberately closed themselves off from the outside world. The reasons for doing so can vary. Sometimes, the desire is to exclude outside merchants from competing with the local economy, but another important reason is to keep out foreign ideas and influences that could threaten the existing social order or government. China stopped its naval program during the Ming dynasty and refused requests for foreign trade, considering itself entirely self-sufficient. In Japan during the Tokugawa Shogunate, the introduction of Western technology and Christianity was considered a threat to population's loyalty to the shogun, and the country completely shut itself off from the world. Joseon Korea similarly was known as the Hermit Kingdom.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the early modern era, European naval powers began to discover and colonise various parts of the world, beginning in the Americas, but subsequently also Asia and Africa. While the initial process happened without much direction, colonialism quickly became state policy for these civilisations. Under colonialism, vast amounts of wealth were extracted from colonised regions under the exploitation of their native populations to the benefits of their European homelands. Colonialism led to the displacements of large population groups, especially under the transatlantic slave trade, and introduced new plants and animals to parts of the world that had never seen them before. International prestige was as important to colonialism as its economic benefits, and colonial powers would often get into conflicts over their colonies and involve local neighbours.
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: Limited Resource Effects
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [H1]Limited Resource Effects[\H1][NEWLINE]In Dawn of Civilization, the number of cities a resource can provide health or happiness to is limited. For example, each instance of the Silk only provides happiness to three cities in your empire. It is therefore necessary to secure multiple instances of a resource to supply all cities in a large empire. If a civilization does not control enough instances of a resource to supply all of its cities, the effect is applied to more cultured cities first. In consequence, it is advisable for large empires to focus on obtaining multiple instances of the same resource, while small civilizations should focus on a diverse set of resources. Note that these new rules only apply to health or happiness directly from resources. Health and happiness from resources with buildings remain unaffected, as well as all other resource effects (e.g. enabling units or providing power).
TEXT.German: No Translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Temples in ancient Egypt were seen as the houses of gods to whom they were dedicated (or pharaoh whom they commemorated). Their architecture varied a lot over the large time span of Egyptian civilization, from small shrines in the Predynastic Period to the large complexes in the New Kingdom. Their most sacred part of an Egyptian temple was an inner sanctuary that housed the god's image. Access to the sanctuary was typically restricted to the priestly caste, but the rest of the temple was an important place in the daily life of Egyptian commoners. Many temples have survived to the current day and are now touristic assets for modern Egypt, as well as important archaeological sources for Egyptologists.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les temples de l'Égypte ancienne étaient vus comme les demeures des dieux auxquels ils étaient dédiés (ou des pharaons qu'ils commémoraient). Leur architecture a beaucoup varié à travers la longue histoire de la civilisation égyptienne, des petits lieux de culte de l'époque prédynastique aux grands complexes du Nouvel Empire. La partie la plus sacrée d'un temple égyptien était le sanctuaire. On y conservait une idole du dieu. L'accès au sanctuaire était réservé au clergé, mais le reste du temple n'en constituait pas moins un lieu important dans la vie de la populace égyptienne. De nombreux temples ont survécu et plusieurs sont désormais des attractions touristiques importantes, lorsqu'ils ne jouent pas le rôle de sources archéologiques pour les égyptologues.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ancestor worship plays a large role in Chinese folk religion, also sometimes called "Shendao" or "Way of the Gods". Temples dedicated to deified ancestors are common, and are closely linked to the emphasis that Chinese culture puts on filial piety. Since Chinese folk religion is complex and diverse, many other types of temples exist in China, including some dedicated to Chinese gods and past emperors. These exist alongside Confucian, Taoist, and Buddhist places of worship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le culte des ancêtres joue un large rôle dans la religion traditionnelle chinoise, aussi appelée shenisme. Les temples consacrés aux ancêtres déifiés sont courants et sont à rapprocher de l'importance qu'accorde la culture chinoise à la piété filiale. Étant donné la complexité et la diversité de la religion traditionnelle, de nombreux autres types de temples existent en Chine, comme ceux qui sont dédiés aux dieux et aux empereurs. Ils existent aux côtés de lieux de culte confucéens, taoïstes et bouddhistes.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Vedism refers to the historical religion of the Indo-Aryans of northern India. Descended from proto-Indo-Iranian religion, itself related to proto-Indo-European religion, Vedism may also have been influenced by the religion of the Indus Valley Civilization. At the end of the Vedic period, around 500 BC, Hinduism emerged from Vedism while also diverging significantly from it. Vedism is known primarily through texts rather than archaeology, and therefore knowledge of its places of worship is scant.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le védisme est la religion historique des Indo-Aryens de l'Inde du Nord. Il descend de la religion proto-indo-iranienne, elle-même apparentée à la religion proto-indo-européenne, mais il pourrait aussi avoir été influencé par la civilisation de la vallée de l'Indus. À la fin de la période védique, vers 500 avant J.-C., l'hindouisme est né du védisme tout en s'en distinguant. Le védisme est connu davantage par des textes que par l'archéologie, aussi sait-on peut de choses quant à ses lieux de culte.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]With their colonnades and rectangular floor plans, temples are perhaps the most recognizable form of ancient Greek culture. Built to house the statue of a deity, commonly one of the twelve Olympians, a Greek temple did not typically function as a meeting place. Instead, it was used to store votive offerings, while ceremonies and sacrifices were performed outside. The Greeks exercised a large degree of cultural influence on Rome, who not only adapted many of the Greek gods and deities into their own, but also developed similar temple architecture. As a result of Greco-Roman influence, columned temples have been built widely across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Two of the best known examples are the Parthenon in Athens and the Pantheon in Rome, both of which were later converted to churches, a fate that befell many other Greco-Roman temples.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Avec leurs colonnades et leur configuration rectangulaire, les temples sont peut-être la composante la plus typique de la culture grecque ancienne. Un temple grec était bâti pour loger la statue d'une divinité, souvent l'un des douze dieux olympiens. Il ne servait généralement pas de lieu de réunion; on y entreposait plutôt des offres votives, tandis que les cérémonies et les sacrifices avaient lieu dehors. Les Grecs ont exercé une grande influence culturelle sur Rome, qui a non seulement adapté les dieux grecs pour en faire les leurs, mais aussi développé une architecture religieuse similaire. Étant donné l'influence gréco-romaine sur le monde méditerranéen, des temples à colonnes ont été construits dans une grande partie de l'Europe, de l'Afrique du Nord et du Moyen-Orient. Deux des exemples les plus connus sont le Parthénon à Athènes et le Panthéon à Rome, tous deux convertis en églises à l'ère chrétienne. De nombreux autres temples gréco-romains ont subi le même sort.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the ancient Levant, "Baal" was a title meaning "lord" and was given to several gods of the Ancient Canaanite religion. For instance, the main god of the city of Carthage was Baal Hammon. Details of Phoenician religious organization and buildings are scarce, although it is known that Carthage had a well-organized caste of priests. The city was also reported by several Roman writers as having practiced child sacrifice for Baal Hammon, but the issue is still contentious among historians due to the poorness of archeological sources and the partisan nature of the literary ones.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans le Proche-Orient ancien, le mot "Baal" était un titre honorifique signifiant "seigneur", mais prenant aussi un sens religieux lorsqu'il était donné aux dieux de la religion cananéenne et phénicienne. Par exemple, le dieu principal de Carthage était Baal Hammon. Peu de détails sont connus au sujet de la religion phénicienne. On sait toutefois que les Carthaginois avaient une caste de prêtre bien organisée. De nombreux auteurs romains ont affirmé que la cité pratiquait le sacrifice d'enfants pour Baal Hammon, mais la pauvreté des sources archéologiques et la nature partisane des sources littéraires ne permettent pas de trancher.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Atua are the gods and spirits of the Polynesians. Across the Pacific Ocean, Polynesian religious activity mostly took place at communal areas called mala'e or marae. In Hawaii, native temples are known as "heiau" and were built for a variety of deities and purposes.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les atua sont les dieux et les esprits des peuples polynésiens. À travers l'océan Pacifique, l'activité religieuse se concentrait dans des lieux publics appelés mala'e ou marae. À Hawaï, les temples des indigènes sont appelés "heiau" et furent construits pour toutes sortes de divinités et d'usages.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mazdaism, named for its central deity Ahura Mazda, refers to the religion of the Iranian people prior to the reforms of Zoroaster. Mazdaism is thought to have resembled Vedism, the ancient religion of India, but little information about it is available, including anything about its places of worship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le mazdéisme, nommé d'après sa divinité centrale Ahura Mazda, est la religion du peuple iranien avant les réformes de Zoroastre. On pense que le mazdéisme ressemblait au védisme, la religion de l'Inde antique, mais les sources sur le sujet sont rares, y compris quant aux lieux de culte.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The various civilizations of Mesoamerica were the most prolific builders of step pyramids. Such constructions typically included a temple at the top, and were in many cases periodically expanded in a layerwise fashion. Step pyramids exist in a diversity of architectural styles, but common elements show the cultural influence that the Mesoamerican peoples had on one another. Notable examples include the Templo Mayor of Tenochtitlan, the Pyramids of the Sun and of the Moon in Teotihuacan, the Temple of Kukulkan in Chichen Itza, and the Great Pyramid of Cholula, which is the largest pyramid known to exist in the world.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les civilisations de la Mésoamérique précolombienne furent de grands bâtisseurs de pyramides à degrés. Ces constructions étaient généralement dotées d'un temple à leur sommet, et étaient dans plusieurs cas agrandies périodiquement en ajoutant des couches. Si les pyramides mésoaméricaines présentent une grande diversité styles architecturaux, elles comportent aussi des éléments communs qui témoignent de l'influence culturelle que les peuples exerçaient les uns sur les autres. Citons en exemple le Templo Mayor de Tenochtitlan, les Pyramides du Soleil et de la Lune de Teotihuacan, la Pyramide de Kukulcán à Chichén Itzá, ainsi que la Grande Pyramide de Cholula, qui est la pyramide la plus volumineuse du monde.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Shinto, shrines are places of worship that house one or more kami, a concept that can be translated as "spirit" or "essence". Many Shinto shrines have a torii, a traditional gate that marks the transition between the mundane and the sacred. Estimates put the number of Shinto shrines in Japan around 100,000. With its "floating" torii, Itsukushima Shrine is perhaps the most well-known.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans le shintoïsme, un sanctuaire est un lieu de culte où l'on vénère un (ou plusieurs) kami, soit une divinité, un esprit ou un élément de la nature. De nombreux sanctuaires shinto comportent un portail traditionnel appelé torii. Le torii marque la transition entre le monde profane et l'enceinte sacrée. Il existerait environ 100 000 sanctuaires shinto au Japon. Le plus célèbre d'entre eux, avec son torii "flottant", est sans doute celui d'Itsukushima.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]In ancient Norse religion, rites were performed both in the outdoors and at temples called hofs. The most famous hof in the Middle Ages was the temple at Old Uppsala, Sweden, and was described by the 11th century chronicler Adam of Bremen as being made of gold and containing statues of Thor, Odin, and Freyr. With the revival of Norse paganism under the name "Asatru", some modern buildings have been dedicated as hofs, and a new pagan temple is under construction in Iceland as of 2018.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans la religion nordique ancienne, les rites avaient lieu à la fois en plein air et au sein de temples appelés en vieux norrois "hofs". Le hof le plus célèbre du Moyen Âge était le temple d'Uppsala, en Suède, décrit par le chroniqueur du 11e siècle Adam de Brême comme paré d'or et renfermant les statues de Thor, d'Odin et de Freyr. Depuis la résurgence du paganisme nordique sous le nom d'"Ásatrú", certains bâtiments modernes se sont vus consacrés comme hofs, et un nouveau temple païen est en construction en Islande en 2018.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]A nemeton is a sacred place of the ancient Celtic religion. Nemeta are typically thought of as outdoor spaces in which druids would perform ceremonies. However, there is evidence that nemeta took a variety of forms, including ritual enclosures, shrines, and temples. Several toponyms in modern Europe derive from the word "nemeton".
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un nemeton est un lieu sacré de la religion celte ancienne. Les nemetons sont généralement perçus comme des espaces en plein air où les druides dirigeaient des cérémonies. Toutefois, il pouvait s'agir d'enclos rituels, de sanctuaires ou de temples. Le mot "nemeton" a survécu dans la toponymie de nombreux lieux européens.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Perun, whose main attributes are thunder and lightning, is the highest god of Slavic polytheism. The most important shrine dedicated to Perun was found on the peninsula of Peryn, near the city of Veliky Novgorod, which was an major religious center in the Early Middle Ages. Various other temples of Slavic paganism existed, but most were destroyed and replaced by churches during the Christianization of the Slavs.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Péroun, dont les attributs principaux sont la foudre et le tonnerre, est le dieu prédominant du polythéisme slave. Le sanctuaire le plus important qui lui est consacré se trouve sur la péninsule de Peryn, près de Novgorod, qui fut un centre religieux d'importance durant le haut Moyen Âge. De nombreux autres temples païens ont existé, mais ils furent en général détruits et remplacés par des églises au moment de la christianisation des Slaves.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Traditional African religions are highly diverse. The religious tradition of the Yoruba people, originally from Nigeria and the surrounding countries, has spread around the world due to the Atlantic slave trade. Its sacred places include the cities of Ife and Oyo, and the grove of Osun-Osogbo.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Il existe une grande diversité de religions traditionnelles africaines. Celle du peuple yoruba, originaire du Nigeria et des pays environnants, s'est propagée à travers le monde via le commerce transatlantique des esclaves. Ses lieux sacrés comprennent les villes d'Ife et d'Oyo ainsi que la forêt d'Osun-Osogbo.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Among the deities worshipped by the Inca, the sun god, Inti, was arguably the most prominent. Each major province of the Inca Empire had a temple dedicated to Inti. The most important one was Coricancha, meaning "gold enclosure". True to its name, it was opulently decorated with gold until the Spanish conquerors pillaged and destroyed it. Its foundations still exist beneath the Santo Domingo convent in Cuzco.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Parmi les divinités vénérées par les Incas, le dieu-soleil Inti est possiblement le plus important. Chaque province de l'Empire inca était dotée d'un temple dédié à Inti. Le plus sacré était le Coricancha, dont le nom signifie "enceinte de l'or". Richement paré d'or, il fut pillé et détruit par les conquistadors espagnols. Ses fondations existent encore sous le couvent Santo Domingo à Cuzco.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]An obo, also spelled ovoo or oboo, is a stone and wood heap used as an altar or shrine in Mongolian shamanism, which is part of the larger Tengrist religious tradition. Obos are often found in high places such as mountaintops. While they can be very simple, some have evolved to become elaborate structures akin to temples.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un ovoo, ou obo, est un amas de pierre et de bois utilisé comme autel ou comme sanctuaire par les adeptes du chamanisme mongol, qui est l'une des manifestations du tengrisme. Les ovoos sont souvent construits en hauteur, par exemple au sommet des montagnes. Certains sont devenus des structures élaborées comparables à des temples.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Hubal was an important god worshipped in Arabia in pre-Islamic times. Hubal's consort was Manat, one of the three main goddesses of Arabian polytheistic religion. The Kaaba, in Mecca, later to become the holiest site in Islam, was initially a shrine dedicated to Hubal and contained an idol of the god, among others.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Houbal était un dieu important de l'Arabie préislamique. Il était lié à Manât, l'une des trois grandes déesses du polythéisme arabe. À La Mecque, la Kaaba, qui deviendrait plus tard le lieu le plus sacré de l'Islam, était à l'origine un sanctuaire dédié notamment à Houbal, dont elle renfermait une idole.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]Before the spread of Christianity to Ethiopia in the 4th century, religion in the Aksumite Empire was closely related to the Semitic polytheism of Southern Arabia. It has been suggested that its principal god was Astar, a male deity equivalent to Mesopotamian goddess Ishtar.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Avant l'arrivée du christianisme en Éthiopie, au 4e siècle, la religion de l'Empire aksoumite était proche du polythéisme sémitique d'Arabie méridionale. Sa divinité principale pourrait avoir été Astar, un équivalent masculin de la déesse mésopotamienne Ishtar.
TEXT.German: [TAB]No translation

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Oromo are a cultural group that has lived for centuries in the area today known as Ethiopia. Historically defined by their unique democratic caste system, each age group within the Oromo was assigned to a specific position within society. As an Oromo citizen aged, they progressed through these age groupings to assume different positions within the Oromo hierarchy. Young men between the ages of sixteen and thirty-two were traditionally assigned to the warrior caste. Young Oromo men were not fully considered men until they had killed a man or, in times of peace, a fierce animal.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bravery in combat was paramount among Oromo culture, and many of their customs required retelling the histories of great warriors. These storytelling traditions reinforced the warlike attitude prevalent throughout Oromo society. In addition to this focus on military achievement, the Oromo also heavily stressed the importance of harmony and peace amongst their people. This unifying ideal ensured that if any outside military force attacked an Oromo tribe, they could expect a united Oromo counterattack.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Oromo sont un groupe culturel qui vit pendant des siècles dans la région de l'Ethiopie contemporaine. Dotés d'un système de caste démocratique unique en son genre, chaque groupe d'âge est assigné à un poste spécifique au sein de la société. Au fil des ans, les citoyens Oromo progressent à travers ces groupes pour assumer différentes positions au sein de la hiérarchie Oromo. Les hommes âgés de seize à trente-deux ans sont traditionnellement associés à la caste des guerriers. Les jeunes Oromo ne sont pas considérés adultes avant d'avoir tué un homme ou, en temps de paix, un animal sauvage.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le courage au combat est extrêmement important dans la culture Oromo, et leurs rituels accordent une place majeure aux légendes des grands guerriers. Ces histoires renforcent le caractère belliqueux de la société Oromo. En plus de cet intérêt pour les exploits militaires, les Oromo insistent également sur l'importance de l'harmonie et de la paix parmi leur peuple. En cas d'attaque étrangère, cette notion d'unité garantit que les Oromo peuvent se rassembler pour affronter l'ennemi.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Oromo bilden eine kulturelle Gruppe, die seit Jahrhunderten in dem heute als Äthiopien bekannten Gebiet lebt. Sie definieren sich historisch durch ihr einzigartiges demokratisches Kastensystem, das jeder Altersgruppe innerhalb der Oromo eine bestimmte gesellschaftliche Position zuweist. Mit zunehmendem Alter durchlief jeder Oromo-Bürger diese Altersgruppen und hatte innerhalb der Oromo-Hierarchie verschiedene Positionen inne. Junge Männer zwischen sechzehn und zweiunddreißig Jahren wurden traditionell der Kriegerkaste zugeteilt. Junge Oromo galten erst als Mann, wenn sie einen anderen Mann oder in Friedenszeiten ein gefährliches Tier getötet hatten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mut im Kampf war in der Oromo-Kultur das höchste Gut, und viele ihrer Bräuche verlangten, dass die Geschichten großer Krieger wieder und wieder erzählt wurden. Diese Erzähltradition verstärkte noch die kriegerischen Sitten, die kennzeichnend für die Gesellschaft der Oromo waren. Außer kriegerischen Leistungen betonten die Oromo ebenfalls sehr stark die Bedeutung von Harmonie und Frieden unter den eigenen Leuten. Dieses Ideal der Einheit sorgte dafür, dass jede auswärtige Militärmacht, die einen Stamm der Oromo angriff, mit einem Gegenangriff aller Oromo rechnen musste.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli Oromo sono un gruppo culturale che ha vissuto per secoli nella zona conosciuta oggi come Etiopia. Storicamente definiti dal loro singolare sistema democratico a caste, a ogni gruppo d'età all'interno degli Oromo era assegnata una specifica posizione all'interno della società. Con l'avanzare dell'età una persona progrediva attraverso le diverse posizioni nella gerarchia degli Oromo. I giovani uomini con un'età compresa fra i 16 e i 32 anni erano tradizionalmente assegnati alla casta dei guerrieri. I giovani non venivano considerati veramente uomini fino a quando non avevano ucciso un altro uomo o, in tempi di pace, un animale feroce.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il coraggio in combattimento è fondamentale nella cultura degli Oromo, e molte delle loro tradizioni prevedono il racconto della storia di grandi guerrieri. Tali tradizioni rinforzarono l'atteggiamento bellicoso prevalente nella società degli Oromo. Oltre all'attenzione ai risultati militari, gli Oromo davano anche molta importanza all'armonia e alla pace all'interno del loro popolo. Questo ideale di unificazione fece in modo che, se una forza militare esterna avesse attaccato una tribù Oromo, avrebbe subito un contrattacco da parte di tutti.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los oromo son un grupo cultural que ha vivido siglos en la zona conocida actualmente como Etiopía. Caracterizados históricamente por un sistema democrático de castas, cada grupo de edad tenía un papel específico asignado en el seno de la sociedad. A medida que los oromo envejecían, iban progresando por las diferentes categorías sociales hasta asumir posiciones en el seno de la jerarquía. Tradicionalmente, los jóvenes de dieciséis a treinta y dos años se englobaban en la casta de los guerreros. A los jóvenes oromo no se les consideraba hombres hasta que habían matado un hombre o, en tiempos de paz, una fiera salvaje.[PARAGRAPH:1]En su cultura, la bravura en combate tenía una importancia capital, y la recreación oral de las hazañas de grandes guerreros desempeñaba un gran papel en sus tradiciones. Estas tradiciones narrativas reforzaban la actitud belicosa que transpiraba su sociedad. Además de la importancia de lo militar, los oromo también concedían enorme importancia a la armonía y la paz social. Este ideal unificador garantizaba que, si una fuerza externa atacaba a los oromo, se encontrase con un contraataque coordinado.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A man of war is an armed naval vessel. The term often refers to ship armed with cannon and propelled primarily by sails as opposed to a galley propelled primarily by oars. The man of war was developed in the Mediterranean in the 15th century from earlier roundships with the addition of a second mast to form the carrack. The 16th century saw the carrack evolve into the galleon and then the ship of the line.[PARAGRAPH:1]A first-rate man of war, such as the HMS Victory was armed with 100 or more guns (as many as 120). The 90-gun HMS Coronation was a second-rate man of war. A seventy-four, a common ship carrying 74 guns, was a third-rate man of war. A sixth-rate man of war carried only 20 guns. First and second-rate men of war had three gun decks. It took over 2,000 oak and elm trees to build a second-rate man of war.

TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A man of war is an armed naval vessel. The term often refers to ship armed with cannon and propelled primarily by sails as opposed to a galley propelled primarily by oars. The man of war was developed in the Mediterranean in the 15th century from earlier roundships with the addition of a second mast to form the carrack. The 16th century saw the carrack evolve into the galleon and then the ship of the line.[PARAGRAPH:1]A first-rate man of war, such as the HMS Victory was armed with 100 or more guns (as many as 120). The 90-gun HMS Coronation was a second-rate man of war. A seventy-four, a common ship carrying 74 guns, was a third-rate man of war. A sixth-rate man of war carried only 20 guns. First and second-rate men of war had three gun decks. It took over 2,000 oak and elm trees to build a second-rate man of war.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Balestrieri were a famous military formation both in the defence of Genoa and as mercenaries for other Italian and European powers during the Middle Ages. Fighting on both land and in naval battles, they were outfitted with a dagger, light metal helmet, gorget and a large shield called a "pavese" which protected them while loading the crossbow. The presence of balestieri companies on the battlefield was highly feared due to the efficiency of their weapons and their organization, and even often enough to lead an opponent to alter his battle plans. The balestrieri remained feared and respected military formations into the late 16th century even after the introduction of black powder weapons into Europe.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The ballista (Latin, from Greek ballistra and that from ballo, "throw"), plural ballistae, was an ancient missile weapon which launched a large projectile at a distant target.[PARAGRAPH:1]Developed from earlier Greek weapons, it relied upon different mechanics, using two levers with torsion springs instead of a prod, the springs consisting of several loops of twisted skeins. Early versions ejected heavy darts or spherical stone projectiles of various sizes for siege warfare. It developed into a smaller sniper weapon, the Scorpio, and possibly the polybolos.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the absorption of the Ancient Greek city-states into the Roman Republic in 146 BC, the highly advanced Greek technology began to spread across many areas of Roman influence. This included the hugely advantageous military advances the Greeks had made (most notably by Dionysus of Syracuse), as well as all the scientific, mathematical, political and artistic developments.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Romans 'inherited' the torsion powered Ballista, which had by now spread to several cities around the Mediterranean, all of which became Roman spoils of war in time, including one from Pergamum, which was depicted among a pile of 'trophy' weapons in relief on a balustrade.[PARAGRAPH:1]The torsion ballista, developed by Alexander, was a far more complicated weapon than its predecessor and the Romans developed it even further, especially into much smaller versions, that could easily be carried.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The "Hetairoi" (Companions) were Alexander's elite cavalry and the primary offensive arm of his army. A master of cavalry tactics, Alexander would hold them back during the opening part of the battle, committing them at the decisive point to charge the shaken foe, often leading the attack himself. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Alexander's father, Philip of Macedon, created the Companions, who were originally his closest retainers, picked from the Macedonian nobility. As their numbers rose, additional young noblemen were recruited from Thessaly and other parts of the Greek world. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]The Companions were organized into "ilai" (wings) of about 200 men, under the command of close personal friends of the king. They generally wore the usual Boeotian helmet with plumes out the top, a dyed cloak and cuirass. Underneath, they wore linen or leather corslets reinforced with metal scales. They carried long thrusting spears and a short sword; few carried shields unless afoot. Occasionally, Alexander armed them with javelins for specific battles. Their mounts were the best that Greece had to offer - short, sturdy animals trained for war. The horses were partially armored, likely with leather skirts over their flanks and rumps. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]The legends of Alexander's Companions have grown with the telling over the centuries. Though their prowess has undoubtedly been exaggerated, it cannot be denied that they played a significant role in victorious battles such as Issus and Chaeronea. And their loyalty was never questioned. For the next several centuries, elite cavalry of many ancient kingdoms would take the Companions as their ideal model.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les "Hetairoi" (compagnons) constituent la cavalerie d'élite d'Alexandre et la première force offensive de son armée. Passé maître en tactiques de cavaleries, Alexandre les retient durant le prologue de la bataille, ne les lançant à l'attaque qu'à l'instant décisif pour charger sur l'ennemi en déroute, le plus souvent menant lui-même l'assaut. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]C'est le père d'Alexandre, Philippe II de Macédoine, crée les compagnons qui regroupent ses connaissances les plus proches, issues de la noblesse de Macédoine. A mesure que leur nombre augmente, de jeunes nobles sont recrutés en Thessalie ou dans d'autres régions de Grèce. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Les compagnons sont organisés en "ilai" (ailes) d'environ 200 hommes placés sous le commandement d'un ami personnel du roi. Ils portent en général le casque Béotien surmonté d'un plumet, une cape teinte et d'un plastron. Dessous, ils sont vêtus d'une cuirasse en lin ou en cuir renforcée de plaques de métal. Ils portent de longues lances et une épée courte. Peu d'entre eux portent un bouclier à moins d'être à pieds. Occasionnellement, Alexandre les équipe de javelots pour des batailles spécifiques. Leurs montures sont ce que la Grèce a de mieux à offrir en la matière : des animaux petits mais puissants, taillés pour le combat. Leurs chevaux sont partiellement protégés, le plus souvent avec des pans de cuir posés sur leurs flancs et leur croupe. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Les légendes concernant les compagnons d'Alexandre ont enflé au fil des siècles. Même si leurs prouesses sont sans aucun doute exagérées, il est indéniable qu'ils ont joué un rôle décisif dans l'obtention de la victoire lors de batailles telles que Chéronée ou Issos. De plus, leur loyauté est sans faille. Durant les nombreux siècles qui suivent, les troupes de cavalerie d'élite considèrent les Compagnons comme leur modèle idéal.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die "Hetairoi" (Begleitreiter) dienten in Alexanders Heer als Elitekavallerie und Hauptoffensivregiment. Als Meister der Kavallerietaktiken hielt Alexander sie in der Anfangsphase einer Schlacht normalerweise zurück und setzte sie erst am entscheidenden Punkt des Gefechts gegen den bereits angeschlagenen Feind ein, wobei er häufig selbst die Führung übernahm. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Die von Alexanders Vater, Philipp II. von Makedonien begründete Begleitkavallerie, deren Mitglieder makedonischen Adelshäusern entstammten, diente ursprünglich als direkte Vorhut des Königs und wurde durch die Rekrutierung weiterer junger Adliger aus Thessalien und anderen Teilen der griechischen Welt stetig erweitert. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Alexanders Begleitkavallerie war in "Ilai" (Flügel) von je etwa 200 Mann organisiert, die unter dem Kommando enger persönlicher Freunde des Königs standen. Sie waren normalerweise mit böotischen, federbesetzten Helmen, einem gefärbten Umhang und einem Brustharnisch bekleidet. Darunter trugen sie mit Metallschuppen verstärkte Brust- und Rückenpanzer aus Leinen oder Leder. Bewaffnet waren sie mit Wurfspeeren und einem Kurzschwert, einige waren außerdem mit Schilden ausgerüstet, es sei denn, sie waren zu Fuß unterwegs. Gelegentlich stattete Alexander seine Begleitkavalleristen für bestimmte Gefechte auch mit Wurfspießen aus. Ihre Pferde gehörten zu den besten Reittieren, die in Griechenland zu finden waren - kleine, robuste Tiere, die speziell für den Einsatz auf dem Schlachtfeld ausgebildet waren. Sie waren zum Teil mit Lederüberwürfen ausgestattet, welche die Flanken und das Hinterteil schützten. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Im Laufe der Jahrhunderte rankten sich immer mehr Legenden um Alexanders Begleitkavallerie. Hierbei wurde im Hinblick auf ihre Überlegenheit sicherlich enorm übertrieben, unzweifelhaft ist allerdings, dass sie bedeutende Beiträge für den siegreichen Ausgang diverser Schlachten leisteten, wie zum Beispiel bei Issos und Chaironeia. Und auch ihre Loyalität steht außer Zweifel. In den folgenden Jahrhunderten wurden in vielen Königreichen der Antike Elitekavallerien errichte, die sich am Vorbild der Begleitkavallerie orientierten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli "Hetairoi" (cavalleria di supporto) costituivano la cavalleria d'élite di Alessandro e il primo braccio offensivo del suo esercito. Maestro nelle tattiche di cavalleria, Alessandro li manteneva lontani dal conflitto nella prima parte della battaglia, attendendo il momento buono per caricare il nemico ormai scosso, spesso conducendo l'attacco personalmente. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Fu il padre di Alessandro, Filippo il Macedone, a creare la cavalleria di supporto, che inizialmente era composta dai suoi più fedeli seguaci scelti tra i nobili macedoni. Quando fu necessario aumentarne il numero, vennero reclutati anche giovani nobili dalla Tessaglia e da altre parti del mondo greco. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]La cavalleria di supporto era organizzata in "ilai" (ali), composte da circa 200 uomini sotto il comando di amici stretti del re. In genere, essi indossavano il classico elmo piumato, un mantello colorato e la corazza; sotto, indossavano corsetti di lino o cuoio rinforzati con piastre di metallo; erano armati con lunghe lance e spade corte e alcuni utilizzavano gli scudi quando si trovavano a piedi. Occasionalmente Alessandro li dotava di giavellotti da impiegare in battaglie specifiche. Le loro cavalcature erano le migliori di tutta la Grecia, animali vigorosi addestrati per la guerra. Anche i cavalli erano parzialmente corazzati con protezioni di cuoio sulla groppa e sui fianchi. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]La leggenda intorno alla cavalleria di Alessandro è cresciuta con il passare dei secoli. Malgrado il suo valore sia stato esaltato a volte eccessivamente, è innegabile che questa unità militare giocò un ruolo fondamentale nelle battaglie vittoriose di Isso e di Cheronea e inoltre, la sua lealtà era fuori discussione. Nei secoli successivi, le cavallerie d'élite presero come esempio quella di Alessandro.[PARAGRAPH:2:1]Fu il padre di Alessandro, Filippo il Macedone, a creare la cavalleria di supporto, che inizialmente era composta dai suoi più fedeli seguaci scelti tra i nobili macedoni.
